webTitle: Money: Even cautious investors are after a slice of the with-profits bonds action

fields.headline: Going along for the ride?
fields.standfirst: Even cautious investors are after a slice of the with-profits bonds action, says Rupert Jones
fields.trailText: Even cautious investors are after a slice of the with-profits bonds action, says Rupert Jones
fields.body:
They are hugely popular, particularly with older, more cautious investors keen to get a slice of stock market action though without a lot of the volatility that investing directly in shares can bring.

But with-profits bonds, where you invest a lump sum with a life insurer, have come under the spotlight recently because of concerns that some people may be buying them on the strength of an attractive headline rate without fully understanding how they work.

The Faculty and Institute of Actuaries - the body representing the number-crunchers who calculate insurance risk - has warned that some with-profits bond companies' advertising may be overstating the potential returns that people can enjoy. "There is a possibility that [in some cases] the marketing literature is not all that clear and people are expecting to get bigger returns than they are going to get," it says.

The actuaries have not named names, and stress that there are "a lot of good products around", but it is thought their comments may relate to practices such as promising a high headline rate of perhaps 9%-plus which applies for just the first year, with the rate after that significantly lower.

Nevertheless, there are some very good deals to be had, provided you are aware of the potential pitfalls.

With-profit bonds are popular because they provide an investment return that is generally better than you would get from a bank or building society. Your money is invested in a broad range of shares, gilts and property, and the aim is to provide a consistent return by smoothing out the ups and downs of the stock market. Each year the company will pay out a bonus that, once added to your investment, cannot be taken away.

With-profits bonds tend to be aimed at people looking to invest at least £5,000 and are very much a medium to long-term investment that should be held for at least five years. More than 20 companies offer with-profits bonds with Standard Life the most recent insurer to enter the market.

Concern has been expressed in some quarters about the high commission payments made to financial advisers selling the bonds - up to 7% in some cases. However, if you buy from a discount broker, they will often forego most of this by adding an "enhancement" of typically 4%-5% to your investment. Baronworth (Investment Services), based in Ilford, Essex, which has just published its latest with-profits bonds survey, offers investors enhancements of between 4.3% and 5.1% depending on how much is being invested. These are in addition to anything on offer from the companies them- selves, many of which give their own extra allocations.

What this means, say the brokers, is that on day one your money can actually end up being worth more than the amount you put in, even after taking charges into account. For example, if you invested £50,000 in the Prudential's Prudence Bond via Baronworth, it would add 5.1% and the Prudential would add 3.75%, which gives £54,425. Even once you have then taken away the Pru's 5% initial charge, you would still be left with £51,705.

Other discount brokers which offer enhancements include Chelsea Financial Services, based in London, and the With Profits Bond Shop in Nottingham.

Products that Colin Jackson at Baronworth likes include Liverpool Victoria's bond, which is offering a rate of 7.5% per annum guaranteed for the first two years - after that, the bonus rate will vary. Minimum investment is £10,000. Another bond he favours, aimed at those looking to take a regular income, is Legal & General's income bond, which is currently paying a rate of 6.5%. The minimum investment is £5,000.

Meanwhile, the Prudence Bond is one of the most popular products for those seeking capital growth. The Prudential says the bond has delivered a total return of 148% since launch nine years ago, so that £25,000 invested on May 1 1991 would have more than doubled to £62,000 by the start of this month.

webTitle: Circus review: Stories on the wire

fields.headline: Stories on the wire
fields.trailText:
Excentricus
Barbican, London ****
fields.body:
Excentricus
Barbican, London ****

Transformed since it was first seen in Edinburgh last year, Cirque Eloize's circus piece, Excentricus, is now the show it always strove to be: a playful celebration of love and life. It is laced with the abandon of flying on a trapeze, the tears of the clown and the control and improbable grace of eight people riding a bicycle.

Excentricus still has a tendency toward soft rock and hazy rainbows, but the performers inhabit their characters and interact with each other like actors and dancers. They take circus beyond the confines of mere feat and into the realm of meaning.

The stage approximates the village square: at times there is hustle and bustle; at others individual stories are played out on the rope, the ladder and the trapeze. There are wheels within wheels at work here, quite literally when it comes to bicycles. Cirque Eloize may not be able to match the Chinese State Circus's 14 on a bicycle but they convey infinitely more astonished pleasure at their own virtuosity

The show features the slightly sinister ring master figure, the hunky village show-off who performs his floor acrobatics to the crowd as if advertising what he would be like in bed, and the scrawny runt of the litter whose feelings of rejection turn the rope into an act of suicide. But the whole thing is glued together by Jamie Adkins's bashful village idiot, who doesn't miss a trick. It is like watching Michael Crawford's character Frank from Some Mothers Do 'Ave 'Em trying to walk the high wire and, to his amazement, succeeding.

There is the odd moment, particularly at the beginning, when it is all a little fey, but this is an immensely engaging circus show and a treat for young and old alike.

 Until September 2. Box office: 020-7638 8891.

webTitle: Money: If you consider yourself to be a shrewd predictor there are rich pickings

fields.headline: Fancy a flutter on fantasy Footsie?
fields.standfirst: If you consider yourself to be a shrewd predictor there are rich pickings. Rupert Jones reports
fields.trailText: If you consider yourself to be a shrewd predictor there are rich pickings. Rupert Jones reports
fields.body:
You've heard of fantasy football: now you can play fantasy Footsie with an investment product that lets you bet on what you think will happen to the stock market in the next 12 months.

With the Speculator Bond, launched by Birmingham Midshires, you estimate the likely growth - or fall - of the FTSE 100 index of leading shares. If you get it right, you'll enjoy a one-year gross return of up to 60% - more than eight times higher than current best-buy savings rates of 6%-7%. If you get it wrong, you get your original investment back with no interest.

It's just one of a spate of savings bonds launched over the last few days.

Birmingham Midshires says the Speculator Bond, available from this coming Friday, is a "first-of-its-kind" investment that will deliver a one-year gross return of between 22% and 60% if your prediction comes true. Minimum investment is £1,000, and you estimate the likely growth or decline of the FTSE 100 index over the 12 months between October 1 2000 and October 1 2001.

If you correctly predict that the FTSE will fall by 10% or more over the period, you will earn a return of 25% gross - £1,250 before tax, £1,200 net if you put in £1,000. If you correctly predict that the FTSE will fall, but by less than 10%, you will enjoy a return of 30% gross.

The other predictions you can choose from, plus what you get if you guess correctly, are as follows:

 FTSE remains static or grows by less than 10% - return of 22% gross;

 FTSE grows by at least 10% but less than 20% - return of 22% gross;

 FTSE grows by at least 20% but less than 30% - return of 30% gross;

 FTSE grows by at least 30% - return of 60% gross.

So to enjoy the biggest return, the market would have to make one hell of a leap.

You can increase your chances of winning by spreading your money across two or more "bands". Birmingham Midshires admits that the bond would not be a suitable place for someone to put their life savings. It's a novel way of spicing up a savings portfolio that might appeal particularly to savers who are clued-up about the stock market.

So what's likely to happen to the FTSE in the coming months? No one can say but looking back on past 12-month growth and decline trends for the FTSE 100 since 1986, these reveal that the most common occurrence has been for the FTSE to grow by between 10% and 20%. But this is no indicator of future performance.

So what do the experts think? Ian Millward at Chase de Vere Investments, an independent financial adviser, likes the bond, describing it as "a clever new product" and "a bit of fun". But he adds: "Your chances of getting it right are pretty slim. Trying to call the market over 12 months is really hard."

This week also saw the launch of a new FTSE 100-linked savings bond from the Woolwich, offering a potential return of up to 40% of the original investment. But it involves tying your money up for five years and isn't offering particularly stunning value once you look closely.

Between £6,000 and £500,000 can be invested in the Woolwich's guaranteed equity bond. The investment starts on October 27 this year and matures on October 27 2005.

At the end of the term you'll get a return based on the growth of the FTSE 100 over the period, up to a maximum of 40% of the original investment, so if you put in £10,000, the most you can get back is £14,000. If the index falls, you are guaranteed the return of your original investment. There are no set-up or management charges.

However, a maximum return of 40% of the original investment is equivalent to compound interest of around 7% a year, which is "not terribly exciting", says Mr Millward.

There are bank and building society instant-access-style accounts offering close to this - the Halifax's internet-operated Web Saver offers 6.35% from £1, Legal & General's Easy Access Tracker (phone and post account) currently pays 6.28% from £1, and Bristol & West's Clic Direct Easy Access account (also operated by phone and post) offers 6.85% from £1,000, though this includes a 1% interest bonus until December 19 2000.

Barclays has launched a stock market-linked savings bond which provides a return linked to the performance of the FTSE 100 or Standard & Poor's 500 index over a three-and-a-half year term (from next October 12 to April 13, 2004), but it's an offshore product only open to non-UK residents.

Fixed-rate savings bonds offered by banks and building societies are widely popular and Yorkshire building society unveiled a new one this week offering an interest rate of 6.60% gross per annum. You can choose a term of one or two years.

This one is unusual in having a minimum investment of just £100 - with many fixed-rate bonds the minimum is £1,000-plus. A monthly interest option is also available. This is a good rate but it's not the best around. Northern Rock is launching a fixed-rate bond offering 7.25% for one year gross. Minimum investment is £1,000.

webTitle: Tax bill blow to Widows windfalls

fields.headline: Tax bill blow to Widows windfalls
fields.trailText: Some Scottish Widows policyholders who received windfalls this week have been landed with an unexpected capital gains tax bill after getting far more money than they were expecting, the company said yesterday.
fields.body:
Some Scottish Widows policyholders who received windfalls this week have been landed with an unexpected capital gains tax bill after getting far more money than they were expecting, the company said yesterday.

The life insurer is paying out £5.8bn to 1.62m policyholders following its acquisition by Lloyds TSB. Windfalls vary dramatically, from £500 to £100,000-plus, with the average handout at £5,700.

Scottish Widows had said it was unable to say precisely how much people would be getting until they received the cheques, but its literature contained figures so policyholders could estimate their approximate likely payout. However, it appears that either some people wildly misjudged how much they were going to get, or the estimates in the literature were much too conservative.

Patrick Connolly at Chartwell Investment Management said it had been contacted by people expecting windfalls of under £7,200 - the current CGT allowance - who had actually received £10,000-£12,000. In some cases, someone receiving £12,000 could face a CGT tax liability of up to £1,920.

Scottish Widows said: "There have been a number of calls coming [from policyholders] saying they have got far more than they anticipated getting and therefore there are capital gains tax liabilities as a result."

fields.headline: Big on emotions
fields.trailText:
Elbow
Monarch, London ****
fields.body:
Elbow
Monarch, London ****

According to the playwright Dennis Potter's Singing Detective, elbow is the loveliest word in the English language. And Elbow, a quintet from Bury with sensitive souls and a sure touch for multi-layered anthems, certainly live up to that loveliness.

The band are nervous: guitarist Mark Potter and bassist Pete Turner barely look up at the crowd when they walk on stage. When Potter's guitar then fails to twang, the probability of tonight going to plan seems doubtful. But after some fiddling with the amp he is back on his stool and punching the air with glee. "There is no gig without Mark," singer Guy Garvey laughs, ruffling his friend's hair, before continuing the aptly named Can't Stop. This camaraderie is not only sweet, it is necessary. Like Radiohead, to whom the band have already been compared, there is so much going on that everyone's role is vital. While singer Garvey commands attention with his swaggering stage presence and by sliding from a whisper to a yell in one note, the rest of the band build up a wall of sound that is overwhelming.

Elbow aren't content merely to make you sigh: they want to blow you away. As Garvey plays guitar his head bounces off the mike stand, but he carries on, oblivious to everything but the music. Who can blame him? Listening to New Born mutate from gentle country pop to cymbal-crashing epic, you realise how long it has been since a band made you fall in love with them at first sight and how special Elbow are.

When the song ends, the crowd are momentarily stunned into silence before bursting into riotous applause. Garvey looks over at Potter for approval and is met by a smile. Elbow are a band of few words, but big emotions.

webTitle: Microchip company Arc International plans £400m float

fields.headline: Arc plans £400m float
fields.trailText: Arc International, a microchip company based in a disused Hertfordshire TV studio, is heading for a £400m flotation, which will turn its chief executive, Bob Terwilliger, into a multimillionaire.
fields.body:
Arc International, a microchip company based in a disused Hertfordshire TV studio, is heading for a £400m flotation, which will turn its chief executive, Bob Terwilliger, into a multimillionaire.

Arc is hoping to copy the stock market success of similar hi-tech electronics companies such as ARM Holdings and Bookham, both of which have surged to valuations of more than £3bn.

Mr Terwilliger said: "When I looked at the appreciation the UK market has for quality hi-tech companies, it made the decision to list in London very easy."

Arc designs chips for computer operating systems and gadgets - its products can be found in Toshiba's latest 3D cameras. Arc does no manufacturing in-house - its sells licences allowing customers to use its intellectual property.

Arc has a similar business model to ARM, which specialises in smaller chips for mobile phones. Arc, however, claims its chips are more flexible - customers can alter them easily for use in specific products.

Mr Terwilliger said the company was floating to raise money for acquisitions - Arc has bought three businesses in the past 10 months and is trying to become a one-stop shop providing all its clients' chip requirements.

"We want to offer our customers a total solution," he said. "We see ourselves growing rapidly in the next couple of years."

About a quarter of the firm's shares will be available in the offering by Goldman Sachs, raising £80m-£100m.

Florida-born Mr Terwilliger, 55, is the largest individual shareholder - his 5% stake will be worth about £20m.

He said: "Wealth is not what this is really all about. When you look at what the company's accomplished, a lot of people will be able to share in the benefits."

A former Silicon Valley engineer, Mr Terwilliger joined Arc four years ago, when the business had just eight staff. it now employs 230 people.

Arc is based in Carlton Television's old studios at Elstree.

fields.headline: First-night nerves
fields.trailText:
Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment
Royal Albert Hall, London ***
fields.body:
Orchestra of the Age of Enlightenment
Royal Albert Hall, London ***

When two of today's most exciting performers make their first appearance at the Proms, you expect something very special. This wasn't, however, quite the night that one had anticipated. The debutants in question were both French, conductor Louis Langrée and Natalie Dessay, who is said to be the greatest coloratura soprano of our time.

Initially it seemed that circumstances were against the pair. The Albert Hall was so stuffy that the OAE abandoned their dinner jackets at half time and dripped their way to the end of the concert in shirt sleeves. Langrée opened with Haydn's "Trauer" Symphony, admirably capturing its reined-in tension, its Bach-like austerity and its brief efflorescences into a pained lyricism. But he had to contend with mobile phones, one of which started squeaking Bach at the end of the symphony's slow movement. The finale seethed with understandable rage.

When Dessay appeared to sing a selection of Mozart's most difficult arias, she looked terribly nervous, and cleared her throat a lot both during and between numbers. Essaying Martern Aller Arten from Die Entfuhrung aus dem Serail, she used a score, yet fluffed an entry. The extended lines of Vorrei Spiegarvi, O Dio exposed a beat in the voice. webTitle: Money: A guide to keeping motor insurance premiums at a minimum

fields.headline: What's driving up the cost of insurance?
fields.standfirst: As premiums continue to climb, Patrick Collinson offers a guide to keeping them at a minimum
fields.trailText: As premiums continue to climb, Patrick Collinson offers a guide to keeping them at a minimum
fields.body:
Soaring personal injury claims and fast-rising motor repair costs are driving up car insurance premiums, with one forecaster predicting a further 25% on your bill this year. But there are plenty of routes to holding down the cost.

Switching insurers is the most obvious and, on average, saves around 20%-30% on your premium. As a starting point, log on to the internet and obtain a quote from an online broker such as screentrade.co.uk or egg.com. Screentrade has a panel of 15 insurers, while Egg claims it will arrange a quote in just 10 seconds from its selection of nine insurers. Both promise to beat any renewal quotes from other insurers, and if they don't, will refund you the difference.

If you are not on the net, a good alternative is a high street or telephone-based broker such as Hill House Hammond (0845-3000443) or the AA (0800-444777).

One drawback to the on-line sites is that they tend not to include the giant telephone-based direct insurers such as Direct Line (020-8686-2468), Admiral (0800-600800) and Churchill (0800-200300), which may offer lower quotes. But as one of the first questions from the call centre operator is: "What's the best quote you've got so far?", the online quotes give you a benchmark they have to beat.

The majority of insurers are standing firm on premium increases because they have incurred steep losses in recent years. But there are always new entrants, and others trying to increase market share, who are worth trying. Two currently in this bracket are Tesco (0845-3004400) and Co-op Insurance Services (08000-282929).

The next cost-cutting step is to decide what level of cover you need, and how you can adjust it to reduce the premium.

 Increase the excess. According to Hill House Hammond, doubling the voluntary excess (typically £100) can knock about 15% off the premium.

 Reduce the number of drivers. "Any driver" policies have soared in cost. Restricting the number of drivers on your policy to just one other named driver can cut the premium by up to 30%. Adding teenagers to a policy is particularly expensive. Whereas premiums for over 60-year-olds are up by around 15% over the last year, premiums for under 25-year-olds have jumped by more than 50%.

 Improve car security. Many insurers will lop 5% off a premium if the car has an insurer-approved alarm and immobiliser.

 Change your car. Smaller, older cars cost far less to insure than newer, racier models. Car magazines list the insurance group cars fall into; a £40,000 BMW Z3 is in group 19, a £6,500 Fiat Seicento is in group 1.

 Limit your mileage. If you can limit the amount you drive to under 5,000 miles a year, most insurers will cut premiums, some by as much as 15%.

 Avoid unnecessary extras. For example, if you drive abroad, look for a policy that offers free European cover rather than an add-on.

 Don't lie. The most common lie is to register cars outside London or the other high-rated metropolitan areas, either at parents or at fictitious addresses. Direct Line says doing so automatically invalidates your insurance.

 Grow up. There is a remarkable drop in premiums after your 20s. Hill House Hammond says the average premium quote for someone under 25 is currently £1,297.86. For someone aged 25-50 it is £455.01, while for over 50-year-olds the average is £448.66.

Female under-25s obtain premium quotes which are about 20% less than males, but the picture reverses after that, with insurers charging older female drivers slightly more than older male drivers. So a sex-change op won't do much for your premiums, then.

This week's scare over car insurance premiums was provoked by a report from consumer analysts Mintel; it says that premium increases in 1999 were 20% and will be a further 25% in 2000.

"At present, premium rises are doing little more than cover the increased cost of personal injury claims. The cost of motor repairs has also become a factor, with garage 'charge out' rates rising sharply and garages no longer prepared to depress labour rates to guarantee volume business," says the report. It estimates that even with a 25% increase this year, most insurers will not move into profit until 2002.

However, Direct Line and others dispute the figures. Direct Line, while refusing to disclose its average premium rates, says that its increases will come in below 25%, while Tesco says: "We don't expect our prices to rise by anything like 25%."

CIS, meanwhile, says its premium increases were around 10% last year rather than 20%, and it expects to keep increases low again this year.

webTitle: Money: The best loans for those bound for the showrooms in search of x-reg

fields.headline: Save a bit Xtra on the new reg
fields.standfirst: X-fever is sweeping Britain - not only the mutant movie, but the new car registration plates out next week. Patrick Collinson looks at the best loans for those bound for the showrooms
fields.trailText: X-fever is sweeping Britain - not only the mutant movie, but the new car registration plates out next week. Patrick Collinson looks at the best loans for those bound for the showrooms
fields.body:
The X-Men (and women) will be swooping on car dealerships this week as the X-registration plate comes into force from Friday. Around 400,000 cars are expected to be registered in September alone, but in the dash to buy an X-car, don't forget to shop around for the best motor finance deal.

Research by Jobs & Money shows that picking the wrong finance package can easily add £2,000 to the cost of a car and there are huge differences in the cost of "payment protection" on personal loans, with the AA charging twice as much as rival lenders.

Northern Rock is cheapest for personal loans. Borrowing £6,000 will cost £190.33 per month if you plan to repay over three years, compared with £207.91 per month that Barclayloan charges for the same sum. For a £12,000 loan, Northern Rock again tops the table, with a monthly cost of £380.66 compared with £415.28 at Lloyds TSB.

With £12,000 you can select from a wide range of new cars; this week Mercedes lopped up to 20% off prices, cutting the cost of its A140 classic from £14,490 to £12,790. Our best buy table on page 13 shows how the list price of a car can easily be undercut by dealers, whether on the forecourt, telephone or internet. For example, the list price of a Ford Focus 1.6LX is £14,000, but Jamjar.com is offering it at £11,287.23, DC Cook sells it for £11,700, and Woolwich Motorbase for £13,479.33.

Northern Rock says its loan rates are available to 98% of applicants, and that it does not cherry-pick the best customers. However, loan applicants at all lenders will be credit checked and scored. Note that NatWest's loans, among the cheaper deals, are only for existing customers, whereas all the other loans are open to any applicants.

All lenders will push you to buy their often very expensive payment protection insurance. When Jobs & Money contacted the banks' call-centres for loan quotes, each time the "with insurance" quote was given first, and the caller encouraged to take it out. Yet for most borrowers payment protection is of dubious value, especially if they are in regular employment.

The AA's payment protection is remarkably expensive. On a £6,000 loan over 36 months, it adds up to £1,583.64, compared with £745.68 at the Nationwide and £878.40 at Northern Rock.

This means that an 11.9 APR loan from the AA with payment protection is more expensive than the same loan from Lloyds TSB, despite its 15.9 APR.

Nationwide's cheap payment protection also means its 9.7 APR loan is better value than Northern Rock's 9.2 APR loan with insurance.

An AA spokesman says: "We see our payment protection as a premium product in this market. Many of the other protection schemes limit the number of claims you can make, which we don't, and we give joint cover so that it covers your spouse, plus a lump sum benefit of £5,000 should either die. It's a Rolls-Royce quality protection scheme." It is also worth noting that the AA's loan package includes a free car buyer inspection, worth £99.

The figures in the table are for personal loans, but there are other ways - deferred car purchase loans, hire purchase and personal contract plans:

 Deferred car purchase
Offered by Alliance & Leicester, Direct Line and NatWest, this gives you the money to buy a swanky car without huge monthly payments. The catch is a chunky final payment. For example, a £12,000 deferred loan from A&L over 36 months costs £268.07 a month, compared with £383.96 a month for a personal loan of the same amount. But after three years, the borrower has to repay a deferred amount of £5,068.

A&L says the deferred amount effectively represents the "equity'" in the car. "It's much more flexible than the manufacturers' personal contract plan. From day one you own the car, you're not hedged in by mileage restrictions and if you want to keep the car you can; just carry on making the same payments."

 Hire purchase
Usually used to finance a new rather than used car purchase. The borrower pays a deposit of around 10-15% and makes monthly payments over one to five years, and does not own the car until they have made all the payments. The finance is secured on the car, so it could be repossessed if payments are not made.

 Personal contract plan
This works in a similar way to deferred car purchase, but is offered largely by car dealers rather than traditional lenders. A deposit of at least 10% is paid and repayments are low because a "minimum guaranteed future value" (MGFV) is taken off the purchase price. The MGFV is what the car is worth when the deal ends, as long as the driver has not exceeded mileage limits.

At the end of the agreed period, the driver can keep the car and pay the MGFV or hand back the car and walk away, or take out a new agreement.

One advantage is that you are less likely to be rejected for a personal contract plan, as the finance is secured on the car, which can be repossessed at any time. They are also attractive, says Roger Ashman of leasing company PHH, when buying a car such as a Mercedes or BMW which has a high resale value. This can make a more expensive car cheaper to buy than a car which rapidly depreciates.

webTitle: Money: The slump in the shares of BT is hurting a million small investors

fields.headline: Telecom stock not the call it was
fields.standfirst: While BT's shares slump is not as great as that of other former monopolies, small investors are being hit, says Robin Stoddart
fields.trailText: While BT's shares slump is not as great as that of other former monopolies, small investors are being hit, says Robin Stoddart
fields.body:
The slump in the shares of BT is hurting a million small investors who have continued to hold the shares directly since privatisation and millions more who hold units in inactively managed funds. Mounting debt and the need for further heavy investment in mobile telephone developments, particularly in Germany, makes the immediate outlook particularly dull.

Although BT's management has often seemed flat-footed, particularly when its big move into the US was trumped by rival local bidders, resulting, ironically, in a return of cash to shareholders in 1998, the decline in the shares has been less dire than that seen among other former national monopolies.

Falls of over half from peak prices, usually coinciding with the technology bubble that burst at the end of March, are common. Compared with the still more highly valued Deutsche Telekom (DT), which remains under majority state ownership, BT's share price has slipped, rather than plunged, in recent weeks.

Buyers of DT's relatively small public offering two months ago have suffered badly with a loss of well over a third. A discount and future loyalty bonus conceded to private buyers provided false lures. At least home and foreign buyers in the UK privatisation are still making profits of several hundred per cent on their holdings and the domestic perks were real enough.

Once the most highly-valued UK company and such an apparent cash cow that the regulatory office increased the pace at which reductions in charges were demanded, BT is now headed for a debt burden of £30 billion. This at a time when interest rates have risen and are generally, if not universally, expected to rise a little further.

While long-term rates on loans of the highest borrower quality are still modest by historical standards, the pace at which the debt has climbed, has made prospective American lenders draw in their horns.

This follows the astronomic UK and German licence auctions for new mobile systems and the agreement for the acquisition of most of the outstanding stake in Viag Interkom, DT's relatively small private sector rival in Germany. A planned $10bn bond issue has been delayed.

Although BT will no doubt get the money before long it will have to pay considerably more than the 6.5% or so at which top borrowers hope to tap the market. This applies also to DT's recent larger issue. If its credit rating is reduced, the interest rate will rise.

Many other fund raising issues, including multi-billion part flotations of the mobile phone subsidiaries of the leading operators in Holland, France, Spain and one or two Scandinavian countries are impending. DT pulled back from its mobile phone part-divestment in June.

As the need to raise funds from disposals becomes more pressing, BT may be among the better placed. As with DT, it may perforce have to hang on to the whole of Cellnet, which is now showing a high return. BT aims to sell a large part of the Yellow Pages advertising branch quite soon.

It will be increasingly keen to unload the old fixed-line household business that was its mainstay, but has become a source of criticism and regulatory complaint in the era of the internet. By holding out against free local calls and maintaining standing charges, it has milked high returns from home connections.

Such disposals would involve a lower dividend but open the way to a higher valuation of the professional and international communications and data transmission activities. BT would become a high technology growth company, rather than an old economy consumer services provider.

Equipment companies still command particularly high ratings and the anticipated expenditure on new mobile phones and systems will provide the main growth area of every advanced economy in coming years. The personal computer may even be supplanted in most homes.

BT meets the requirement for high-speed flat-rate internet charges, though, as AltaVista's problems show, free unlimited access is not yet on offer.

The yield on BT shares is the best in the sector and indeed the only one available from a leading operator apart from Vodafone's tiny distribution and American partner AT&T's similar return of 2.8 per cent. However, turnover growth is the main criterion for investors. At around £50bn, BT's market capitalisation is under three times its sales - not the high-tech rating that might be justifiable.

webTitle: Money: New evidence reveals how lenders have short-changed the repossessed

fields.headline: Shutting the door on the house price misery
fields.standfirst: New evidence reveals how lenders have short-changed the repossessed. Tony Levene reports
fields.trailText: New evidence reveals how lenders have short-changed the repossessed. Tony Levene reports
fields.body:
As the house price boom shows its first signs of cracking, top of the market purchasers must now hope that the relative optimism of property commentators is not misplaced.

For there are still many victims of previous home price booms and busts around, all reminders of what could happen if the "buyers turning their backs on the housing market in July" - revealed by this week's Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors research - turns into a rout.

But many of those who lost out in the frantic housing market of the late 80s and early 90s might now find they have greater muscle against the debt collectors who are still harrassing them for shortfall debts: the difference between the price achieved on a repossession sale and what they borrowed, plus interest and other costs.

For today, despite claims from the home loans industry that repossessed properties are always sold at the very best prices achievable, Jobs & Money can expose how bosses at one top home loan company ordered staff to sell off "homes in possession" at potentially knockdown prices. It is an admission that will add fuel to the controversy over the way mortgage firms and debt chasers deal with ex-customers who have lost homes.

And Jobs & Money can also reveal how the same big mortgage company conceded it had been lending on low quality criteria - in other words, it had encouraged people to stretch resources to breaking point with loans which they might not be able to repay if interest rates rose or their earnings fell.

Taken together, our revelations - and there is little doubt that they applied to many lenders - could lead to new legal clashes between mortgage companies and former customers whom they are now chasing for arrears and shortfall payments. Customers may be able to claim they were misled and mis-sold.

Confidential memos show that branch managers at a major home loan company were told to sell repossessed properties at ultra-low prices to get them off the books.

One of the main complaints of repossession victims has been the low price received for their former properties when they were sold - often to professional bargain hunters at auctions. This shortfall has exacerbated the arrears - and made them doubly difficult to bear once interest is added to the loss.

Mortgage companies have always maintained the prices they obtained on repossessions were fair market prices.

Internal documents and memos from Cheltenham & Gloucester, dating from the 80s when it was still a mutually owned building society - it is now part of the Lloyds TSB empire - show it was already worried about repossessions in 1985. They were, of course, to get far worse over the following decade.

In that year, around 1,400 C&G-financed homes were seized - and that was almost 15 times higher than in 1982. Financial losses were also mounting fast, although mortgage indemnity guarantee insurers paid most of the deficit.  Branches to accept offers within 10% of valuation;

 Agents must market properties labelled "Finance Company Re-Possession - offers around £XXXXXX". Offers lower than that had to be referred to the society's arrears department.

Accepting a 10% cut gives £45,000 for a property worth £50,000 and produces a £5,000 shortfall. This could easily turn into a debt of £25,000 over eight to 10 years with interest and other charges.

And labelling homes as repossessions gives a further turn on the screw - buyers know it is a desperation sale.

The second part of the C&G loss control plan was to improve lending quality. Longhurst told managers: "In recent years you have been urged to lend as much as you can, but you have never been urged to lend on rubbish or to rubbish."

He called for "a more careful consideration of each and every new mortgage application". C&G made major changes in the way it deals with repossession properties in 1994. "Selling agents are instructed not to advertise the property as a repossession as this could be in conflict with our duty of care to obtain the best price.

But Abbey's staff misunderstood how VAT worked. The £25,000 figure is turnover, not profit - his annual earnings were £11,000.

Harborne only lived in his £74,500 Wandsworth, London house for a month. "I gave back the keys. I was blacklisted for credit - I couldn't even get a bank account."

In 1997, the Abbey sent him a bill for £45,036, but after Harborne advertised his plight on his own website, Abbey settled for £3,500.

Recently, some mortgage brokers and lenders have been offering up to five times salary - rather than the more prudent 3.25 times as borrowers geared up to meet fast rising property prices. And this has led to fears that repossessions and shortfalls could all happen again to a new generation of borrowers.

Repossessed: The college lecturer

The Archaeology lecturer Eleanor Scott paid £18,500 for a Newcastle flat in 1991. When it was sold as a repossession, it fetched just £1,300. Now she wants the lenders to admit it should not have lent her the money as the valuation surveyor failed to put a fair value on the property.

Dr Scott borrowed £16,500 from National & Provincial Building Society - now part of Abbey National. Two years later, on leaving the property, she realised prices had fallen, but N & P would not allow her to sell privately at a loss as this would deprive it of a claim under its mortgage indemnity guarantee policy.

She failed in an attempt to rent the property - and being in a less desirable area of Newcastle, it was damaged by substantial vandalism while it stood empty.

In 1995, the N & P wrote to her - several months after she had contacted them - with a Voluntary Possession Form. The lender assured her it "would start to actively market the property to obtain the best market value advised by two independent estate agents."

When sold at auction the flat fetched just £1,300. The Abbey eventually asked her for £16,991 in shortfall via solicitors Eversheds. After she wrote to Abbey National chief executive Ian Harley, the bank cut its demand to £7,000.

But Dr Scott, who now lives in Hampshire, cannot afford this either on her part-time salary.

She says: "I relied on the valuation surveyor the N & P used. Surely if it was worth far less than what I paid, the surveyor should have turned down the loan. After all, it is their security that is at risk and the money of their savers."

But although the valuation survey is paid for by the home buyer, it belongs to the lender. It is only more recently that lenders have agreed to let borrowers see this document if they ask to do so.

webTitle: Websites like jamjar say they make the best offers, but not if you're trading in

fields.headline: The net or a forecourt
fields.standfirst:
Websites like jamjar say they make the best offers, but not if you're trading in. Richard Simpson shops around to test the market
Shopping unlimited
fields.trailText: Websites like jamjar say they make the best offers, but not if you're trading in. Richard Simpson shops around to test the market
fields.body:
Click on to any one of the online new car sites, like Direct Line's www.jamjar.com or www.virgin.com, and you'll be gobsmacked by the savings they're claiming. For example, jamjar says that it is averaging savings of £850, and adds that if we all bought our new X-reg cars from it this September then the great British car buying public would save £300m in one month alone.

It all sounds terribly impressive, as does jamjar's statement that in just over a month's online trading it has delivered almost 100 cars, with another 500 or so on order.

But look harder and something doesn't quite add up, because jamjar has been advertising extensively on television - with those irritating little "models" - and yet it has still only sold 100 cars, which is a vanishing fraction of the annual total of around 2m new car registrations.

And jamjar's case isn't helped by the fact that its savings claims are made against the manufacturer's recommended retail prices (RRPs), which as the motor trade never ceases to remind us, are almost always rather higher than the price you'll actually pay anyway.

So, if you're out buying a new car in the next couple of weeks you need to be aware of the reason why everyone isn't already buying online - and fundamentally it's because the price you pay for your new car is only half the financial story.

After all, most of us have a car to sell when we go looking for a new one, so what really matters is the "transaction cost" or "cost to change" - which, of course, is the difference between the price of your new car and what you get for the old one.

The financial implication of all this is obvious enough: because an apparently cheap new car will become altogether more expensive if you get a low offer for your old one.

So might uncompetitive transaction costs be the reason why we aren't buying all our new motors over the web?

As an entirely unscientific test, I decided to see what it would cost me to change my 1997 P Citroen Xantia 1.8 16v with 40,000 miles for a shiny new Ford Mondeo 1.8LX.

Jamjar will sell me the new Ford for a very tempting sounding £11,561, while their offer for my old car was £3,610 - giving me a net cost to change of £7,951. (And incidentally that was for a UK-sourced car, which I could have as soon as I wanted it.)

So, could a Ford dealer do better? I called a local dealer and was told they would give me "about £4,000" for the Citroen, while my new Mondeo would cost £12,500. That meant a cost to change which was more than £500 worse than jamjar's.

I then asked if there'd be some haggling room, and was told that I'd "very probably" be able to get the cost to change down from that £8,500 first offer. However, the beauty of jamjar is that it's hassle - and haggle - free.

Had jamjar won the day outright? Not quite, because these days many of the big car supermarkets are also selling new cars.

Motorpoint of Derby offered me a shiny new UK-sourced X-plate Mondeo 1.8 LX for just £9,999, and then bid £3,600 for my old Xantia. That meant an internet-busting cost to change of £6,399, which was more than £1,500 better than jamjar's net transaction cost.

It's hardly a scientific test I'll grant you, but my ring-around helps to make the point that heavily promoted and strongly branded websites aren't necessarily the cheapest source of new cars.

And that's hardly surprising when you realise that those of them who do offer a complete service, as jamjar does, rely on the established motor trade to deal with their part exchange cars, and to sort out those all-important test drives too.

In jamjar's case, that motor trade partner is Dixon Motors plc, and it's quite hard to see how jamjar can achieve really low transaction costs when it's effectively adding a whole tier of marketing costs on to an established dealer distribution network.

But let's not be too hard on jamjar, because I find that many of the other new car websites are less than enthusiastic about taking old cars in part-exchange at all, while to its credit jamjar have worked hard to make the process simple and customer-friendly.

So, the best advice is to shop widely this September, both on and offline, and if you've got an old car to sell or part-exchange, then never lose sight of that cost to change figure. Because in the end it's the one figure which will tell you for certain that you've done a really good deal.

And that applies whether you're buying over the internet or from the dealer round the corner.

webTitle: Money: Pension loophole closed by Court of Appeal decision

fields.headline: Standard Life pays out  £77,000 after admitting pensions negligence
fields.trailText: A Court of Appeal decision last month has closed a loophole which Standard Life tried to exploit after mis-selling a pension, writes Richard Colbey. The decision will make it harder for pension and life assurance companies to escape liability when they do get things wrong.
fields.body:
A Court of Appeal decision last month has closed a loophole which Standard Life tried to exploit after mis-selling a pension, writes Richard Colbey. The decision will make it harder for pension and life assurance companies to escape liability when they do get things wrong.

Lesley Gorham's husband was sold a pension by Standard Life in January 1992. He was working for BT, and would have been far better off in its occupational pension scheme.

This was particularly the case as he had told the salesman that his first priority was providing for his family, and the occupational pension had a generous benefit should he die prematurely. When Standard Life reviewed his pension in November 1992, it realised the mistake and advised him to switch to the BT scheme. Unfortunately, though, effecting that switch was something Mr Gorham never got around to doing, and he died in September 1994, leaving two young children.

If he had been a member of the BT scheme for two years before his death, his family would have been entitled to benefits worth around £77,000. This was in addition to a substantial sum they would have received even if he had only joined when he was advised to in November 1992.

Of course, as he had not been in the scheme at all they missed out on these altogether. In court, Standard Life accepted that the advice it had given was negligent and that it had had a duty not to sell him one of its pensions. But it still argued that Mrs Gorham should not receive any compensation, claiming that as its contract had been with Mr Gorham, only he should have the right to take action for breach of it.

This argument will not sound very attractive to the pension-buying public, who do not expect negligent institutions to be able to rely on technicalities to escape liability. Even if the argument were legally valid, a mutual body supposedly run for the benefit of its members, might have been expected to pay out anyway.

Standard Life also argued that in any case compensation should be restricted to the £77,000, and not the additional sums Mrs Gorham would have received had her husband followed its advice and switched schemes in November 1994. The Court of Appeal decided, by a majority of two to one, that her claim was restricted to that sum, that the further losses had been caused by Mr Gorham's own fault in not switching.

However, the Court had no difficulty in deciding that the £77,000 had to be paid, despite Standard Life's claim that there was nothing in the Financial Services Act or any of the Act's Codes that gave third parties the right to compensation.

The life assurance industry so often makes the assumption that this legislation provides the entire basis for its liability, that it was reassuring to see the Court of Appeal remind it that it is also subject to the common law.

The court considered a 1995 decision in a claim brought by Carol White, who would have benefited had her father's will been finalised. She was able to recover compensation from the solicitors who had been instructed to draft the will but never quite got around to it before he died.

There the House of Lords considered there was no reason for not saying the solicitors owed her a duty to act properly: she was going to lose out if they didn't.

The Court of Appeal considered that there was no reason to distinguish between Mrs White's situation and Mrs Gorham's. Lord Justice Pill said "practical justice" required beneficiaries under pension schemes to have rights when things went wrong.

A spokesman for Standard Life said that it would have let Mrs Gorham keep the £77,000 even if it had succeeded in the Court of Appeal. However, that does not alter the fact that at the first court hearing it was aiming to deprive her of everything. The episode will have cost the company more in legal fees than it paid out to Mrs Gorham.

Richard Colbey is a barrister.

fields.headline: Who cares if you can't
fields.trailText: Every Saturday night, the amateur Frank Sinatras in my local pub find it impossible to resist the temptation to over-act their way through My Way.
fields.body:
Every Saturday night, the amateur Frank Sinatras in my local pub find it impossible to resist the temptation to over-act their way through My Way.

And the line that gets the biggest response is when the singers scrunch their faces and belt out "Regreeaaats, I've had a feeeeew... "

Maybe it's that type of pub - old men brooding over pints - but that regret goes down a storm every week. But I have a fantasy: one day someone is going to disrupt this OAP karaoke by singing Je Ne Regrette Rien, and they'll be jeered off by a hard core of regretters gathered around the makeshift stage.

Fights might break out between the Regret Nothing crowd and the resident Regret Everything crew.

For a reason I can't quite explain, I was reminded of these regretful drinkers when I saw a naff cable television advert for life insurance. The thrust of the advert was that none of us are getting any younger and any of us could be hit by a bus tomorrow and we wouldn't want to be left regretting that we'd made no provision for those left behind.

But the flaw in this hit-by-a-bus scenario is that it always assumes that the Grim Reaper is at the wheel and that there are no loose ends left untied; we're dead, the insurance pays out and our carefully prepared will allocates our worldly possessions to our loved ones.

But life is full of loose ends, and what isn't explained is what happens if the bus doesn't leave us dead, but so badly incapacitated that we're unlikely to be able to handle our own finances again. There might be critical illness cover in the insurance for our relatives, but the biggie financial question is who is going to take charge of handling the rest of our money. If we were dead, an executor would step in. But if you're alive, who can take charge of your bank accounts, credit cards, shares and anything else that's only in your name?

Less melodramatically than being hit by a bus, ours is an ageing population, which means many more people will have relatives who at some point will no longer be able to look after their own finances.

Even though someone's health might have failed, there are still bills to be paid, repayments to be kept up, bank accounts to be checked and decisions to be made on their behalf over savings and investments. If you're incapacitated and in long-term care, who's going to sign the cheques or collect any money that's owed to you?

The person who can intervene in such circumstances is given what is known as the "enduring powers of attorney". And, back to our regrets, this person, who might be a friend, relative or someone else you trust, has to be appointed before the bus hits you. It means that you grant someone else a kind of financial guardian status, where the attorney can sign cheques, move money in and out of accounts and act in whatever they believe to be your best interests.

"Everyone should consider arranging an attorney, as you never know what might happen. The alternative can be a lengthy and expensive application to the Court of Protection to allow a supervised individual to act on your behalf. Preparing for an attorney in advance allows people to make their own choice as to who they want to deal with their financial affairs, should they become mentally incapable of looking after them themselves," says Jan Wright, a solicitor who specialises in this area at Radcliffes law firm in Westminster.

Nominating your chosen attorney involves filling in an official document, probably with the advice of a solicitor. This can grant almost unlimited power over your financial affairs or can be limited to specific areas. Either way, the powers can't kick in until you've lost your powers of reasoning and the appointed person registers their Enduring Power of Attorney with the Public Trust Office.

Registration (which costs a £50 fee) also requires the attorney to inform at least three relatives of the person concerned that they are taking on these powers (usually carried out unsupervised and without the obligation to keep accounts), with relatives having the right to make a legal challenge to the appointment.

Last year there were 12,000 registrations of attorneys, and with the anticipated increase in longevity and the illnesses associated with it, there could be many more people needing to find someone able to take up the financial reins on their behalf. And as the pub Sinatras might say, choosing your own pre-death executor will help you to do it your way.

And the line that gets the biggest response is when the singers scrunch their faces and belt out "Regreeaaats, I've had a feeeeew... " Maybe it's that type of pub - old men brooding over pints - but that regret goes down a storm every week. fields.headline: Dressed to thrill
fields.trailText:
Igor Zelensky and the Stars of International Ballet
Lowry, Salford ***
fields.body:
Igor Zelensky and the Stars of International Ballet
Lowry, Salford ***

Igor Zelensky may have purloined one or two of the Kirov's dancers for this night of ballet's greatest hits, but one absence was immediately apparent: the orchestra. The show opened with Balanchine's Apollo, with Stravinsky's score piped through two conspicuous amplifiers. Although this did little to diminish the audience's enjoyment, it did make for awkward pauses, some errant timing and rather tinny acoustics.

Zelensky's strong-jawed Apollo presided over the muses as they cavorted around him on eager tip-toes. Yulia Makhalina's Terpsichore deftly nuanced her complicity with the god through her bold, mature movements, while Zelensky's daunting pirouettes signalled an exemplary technique that, strangely, is not quite animated beyond his majestic presence.

Although devoid of sets - the performers relied simply on occasional props and imaginative lighting - there was no shortage of glittering costumes. Dressed in a silver-studded waistcoat, Thomas Edur, currently with the English National Ballet, danced the Sleeping Beauty pas de deux with Svetlana Ivanova, who was resplendent in a pink tutu and tiara.

More relaxed than the previous pairing, they had some fun as Edur's leaps and turns competed with Ivanova's amusing range of theatrical gestures, from disdainful hand-flicking to flirtatious hips. The middle act of Balanchine's Jewels, Rubies, was another dazzling affair, even though the irrepressibly quick Andrian Fadeyev seemed to be slightly out of time with Irina Golub, whose facial expressions and hands-on-hips petulance were a delight.

Zelensky returned for the Don Quixote pas de deux, and immediately re-established himself with more tight, smooth leaps and pirouettes. One of his own compositions formed the finale, danced to a Japanese percussion score that at times sounded like rock'n'roll. An ensemble piece, the four girls, four boys, all in black, engaged in boisterous shadowplay. Young Fadeyev was again exhilarating, while Zelensky let out a despairing yell as he finally leapt into the wings.

fields.headline: England switch to Cole
fields.trailText: David Lacey believes Kevin Keegan's selection to face France on Saturday week just confirms England's present limitations despite the recall of Andy Cole.
fields.body:
Alan Shearer's retirement from international football could mark the renaissance of Andy Cole's faltering England career. The friendly against France in Paris tomorrow week may well give the 28-year-old Manchester United striker an opportunity to prove to Kevin Keegan that he is ready to take over from Shearer in the attack for the 2002 World Cup qualifiers.

Cole was left out of Keegan's squad for this summer's European championship after telling the England coach that he doubted his fitness and wanted to be ready for the new season with United. "There are still a few who can't believe that but I keep saying it because it's the truth," Keegan stressed yesterday when he announced the squad for the encounter with the world and European champions.

Now, with Cole fully fit and showing good early-season form at Old Trafford, Keegan gave every sign that he would recall him to the side against France in the hope of finding a successful goalscoring combination for the World Cup qualifiers against Germany and Finland early in October.

"He deserves to have a chance," the coach said. "He was an outstanding 23-year-old when I had him at Newcastle but at 28 he's in his prime."

The alternative would seem to be Liverpool's Emile Heskey, still in credit with Keegan after his impressive performance in the goalless friendly against Argentina in February. Keegan's problem, however, is that memories of what might have looked promising before Euro 2000 were quickly buried by England's failures once they got there and their early return home after defeats by Portugal and Romania.

The squad against France, which will form the basis of the teams that will face the Germans and the Finns, confirms England's present limitations, for all the coach's continued insistence that the quality is there.

Shearer (retired), Robbie Fowler (unfit) and Richard Wright, dropped as third-choice goalkeeper in favour of David James, are missing from the squad of 22 picked for Euro 2000.

Cole, Kieron Dyer, James and Rio Ferdinand have been recalled, along with Darren Anderton, another who announced that he wanted to spend the summer getting himself fully fit.

Tony Adams will, as Keegan had intimated, take over the captaincy from Shearer in spite of reservations about his fitness after only one appearance in Euro 2000.

"Tony Adams is the most natural person to take over from Alan," Keegan said yesterday. "His leadership qualities are there for all to see. People respect him. But it may be short-term and we have to be prepared for that."

Steven Gerrard, the 20-year-old Liverpool midfielder who played impressively against Germany in Charleroi, is another likely starter in Paris and Keegan also hinted that he might use Steve McManaman as a substitute even though the Real Madrid man is short of match practice.

With Dyer and Rio Ferdinand available, England look a little better equipped to produce the quality of passing and movement so badly lacking during Euro 2000. But when Keegan yet again talks fondly of recalling the 38-year-old Stuart Pearce, it is clear that in certain positions his options are still severely limited.

 Seven players from the English Premiership are included in France's 22-man squad - unchanged from Euro 2000 - for the friendly. The match will be the central defender Laurent Blanc's last for his country.

Goalkeepers: Barthez (Manchester United), Lama (Rennes), Rame (Bordeaux). Defenders: Blanc (Internazionale), Candela (Roma), Desailly (Chelsea), Leboeuf (Chelsea), Lizarazu (Bayern Munich), Thuram (Parma). Midfielders: Deschamps (Valencia), Djorkaeff (Kaiserslautern), Karembeu (Middlesbrough), Micoud (Parma), Petit (Barcelona), Vieira (Arsenal), Zidane (Juventus). Strikers: Anelka (Paris St-Germain), Dugarr y (Bordeaux), Henry (Arsenal), Pires (Arsenal), Trezeguet (Juventus), Wiltord (Bordeaux).

fields.headline: McManaman in Chelsea talks
fields.trailText: Steve McManaman has admitted that his position at Real Madrid is untenable, according to reports in the Spanish press, and was last night linked with a move to Chelsea.
fields.body:
Steve McManaman has admitted that his position at Real Madrid is untenable, according to reports in the Spanish press, and was last night linked with a move to Chelsea.

The Real executive council member Amancio Amaro met representatives of both the midfielder and Chelsea yesterday to discuss a possible transfer. However, the fee of £12m plus Chelsea's Norwegian striker Tore Andre Flo is likely to prove a stumbling block.

McManaman was upset when told he would not be making the trip to Monaco to play in the Super Cup against Galatasaray today. "This is incredible," he told El Pais.

"I think I deserve some respect," he was reported as saying by Marca. "They should give me an explanation as to why I'm not going to Monaco, but so far no one has spoken to me.

"I am pretty upset because everyone likes to play in these sorts of games, but my aim is still to stay at the club."

The Real coach Vicente del Bosque has told McManaman that he would have few chances of first-team football in the coming season after the arrival of the world-record signing Luis Figo and his fellow midfield players Claude Makelele and Flavio Conceicao. "I'm the only player who hasn't played a single minute of pre-season," McManaman said. "This is very tough for me."

He is aware that not playing may jeopardise his England place. "I would like to play in the next World Cup and at the moment that is going to be very difficult," he told Marca.

Madrid, the holders, are in pot one, alongside Manchester United and the other top seeds, in today's draw for the first group stage of the Champions League.

Arsenal are in pot two, with Milan and Galatasaray, who may be drawn in the same group as Leeds United. Two Leeds supporters were stabbed to death in Istanbul when the teams met in last season's Uefa Cup semi-finals.

The eight groups will comprise one team from each of the four pots, with clubs from the same country kept apart.

Pot One: Real Madrid, Juventus, Barcelona, Bayern Munich, Lazio, Man United, Monaco, Valencia.

Pot Two: Spartak Moscow, Paris St-Germain, Olympique Lyonnais, Milan, Deportivo la Coruna, Arsenal, PSV Eindhoven, Galatasaray.

Pot Three: Dynamo Kiev, Rosenborg Trondheim, Bayer Leverkusen, Olympiakos, Panathinaikos, Leeds United, Sparta Prague, Rangers.

Pot Four: Sporting Lisbon, Hamburg, Anderlecht, Besiktas, Sturm Graz, Heerenveen, Helsingborg, Shakhtar Donetsk.

fields.headline: Sunderland
fields.standfirst: Europe? Not yet. But there's no shame in that, writes Sean Ingle
fields.trailText: Europe? Not yet. But there's no shame in that, writes Sean Ingle.
fields.body:
As 2000 dawned, Sunderland were in sniffing distance of a Champions League place. Then injuries to key players and a mystifying post-millennium malaise struck the Stadium of Light. First Wimbledon beat them, then Tranmere, Arsenal and Leeds did the same. And so did Coventry and Leicester. When the dust had settled Sunderland had lost seven out of 11 games (the other four were drawn), but despite free-falling down the Premiership, Peter Reid's side dug in, recovered, and eventually finished a deserved seventh.

Last season's efforts - after many had tipped them to go down after their 4-0 opening day thumping at Chelsea - spoke volumes about the manager, the club and the players. Sunderland fans have every right to expect bigger and better things, but while the Black Cats are certainly going places, don't expect them to get there quite yet - a place in the top half beckons, but Europe is probably just out of their reach.

That said, a couple of astute pre-season signings have left Sunderland with a stronger squad than last year. Reid has moved smartly to sure up his defence, picking up the Fernando Couto lookalike Stanislav Varga, a 6ft 5ins Slovakian colossus for £800,000, and Julio Arca, the 19-year-old wonderboy from Argentinos Juniors for £3.5m.

The midfield also has a tougher, more reassuring feel to it. In the middle Hutchinson and (when he is finally fit) Schwartz will provide the just the right balance between tough tackles and exquisite passes, while last season's signing Kevin Kilbane will continue to dance, skip and cross his way into the Sunderland hearts.

And then there's the attack. Kevin Phillips could well be the best English striker in Premiership, despite what Kevin Keegan thinks. And he will be amply supported by the creaking and lumbering but highly effective frame of Niall Quinn. The only danger is that if one of them gets injured then Daniel Dichio will probably have to step in, and the Black Cats will be a lot less potent as a result.

But that lack of depth is Sunderland's only problem. They can scrap and snatch and snipe with the best of them, and they can play it around too. And with even more supporters in the Stadium of Light behind them, they will be a match for any team. But if injuries strike, like they did last year, then a Uefa place will be beyond them.

In Don Hutchison (Everton), Tom Peeters (Mechelen), Jurgen Macho (FC Vienna), Patrick Tano (Monaco), Julio Arca (Argentinos), Stanislav Varga (Bratislava), Allan Johnston (Rangers), Sam Aiston (Shrewsbury)

OutAllan Johnston (Rangers), Sam Aiston (Shrewsbury)

Odds 150-1

fields.headline: Keegan defends the Poll toll
fields.trailText: Kevin Keegan yesterday sympathised with Graham Poll, the referee who controversially sent off three players during Monday night's game between Arsenal and Liverpool, and described Andy Gray's after-match comments on Sky as "ridiculous".
fields.body:
Kevin Keegan yesterday sympathised with Graham Poll, the referee who controversially sent off three players during Monday night's game between Arsenal and Liverpool, and described Andy Gray's after-match comments on Sky as "ridiculous".

"I don't think Poll had a great game," he said, "but Andy Gray can call on 12 cameras and slow-motion replays to prove whether or not a tackle took the ball."

Keegan said he could not recall seeing football played at such a pace as it was at Highbury. "In difficult circumstances Graham Poll made what he thought were the right decisions," he added. "Nowadays there are no grey areas. It's got to be black or white."

After studying the video replays Poll has since rescinded the second booking, which led to Liverpool's Dietmar Hamann getting the third red card of the evening. But he has confirmed his decisions to send off Gary McAllister and Arsenal's Patrick Vieira, another second yellow, for two-footed tackles.

The Football Association is under pressure to calm things down with eight dismissals in the first five days of the new Premiership programme and the Arsenal manager Arsène Wenger charged with misconduct for an alleged incident with the fourth official at Sunderland on Saturday, when Vieira was sent off for flailing an arm at Darren Williams.

Lancaster Gate, however, is unlikely to be panicked into premature action, taking the view that these are early days and the sendings-off probably will not continue at their present rate. If they do, however, Phil Don, the Premier League official responsible for referees, may well be advised by the FA to issue instructions for greater leniency.

The rash of red cards is a result of the annual pre-season get-together of representatives of referees, managers and players, who this time agreed that fresh efforts should be made to outlaw two-footed tackles and flying elbows.

The Premier League asked referees to operate as they did in the second half of last season, when fewer yellow cards were shown as officials used more discretion. The apparent contradiction between this and what has actually happened has yet to be resolved.

Lancaster Gate, however, is unlikely to be panicked into premature action, taking the view that these are early days and the sendings-off probably will not continue at their present rate. If they do, however, Phil Don, the Premier League official responsible for referees, may well be advised by the FA to issue instructions for greater leniency. The rash of red cards is a result of the annual pre-season get-together of representatives of referees, managers and players, who this time agreed that fresh efforts should be made to outlaw two-footed tackles and flying elbows. The Premier League asked referees to operate as they did in the second half of last season, when fewer yellow cards were shown as officials used more discretion. The apparent contradiction between this and what has actually happened has yet to be resolved.

fields.headline: Burchill's hurricane hat-trick
fields.standfirst:
Burchill 12, 14, 15, Berkovic 22 46, Riseth 52, Petrov 71
Celtic win 11-0 on aggregate
fields.trailText: Mark Burchill scored one of the quickest hat-tricks in British football as Celtic recorded a thumping 11-0 aggregate win.
fields.body:
Coasting in football does not come easier than this. Celtic won this affair with a thumping aggregate score and via some abrupt shrapnel from Mark Burchill, who surely scored one of the quickest hat-tricks in British football.

It has been a misleading week for the Old Firm. Rangers on Wednesday dusted off the challenge of Herfolge in the Champions League and Celtic treated poor Jeunesse from Luxembourg with all the respect of a tossed salad in this Uefa Cup qualifying tie.

To add to their 4-0 lead from the first leg Celtic, who have confirmed the appointment of John Robertson as assistant manager, had already grabbed four by the 20th minute here, though the tedium of watching this match was at least relieved by a couple of maverick elements. Starting only his second competitive match for the club since arriving for £5m from Brazil last season was Rafael. Martin O'Neill has been reluctant to deploy this expensive mistake thus far, and last night we had a hunch as to why.

Rafael is a remnant from the derided John Barnes era at Celtic, as is Bobby Petta who is in danger these days of becoming a darling among the Celtic faithful. Petta drew more cheers for his slaloming runs last night, but it isn't mere fluke that his one truly mesmerising performance came in the first leg against Jeunesse.

One player who is talented, and currently demanding a transfer from Celtic, is Burchill, whose quickfire hat-trick was reminiscent of the mayhem of Jimmy McGrory in the late 1940s. Between the 12th and 15th minutes Burchill sent a bullet header and a couple of swift prods past John van Rijswick, the Jeunesse goalkeeper who must have felt victimised. Even before the first half was out, Celtic had a fourth through Eyal Berkovic.

The rout was completed through a further goal from Berkovic as well as strikes by Vidar Riseth and Stillian Petrov in the second half.

 With Bohemians of Dublin holding Aberdeen to a single goal, Hearts were the only other Scottish or Welsh survivors, defeating IBV Vestmannyjar of Iceland 5-0 on aggregate thanks to strikes by Gary McSwegan, Robert Tomaschek and Kris O'Neil.

Celtic (3-5-2): Gould; Tebily, Riseth, Scheidt; Healy, Lambert (Miller, h-t), Mjallby, Berkovic, Petta; Burchill (Boyd, h-t), Lynch (Petrov, 61).

Jeunesse Esch (4-4-2): Van Rijswick; Schaack, Wagner, Schauls, Lamborelle; Sabotic, Borbiconi, Meylender, Kurtz (Neis, 65); Betis, Anodio.

Referee: P Leuba (Switz).

fields.headline: Arsenal finally capture Wiltord
fields.trailText: Arsenal have provisionally agreed terms for the purchase of Bordeaux striker Sylvain Wiltord.
fields.body:
Arsène Wenger put his personal problems behind him yesterday to finally capture the striker he has been chasing all summer.

"Terms have provisionally been agreed with Bordeaux for the signature of Sylvain Wiltord," announced Arsenal, though it is unlikely that the deal will be tied up in time for the French international, who is in London, to play in tomorrow's home game against Charlton.

However, the fact that Wenger has finally agreed terms with Bordeaux for the 26-year-old will be a relief to the Arsenal manager, who has been trying to bring his strike force back up to four after the release of Davor Suker in the summer.

Bordeaux and Arsenal had been unable to agree a fee for Wiltord, with the French club holding out for £15m while, during weeks of haggling, Arsenal's vice-chairman David Dein offered much less.

Arsenal are not revealing the price they have paid but it is expected to be around £12.5m. That is some £4m more than Arsenal's initial valuation of the striker whose injury-time equaliser against Italy set up France's golden-goal win in the Euro 2000 final.

But it is a compromise born of necessity on both sides. Arsenal desperately needed to sign a striker before the August 31 deadline to be eligible for the Champions League.

Not only may Dennis Bergkamp miss Champions League games because of his refusal to fly but Wenger also needs to budget for the likely loss of Nwankwo Kanu, who was yesterday named in Nigeria's Olympic squad. Arsenal have lodged an official appeal with Fifa and the Football Association to prevent him going but, if they lose, Kanu will miss five Premiership games and three Champions League games, possibly leaving Thierry Henry as Wenger's only available striker.

Bordeaux were holding out for a high fee for Wiltord because 40% of it will go to Deportivo La Coruna under the deal that saw the player move from the Spanish club at the start of last season. But Wiltord has been refusing to train with Bordeaux after falling out with the coach and has threatened to take the club to court to gain his release.

Although he has yet to agree personal terms with Arsenal and must also still pass a medical, his agent Giselaine Dugueteroux said: "Sylvain likes England and he wants to play in the Champions League. Arsenal are a great club."

The pacy Wiltord, who two years ago was top scorer in the French league with 22 goals, is Wenger's third big-money summer signing after the £7m midfielder Lauren and the winger Robert Pires, who arrived for £5m. The Arsenal manager is still looking for another midfielder.

Meanwhile Middlesbrough's Cameroon striker Joseph-Désiré Job has turned down the chance of playing in the Olympics to concentrate on his Premiership career.

Tottenham's Norwegian international striker Steffen Iversen has signed a new contract which is expected to double his wages and commit the 23-year-old to Spurs until 2006.
