webTitle: Time for referees to bring in the three-card trick

fields.headline: Time for referees to bring in the three-card trick
fields.trailText: Excessive red cards rob the paying public, may have a bearing on the championship and needs to be sorted out now.
fields.body:
The number of unnecessary red cards shown since the start of the Premiership season has really disappointed me. It robs the paying public, may have a bearing on the championship and needs to be sorted out now. To my mind a new three-card system would be a good start.

The idea is straightforward. A red-card offence would remain an automatic dismissal but the bookings law would be more flexible. A player cautioned twice would not be sent off but instead would serve an automatic one-match ban. Only after three yellow cards would the red follow.

That gives players breathing space, means the fans are not cheated out of seeing 11 v 11 so often and yet at the same time ensures offenders do not get off scot-free. Crucially, it also gives managers a chance to reassess.

Once a player reaches two bookings the manager could either haul him off, if he has not used his substitutes, or run the risk of a third card. At the moment players can end up on sudden death after they mistime a sliding tackle in the wet in the first minute.

Unfortunately, I don't imagine the Football Association will adopt that idea this season. In fact, I'll plait sawdust if it does. But there could and should be a meeting involving representatives of referees, managers, players and the FA to discuss what is going on. Why not televise it and get everything out in the open? Let's make sure everyone is clear about what is allowed and what is not.

I must stress at this point that referees are right an awful lot more often than the players are. But mistakes happen, as Graham Poll was honest enough to admit over his sending-off of Dietmar Hamann at Highbury, and I would favour a panel to assess some decisions.

I had first-hand experience of that in Spain when I was in charge of Atletico Madrid, and particularly remember one case after a game against Real Madrid. Their keeper made some dreadful challenges in one-on-ones, reminiscent of Harald Schumacher's on Patrick Battiston in the 1982 World Cup, but was only booked, whereas we had two sent off. After the committee had examined what went on, my players escaped a suspension and Real's keeper got a nine-match ban.

If I was on a panel I would certainly have called for several of this season's red cards to be overturned. Roy Keane's dismissal in the Charity Shield was spot on - we want those tackles out of the game - but everyone could have stayed on at Arsenal on Monday and Patrick Vieira should not have been sent off at Sunderland.

In that incident Vieira was being tugged back and was just trying to shake Darren Williams off; he wasn't trying to knock his head off. Referees need to take into account more that it's a game of dispute and competition. They also need to use greater man-management. Perhaps they could sit down with senior pros or players who have just retired and go through videos, examining what is dangerous and what is not.

There is definitely a case for former players being fast-tracked into refereeing, and of all the incidents this week I was particularly fascinated to see Arsène Wenger charged by the FA with "threatening behaviour and physical intimidation" at Sunderland. Let's be honest, he's the last person you would have in that category.

I've seen referees fronted up in tunnels and remarks thrown for them to hear. There have also been isolated incidents such as Ian Wright bursting into the referee's room. But the relationship between refs and the players and managers has clearly deteriorated and cannot afford a greater split without real resentment festering.

Referees are more and more becoming personalities and the old camaraderie and respect have been replaced by a feeling of "them and us".

As a manager I invited referees for a drink after the game. I had Keith Cooper singing in my office after one match, but he gave a penalty against us in the first minute the next time we met so he clearly wasn't doing us any favours. Somehow I can't imagine referees serenading any Premiership managers tomorrow.

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Performances in tour games can be deceptive but West Indies continue to give a good impression of a side in disarray. Following their two-day defeat in the fourth Test they are in some danger of succumbing to Somerset at Taunton.
fields.body:
Performances in tour games can be deceptive but West Indies continue to give a good impression of a side in disarray. Following their two-day defeat in the fourth Test they are in some danger of succumbing to Somerset at Taunton.

West Indies' top order crumbled again, this time on an excellent batting pitch. After Somerset had reached 488 in their first innings with the all-rounder Keith Parsons extending his career-best score to 193 not out, West Indies slipped to 141 for seven with the 20-year-old Joe Tucker dismissing Brian Lara with his second ball in first-class cricket. Lara hooked a delivery to Jamie Cox at fine leg.

They were rescued by the leg-spinner Mahendra Nagamootoo. Coming in at 82 for five, he ended the day three short of a century. His bowling, however, did little to convince the selectors that they should stray from the dogma of employing four fast bowlers in next week's final Test at the Oval. He took one for 126 from 41 overs.

Shane Warne took five for nine in 30 balls to give Hampshire the chance of an unlikely victory against Kent at Canterbury. He finished with six for 34 in Kent's second innings, his best figures for the county. It left Hampshire needing 314 to win.

The match is set for a tense conclusion. Hampshire, for whom victory is a necessity, require 63 more with four wickets remaining.

Two days before their fourth successive Lord's final, Gloucestershire showed they are at last coming to terms with the four-day game. Their seven-wicket victory over Middlesex on a pitch of variable bounce at Bristol was their third in a row, moving them off the bottom of the Second Division and into contention for promotion.

"We're starting to get a better understanding of four-day cricket," said John Bracewell, Gloucestershire's coach. "Promotion was our goal at the beginning of the year and it's still alive."

Chris Adams owed his side a favour after putting Glamorgan into bat at Colwyn Bay on Tuesday and he duly produced his best batting of the summer.

In response to the Welsh county's 718 for three declared, the Sussex captain made his first century of the season, 156, and shared a sixth-wicket stand of 232 with Umer Rashid, who recorded his maiden first-class century.

Adams, who was dropped at slip on 103, eventually fended a delivery from Alex Wharf to gully, sparking an excessive reaction from the bowler that could lead to him being reported to Lord's.

Adams's wicket was the first of five that went down for 24 runs. Sussex had to follow on 376 behind and Adams was soon back for more, reaching 68 not out in the second innings. Sussex enter the final day trailing by 208 with six wickets left.

webTitle: Top guns on target as Foxes stumble

fields.headline: Top guns on target as Foxes stumble
fields.standfirst:
Leicestershire 372 & 75-1
Lancashire 574-5 dec
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText:
Leicestershire 372 & 75-1
Lancashire 574-5 dec
fields.body:
The Leicestershire bowlers who laboured in vain here could be accused of many things, but certainly not inconsistency. Over the course of two days which might have been more pleasantly spent in Sing-Sing or Alcatraz, they did, after all, muster a wicket per session.

Trailing by 202, the hosts lost Darren Maddy, caught behind cutting at Chris Schofield, leaving Lancashire sniffing the 20-point win that will draw them level at the top of the table with Surrey, albeit having played a game more. That said, the pitch, which has not worn as anticipated, may be the ultimate victor.

Foxhunting is scarcely the world's most admirable sport, but don't tell Lancashire. Their affinity for the home attack is on a par with Benny Hill's fondness for double-entendres. Against the rest of the division their average total is 240; this resolutely sadistic effort followed the 488 that fuelled an innings win at Old Trafford. As an example of how to construct an innings, moreover, few this run-starved summer can have been quite so impressive, or so ruthless.

Not, in the circumstances, that we should have expected much less. Between them the visitors' five senior batting guns collectively boast nearly 500 international caps, yet this was the first time all summer they had simultaneously remembered the whereabouts of the trigger.

Each of the first six wickets yielded a liaison worth at least 59, Neil Fairbrother and Warren Hegg's 138 for the sixth pre-eminent. Whether coincidentally or not, the lead and the opposition casualty list rose together. At various times all three seamers - Phil DeFreitas (ankle), James Ormond (hamstring), Jon Dakin (achilles) - were hors de combat; hence, presumably, Ben Smith's decision to stick with the same ball for 177 overs. Carl Crowe, a promising offie, had a more unusual alibi for missing yesterday's torment: sunstroke.

Not that DeFreitas could be faulted for effort. In residence at the Bennett End all morning, he mingled swing, cutters and off-breaks while conceding 28 runs in 17 overs, keeping Fairbrother and Sourav Ganguly on a tight leash after Dakin had finally ejected John Crawley via a slash to backward point.

DeFreitas delivered 30 overs in the day for 67, yet so clinical was the Red Rose mood that there was no champing at the bit. Never did the scoring rate reach 3 an over. Chinese water torture would have been more tolerable.

Ganguly missed his maiden championship century when, seduced perhaps by the off-spin Ormond had purveyed prior to the interval, he was trapped upon the resumption by something altogether sharper. That, though, merely ushered in Hegg, whose duet with Fairbrother, an even nimbler nudger and nurdler, must have felt a bit like being tickled to death by elves.

Chinks of daylight were fleeting. A sharper fielder than Aftab Habib might have run out both; Hegg had turned for the pavilion when Iain Sutcliffe spilled a sitter beneath the old scoreboard. When Fairbrother completed his second century of the season - both at the Foxes' expense - he showed no sign of pleasure. Compassion at last - or a proud Lancastrian focusing grimly on the holiest of grails?

webTitle: Cork revels in flair for the dramatic

fields.headline: Cork revels in flair for the dramatic
fields.standfirst:
Derbyshire 167 & 476-7 dec
Durham 144 & 257-6
County Championship First Division table
fields.trailText:
Derbyshire 167 & 476-7 dec
Durham 144 & 257-6
fields.body:
Whether in a breathless finish to a Lord's Test or a lazy day in the championship, Dominic Cork retains his sense of the dramatic. The Derbyshire captain, whose previous career best was a modest 104, converted his overnight 105 to a maiden double century in only 63 deliveries, immediately declared his team's second innings - and then took a wicket with the first ball of Durham's reply.

Jon Lewis was struck on the pad half-forward to a good-length delivery and it would have taken a brave umpire to turn down Cork's appeal.

Cork occupied the less familiar territory of the back seat after that, bowling only seven overs and watching from first slip as Derbyshire moved inexorably towards their second championship win of the season.

Durham needed 500 to win when Cork declared before lunch with a minimum of 177 overs remaining, but could not have asked for more friendly conditions than this: a blameless pitch and against a Derbyshire attack with a single, inexperienced spinner.

Despite the early loss of Lewis and Michael Gough, bowled by Paul Aldred's first ball of the match, the visitors reached 152 for two, with Simon Katich and Paul Collingwood scoring half-centuries. But Collingwood threw away the chance to make Luke Sutton, Derbyshire's wicketkeeping deputy for the injured Karl Krikken, pay fully for dropping him on 19, moving to 66 before driving the young left-arm spinner Liam Wharton to Tim Munton at mid-on.

And when Katich, a prim and proper left-hander from Western Australia who has now scored 936 championship runs at a healthy 40-plus average, cut the admirable Munton to Michael Di Venuto in the gully, it became a matter of when, rather than whether, Derbyshire would win.

They are still likely to be playing Durham in the Second Division next summer, however, with both counties remaining well adrift of Kent in the bottom three with only two games to play. The major effect of a win here would be to make Derbyshire rue even more the eight points they were docked for the substandard pitch on which they beat Surrey in June.

Their appeal was rejected last week and their chairman Trevor Bowring's last-gasp plea to Lord MacLaurin for a rethink, which he posted yesterday, seems unlikely to meet with much joy.

Cork and Mathew Dowman had taken less than four overs to collect the 16 runs they needed to set a record for Derbyshire's seventh wicket, extending their stand to 258 from 73 overs before Dowman became a third victim for Steve Harmison, chopping on a short ball, for 140.

Cork, though, knew he might never get a better chance to score a double century and savaged an increasingly dispirited Durham attack, plundering a total of 32 fours in addition to three sixes off the occasional off-spin of Gough, who is no John Emburey. It was the first double century against Durham in the championship since Brian Lara's 501 at Edgbaston in 1994. Cork will appreciate that stat, too.

 There are changes in the way bonus points are earned in the millennial revision of the County Championship.

As before, a win earns 12 points , a tie 6 , a normal draw 4 (see later *) and a defeat none, plus any bonus points accrued for batting and bowling in each first innings.

Bonus points are now reckoned on the score in the first 130 overs, not 120 overs as in recent seasons.

Batting: now 5 pts can be earned (4 last year)

200 -249 runs (1pt)

250-299 (2pts)

300-349 (3pts)

350-399 (4pts)

400 or over (5pts)

Bowling: now only 3 points available (4 last year)

Three-five wickets (1pt)

Six-eight wickets (2pts)

Nine-10 wickets (3pts)

The new ball can still be taken after 100 overs.

A no ball is worth two runs to the batting side; runs scored off a no ball count in addition to the two-run penalty.

A single-innings match may be played when bad weather prevents any start until less than eight hours remain. A win earns 12 points, a tie six and a draw three but there are no bonus points.

*In a draw where the scores finish level, the side batting in the fourth innings earn 6 points their opponents 4, plus bonus points.

webTitle: Security stepped up at murdered loyalist's funeral

fields.headline: Security stepped up at murdered loyalist's funeral
fields.trailText: A leading loyalist shot dead in Belfast was given a full paramilitary funeral amid tight security today.
fields.body:
A leading loyalist shot dead in Belfast was given a full paramilitary funeral amid tight security today.

Huge crowds turned out for the burial of Jackie Coulter, who was gunned down along with Bobby Mahood on Monday amid bitter loyalist feuding.

One of the chief mourners was John White, chairman of the Ulster Democratic Party, which represents the Ulster Freedom Fighters. He said he had appealed to the UFF to talk to its enemies but that his plea had, so far, fallen on deaf ears.

"I have been trying to encourage dialogue but I have been told there is no room for dialogue."

Mr White is a close associate of UFF boss, Johnny Adair, sent back to prison on Tuesday on the orders of Northern Ireland Secretary Peter Mandelson.

Police and troops lined the funeral route, blocking off side roads as the coffin with carried from his home in the Shankill Road area.

Mr Coulter's wife Agnes, son and three daughters walked behind the coffin. The cortege stopped briefly on the spot in the Crumlin Road where Mr Coulter and Mr Mahood were shot dead by a lone Ulster Volunteer Force gunman at the beginning of the week.

More than 1,000 men marched slowly behind the coffin and youths in white shirts and black ties carried floral tributes at the head of the procession. The coffin was then put into a hearse which drove down the Shankill Road and across the city to Roselawn Cemetery.

During the service a wreath from the Loyalist Volunteer Force was delivered by a group of men.

Marshals with black arm bands and walkie talkies controlled the crowd and kept cameramen well back.

Security around the Shankill will remain tight in the days ahead as security chiefs fear the continuation of the loyalist feud between the Ulster Defence Association , the UFF and Ulster Volunteer Force.

A man with links to the UVF - shot dead on Wednesday night in retaliation for the murder of Mr Coulter and Mr Mahood - will be buried tomorrow.

Security chiefs are concerned there could be yet more bloodletting following the funerals.

Meanwhile, six men arrested after a chase in the Shankill Road area during which six weapons were found today remained in police custody.

webTitle: Full text of Greg Dyke's speech

fields.headline: Full text of Greg Dyke's speech
fields.standfirst: BBC director-general's MacTaggart lecture at start of Guardian Edinburgh international television festival
fields.trailText: "Let me start by saying how pleased I was to be asked to deliver the MacTaggart lecture in this the 25th year of the Edinburgh International Television Festival.
fields.body:
"Let me start by saying how pleased I was to be asked to deliver the MacTaggart lecture in this the 25th year of the Edinburgh International Television Festival.

I wasn't here for the first few years but I have been coming on and off for most of the Festival's existence.

Three things have changed fundamentally since those early days. Firstly the size and professionalism of the festival has changed beyond recognition.

Secondly the price of hotels in Edinburgh for this particular weekend have gone through the roof.

Finally, and the biggest change of all, my friend Gus MacDonald has gone from being a radical programme maker with strong far left credentials to become Lord MacDonald of Tradeston.

Gus, 25 years ago the only thing less likely than me becoming Director-General of the BBC was you agreeing to become a member of the House of Lords.

Actually I'm the first ever Director-General never to have worked for the BBC before taking on the role. I only ever applied for two jobs at the BBC - the first in 1970 as a reporter on Radio Teeside, which I failed to get, and the second nearly 30 years later as Director-General.

I am also flattered to be the first person ever to deliver the MacTaggart lecture twice, although there is one big drawback to that. I used all my best jokes the first time. So forgive me if my lecture here tonight is unremittingly serious and I realise that as a result, some will think that I've gone completely native after less than a year at the BBC.

In 1994, my lecture was about broadcasting and politics. My concern then was that the relationship between Government and broadcasters was in danger of becoming unhealthy; that as the world of broadcasting was changing broadcasters were always wanting something from the Government and, as such, were less likely to be brave in their programming when standing up to the Government of the day.

I still have that concern - in fact the danger has grown. Broadcasters today want more from Government than we could possibly have imagined just six years ago. That is why the Government's decision to give the BBC a seven year licence fee agreement, right through to the end of the current BBC Charter, is important. It gives the BBC the freedom and independence to be brave.

However we all still need to be vigilant in the area of political independence and I am particularly concerned when I read of proposals for a single content regulator across the whole television industry.

I believe we have a far better chance of resisting political pressure if, between us, we have more than one content regulator. Pluralism in regulation is as important as pluralism among broadcasters.

But tonight I don't plan to talk about politics, I want to talk about change and why it is difficult to bring about in an organisation like the BBC.

The Council Chamber in Broadcasting House at the BBC is an austere place where the windows are set so high that no one can see in or out. If you believe that is symbolic, beware - our new boardroom has no windows at all.

As you go into the Council Chamber you will find something equally symbolic - the portraits of previous Directors-General hang on the walls around you to serve as a constant reminder of the BBC's heritage.

In the spot above the mantelpiece, pride of place rightly goes to the BBC's founder, John Reith. The second best spot, directly opposite him, is taken by Hugh Carleton Greene. These are seen by many as the two truly great Directors-General.

Now, the myth of the BBC is that there is a single flame, a single idea handed seamlessly from generation to generation. The flame is public service broadcasting and each generation understands its inheritance and fights not to change it but to defend it to the death. Having the previous Directors-General looking down upon you is no doubt intended to remind you that you tamper with it at your peril.

Echoes of the past

The truth, of course, is very different. John Reith - on your right as you walk into the Council Chamber - ended up disliking Greene, on the left, with an intense passion. Reith's view was that Greene had trivialised his great institution; that Greene had - dare I use the words - "dumbed down" the BBC. As Reith put it when talking about Greene, "I lead, he follows the crowd in all the disgusting manifestations of the age¿ Without any reservation he gives the public what it wants; I would not, did not and said I wouldn't. I am very annoyed that I even got on to terms with him".

In fact, many of the changes attributed to Greene had actually been started by his predecessor Sir Ian Jacob. Reith's views of Jacob were similar to his views of Greene. When he heard Jacob's portrait was going to be hung in the Council Chamber, Reith was so angry that he demanded that his own portrait be removed.

What had Jacob and Greene actually done to so upset the BBC's founder? The story is very illuminating.

Under Jacob, Greene had been Director of News and Current Affairs and had set about introducing radical change.

In the mid-fifties the great joke about BBC News was that every newsreel would begin, "The Queen Mother yesterday¿". I do, of course, realise that I am on dangerous ground when talking of the Queen Mother, but I'll take the risk.

Back to the joke. All newsreels started "The Queen Mother yesterday". The Queen Mother because everyone loved the Queen Mother; and yesterday because it took the BBC at least a day to check with the Queen Mother that she had done what she was said to have done, even though they had film of her doing it.

Greene set about changing the whole journalistic ethos of the BBC, transforming a largely obsequious and deferential institution into a gritty news organisation that could respond swiftly and imaginatively. At the heart of the changes were two extremely controversial views, though: firstly that television not newspapers would prove to be the bedrock of news reporting in the future; and secondly that news and current affairs had to be less isolated from the rest of the BBC.

ITV on the scene

It was out of these twin beliefs that truly ground-breaking genre-defying programmes like Cathy Come Home were later to spring.

After two years running News and Current Affairs, Greene became Director-General in 1960 at a time of real turmoil in the industry. Interestingly on becoming Director-General one of Greene's first actions was to move the nine o'clock news on the old Home Service, now Radio Four, to ten o'clock. You will not be surprised to know that the decision was ferociously attacked at the time.

By 1960 BBC Television was in real trouble. ITV had come into existence in 1954 and after a difficult start was making life very hard for the BBC. BBC Television's share had gone from 100% to 34% in only six years, and remember this was still only a two channel world.

With quiz programmes like Double Your Money, Take Your Pick and a raft of popular American series, ITV was stealing the hearts and minds of British viewers. Meanwhile BBC Television, obsessed with its own importance, was inward looking and hardly seemed to notice what was going on.

Jacob and Greene set about changing this. For the first time British audiences were to be offered a diet of programming that was both challenging and popular, programmes like Play for Today, Z Cars, The Forsyte Saga, That Was the Week That Was, Til Death Us Do Part, Doctor Who, Monty Python's Flying Circus and literally dozens of others.

It wasn't that Greene produced these programmes, of course he didn't. But he did make them possible. He gave BBC producers the ambition to make popular quality programming for the first time - programmes which both appealed to large audiences and made a difference to their lives. In rating terms, the BBC made a great recovery which left ITV with no option but to follow the BBC's lead, effectively making Greene the founder of modern day British television.

Radio reforms

And it didn't end with television either. When Radio Caroline and other pirate stations started broadcasting under a Panamanian flag of convenience in 1964 he not only argued that they should be closed down, but along with Frank Gillard, his legendary head of radio, he put in place the now familiar pattern of Radios 1, 2, 3 and 4. Imagine the fuss that caused.

Greene and Gillard's reforms of radio and television brought cries of derision. A Times leader accused the BBC of "abandoning their role as the sponsors and protectors of quality broadcasting".

Even the now seemingly innocuous Z Cars received its fair share of condemnation. The Chief Constable of Lancashire, Colonel Eric St Johnstone, demanded that it be cancelled. His force, to a man, he complained, were full of disgust.

Mary Whitehouse complained about the spate of modern plays on the BBC: "We are told that the dramatists are portraying real life, but why concentrate on the kitchen sink when there are so many pleasant sitting rooms?" No wonder she said of Greene: "If you were to ask me who, above all, was responsible for the moral collapse which characterised the Sixties and Seventies, I would unhesitatingly name Sir Hugh Carleton Greene."

Outrage from journalists, politicians, the great and the good and even some of the BBC's own staff at any mooted change in BBC radio or television is a pattern you can find throughout the history of the BBC.

Just look at the last decade - changes within all of our memories. Remember the fuss and outrage when Matthew Bannister re-shaped and effectively re-invented Radio 1 in the mid Nineties? Yet Radio 1 is now seen as one of the great success stories of the BBC.

Remember the fuss when the BBC created Radio Five Live with the idea of starting a radio station aimed at a younger audience and based around news and sport? Today Five Live is supreme in its field and its audience is still growing rapidly year by year.

Remember when John Birt set up BBC Online? He was widely accused of wasting licence payers' money and yet now it is the most visited content site in Europe and widely loved by some of the very people who accused him of wasting money at the time.

Populism

Long before any of these recent examples, a few of you may remember Grace Archer's death in the Archers - which just happened to coincide with the opening night of ITV. It was greeted by Denis Pitts in the Daily Herald with the following denunciation: "The BBC went too far on Thursday when, for the sake of a stunt, they killed off Grace Archer. The stunt was mean, callous and cold-blooded. I accuse the BBC of a shabby trick which has left an unpleasant taste in nine million mouths. I am angry. So is my wife."

You have to wonder what his wife would have thought about EastEnders.

In the sixties the opponents of change and in particular Greene's style of populism were everywhere. We now see Steptoe and Son as the great turning point in British situation comedy, a seminal series which helped pave the way for Dad's Army, 'Til Death Us Do Part, Fawlty Towers, Only Fools and Horses and many others. But it wasn't always perceived as that.

Wilfrid Brambell - the Shakespearean actor who played Steptoe senior said at the time: "I suppose every actor has to get into dustbin drama sooner or later".

One wonders if anyone today would ever have heard of Brambell if he hadn't got into "dustbin drama" - I rather doubt it.

None of this is new. As the BBC's Chief Archivist described it to me, "The BBC has been accused of dumbing down from the day Reith invented it." Propose any significant change and the BBC is accused of betraying its heritage.

The point is that the real genius of the BBC is that it has adapted and changed over the years. Successive generations of leaders have not simply taken the flame of public service broadcasting as a whole and passed it on unchanged. At crucial times in the BBC's history they have recognised that change was essential and have taken the bold decision to introduce it despite loud protests from all around them.

By and large history has rewarded their courage and their detractors have been forgotten. No Director-General was more criticised than Greene and yet today his memory is revered - without Greene there would not be the BBC as we know it. Reith invented the BBC for one age. Greene re-invented it for another.

John Birt

Of course it's pretty obvious why there are so many howls when anyone wants to change even comparatively small parts of the BBC.

It was Machiavelli, when writing The Prince, who summed it up when he wrote: "There is nothing more difficult to plan, more doubtful of success, nor more dangerous to manage than the creation of a new system.

"For the initiator has the enmity of all who would profit by the preservation of the old institutions and merely lukewarm defenders in those who would gain by the new."

Oddly when I looked up that quote in my files written on the same sheet was one which is less philosophical but equally applicable. It was from the former French President General De Gaulle who said, "Never stand between the dog and the lamp post."

So given this history, why try to change the BBC?

Look at the venom directed at John Birt - the man who had the courage to start the modernisation process at the BBC.

Why be radical in an age when attacks from sections of the press are more vicious and more personal than ever before; when the BBC's commercial competitors are more ruthless than they have ever been; and when some politicians and commentators seem more interested in quick headlines than in trying to understand the real issues?

The answer, of course, is we have no option. I believe the stark choice facing the BBC today is that we either change or we simply manage decline gracefully and none of us joined the BBC to do that.

Digital TV

The changes happening in technology; in the wider society; and in our competitive environment are what make this one of those times in history when change at the BBC is essential.

Let's take technology first. Digital television, and with it as many as 160 channels in digital satellite homes, has arrived at a pace faster than any could have imagined, certainly faster than I anticipated when I gave this lecture six years ago.

But we are only just beginning to see what digital television can really bring. Electronic programme guides are already changing viewing habits in digital homes dramatically, but the real revolution will come with the arrival of the TiVo box and similar in-home, hard disc recording technologies which will give the consumer complete freedom to watch what they want, when they want it.

I still believe there will be a role for conventional channels by the end of this decade - at times people will still want informed selection - but the channels are likely to be more focused, and aimed either at particular audience groups or based on particular programme genres.

Changing society

Secondly society is changing. Huge gulfs have opened up in the attitudes and values of different generations in a way not seen before.

In recent research people from different age groups were asked if they agreed or disagreed with the following statement, "There is too much sex, bad language and violence on TV and in cinema today." Amongst the over 45's 72% said they agreed. Amongst the 25 to 34 year olds 79% disagreed.

This dramatic polarisation of views creates real challenges for programme makers, broadcasters and regulators alike, particularly in the areas of taste and decency.

The people brought up in the Thatcher age are the biggest challenge of all whether you're a politician, the Chief Executive of Marks and Spencer or a television executive.

For these are the children of the multichannel age, they are used to choice and love it - whether it's shopping, music or television and they are certainly not deferential to Britain's traditional institutions like the BBC.

This generation doesn't complain if they don't like our schedules they simply turn over. "Disgusted of Tunbridge Wells" is disappearing and being replaced by "Not bothered of Newcastle".

And as the retiring speaker of the House of Commons reminded us recently this is also a generation with very little interest in conventional politics.

However what we know is that they are passionate about many of the important issues of our times, they just don't think Westminster politics can provide the answers.

Competition

I believe this will become an increasingly serious problem for broadcasters and programme-makers steeped in a tradition of reporting conventional politics.

If the BBC is to stay relevant over this decade we have to understand this generation and meet their needs, not only because they matter, but because we are all being influenced by them. In the old days kids wanted to be like their parents. These days parents, terrified of growing old, want to be more like their kids.

As Bob Dylan wrote "I was so much older then I'm younger than that now."

The third reason the BBC has to change is that the BBC's competitive environment has changed and will be transformed beyond recognition in the next decade. Consolidation and merger are the order of the day amongst media companies.

Our competitors today are bigger, richer and more ruthless than at any time in the BBC's history. They are increasingly part of a global media industry which has access to vast capital funds. This is competition on a scale the BBC has never seen before.

It's this combination of factors which mean that this is one of those periods when the BBC, and BBC Television in particular, has to go through fundamental change. In the words of Margaret Thatcher, "there is no alternative".

Inside the BBC we have been discussing the changes we need to make to our television channels since I first took over, as no doubt many of you have read in Broadcast and elsewhere.

One thing I have discovered in that time is that there is no such thing as a confidential debate in the BBC, but if a few headlines are the price you pay for an open and questioning environment it is a price worth paying.

At the BBC we all recognise that changing anything is difficult to achieve without controversy. But no-one feels this more keenly than our new Director of Television Mark Thompson who went to make the keynote speech at the Banff festival in Canada a couple of months ago.

Mark took the opportunity to outline some ideas about the future of our television services in an intelligent and thought provoking speech. He opened the debate.

Within days the forces of darkness came down upon him. He was accused of being a philistine with plans to turn BBC One into an all entertainment channel, which he didn't say and is not true, and relegating all serious programming to the fringes, again which he didn't say and is not true.

It was all familiar stuff. Predictably the retired old men of the BBC came out in force to defend yesterday as they always have done and always will. Had they read the speech? I doubt it. Did they understand the arguments? Unlikely. They just want television the way it was in their day. But that simply isn't an option.

New plans

So what are the changes we plan to make?

Well one of the dangers of making this speech here today is, as our Head of Press said to me, I'm bound to disappoint. He told me "people are expecting you to be Moses coming down from the mountain with tablets of stone".

Of course Moses had it easy - he only had to carry the stone, someone else had already worked out the messages.

Let me make it clear, I haven't come here today with all the answers, there are no new Ten Commandments.

What we do have are some exciting ideas for the future of BBC Television in the first decade of a new century which also happens to be the first decade of the digital age. Like all ideas some will succeed and others won't but that doesn't matter, this is only the start of a journey, the process of change is ongoing.

Let me explain our plans in three parts.

First of all I want to talk about money and what the BBC can and cannot afford to do.

Secondly I'd like to talk about our proposals for a portfolio of BBC public service channels, which will eventually be available in every home in Britain.

And finally I want to talk about the purpose of the BBC and public service broadcasting in the digital age.

Money matters

Starting with the money then. One thing I have learned in my years in the television industry is that money matters when you're trying to make outstanding programmes. It's not enough on its own - at some time or other most of us have spent a lot of money producing a very average programme - but trying to make fantastic programmes without the right budget is incredibly difficult.

In fact I believe one of the problems of BBC Television today is that too many of our services have been under funded.

BBC One certainly needs more money, particularly for drama and quality entertainment and two of our digital services, BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge, were started without enough money to commission truly original and inspiring programmes, programming of the quality people expect from the BBC.

If we want to spend more money on our traditional services, and we do need to, there are certain consequences. Firstly we have to find the money and secondly we have to limit our plans for new services to what we can afford.

This year's licence fee settlement, which gave us an increase of inflation plus 1.5% every year for seven years was a fair, even generous, award. By 2007 this will produce a real increase

The Queen Mother because everyone loved the Queen Mother; and yesterday because it took the BBC at least a day to check with the Queen Mother that she had done what she was said to have done, even though they had film of her doing it. Greene set about changing the whole journalistic ethos of the BBC, transforming a largely obsequious and deferential institution into a gritty news organisation that could respond swiftly and imaginatively. At the heart of the changes were two extremely controversial views, though: firstly that television not newspapers would prove to be the bedrock of news reporting in the future; and secondly that news and current affairs had to be less isolated from the rest of the BBC. ITV on the scene It was out of these twin beliefs that truly ground-breaking genre-defying programmes like Cathy Come Home were later to spring. After two years running News and Current Affairs, Greene became Director-General in 1960 at a time of real turmoil in the industry. Interestingly on becoming Director-General one of Greene's first actions was to move the nine o'clock news on the old Home Service, now Radio Four, to ten o'clock. You will not be surprised to know that the decision was ferociously attacked at the time. By 1960 BBC Television was in real trouble. ITV had come into existence in 1954 and after a difficult start was making life very hard for the BBC. BBC Television's share had gone from 100% to 34% in only six years, and remember this was still only a two channel world. With quiz programmes like Double Your Money, Take Your Pick and a raft of popular American series, ITV was stealing the hearts and minds of British viewers. Meanwhile BBC Television, obsessed with its own importance, was inward looking and hardly seemed to notice what was going on. Jacob and Greene set about changing this. For the first time British audiences were to be offered a diet of programming that was both challenging and popular, programmes like Play for Today, Z Cars, The Forsyte Saga, That Was the Week That Was, Til Death Us Do Part, Doctor Who, Monty Python's Flying Circus and literally dozens of others. It wasn't that Greene produced these programmes, of course he didn't. But he did make them possible. He gave BBC producers the ambition to make popular quality programming for the first time - programmes which both appealed to large audiences and made a difference to their lives. In rating terms, the BBC made a great recovery which left ITV with no option but to follow the BBC's lead, effectively making Greene the founder of modern day British television. Radio reforms And it didn't end with television either. When Radio Caroline and other pirate stations started broadcasting under a Panamanian flag of convenience in 1964 he not only argued that they should be closed down, but along with Frank Gillard, his legendary head of radio, he put in place the now familiar pattern of Radios 1, 2, 3 and 4. Imagine the fuss that caused. Greene and Gillard's reforms of radio and television brought cries of derision. A Times leader accused the BBC of "abandoning their role as the sponsors and protectors of quality broadcasting". Even the now seemingly innocuous Z Cars received its fair share of condemnation. The Chief Constable of Lancashire, Colonel Eric St Johnstone, demanded that it be cancelled. His force, to a man, he complained, were full of disgust. Mary Whitehouse complained about the spate of modern plays on the BBC: "We are told that the dramatists are portraying real life, but why concentrate on the kitchen sink when there are so many pleasant sitting rooms?" No wonder she said of Greene: "If you were to ask me who, above all, was responsible for the moral collapse which characterised the Sixties and Seventies, I would unhesitatingly name Sir Hugh Carleton Greene." Outrage from journalists, politicians, the great and the good and even some of the BBC's own staff at any mooted change in BBC radio or television is a pattern you can find throughout the history of the BBC. Just look at the last decade - changes within all of our memories. Remember the fuss and outrage when Matthew Bannister re-shaped and effectively re-invented Radio 1 in the mid Nineties? Yet Radio 1 is now seen as one of the great success stories of the BBC. Remember the fuss when the BBC created Radio Five Live with the idea of starting a radio station aimed at a younger audience and based around news and sport? Today Five Live is supreme in its field and its audience is still growing rapidly year by year. Remember when John Birt set up BBC Online? He was widely accused of wasting licence payers' money and yet now it is the most visited content site in Europe and widely loved by some of the very people who accused him of wasting money at the time. Populism Long before any of these recent examples, a few of you may remember Grace Archer's death in the Archers - which just happened to coincide with the opening night of ITV. It was greeted by Denis Pitts in the Daily Herald with the following denunciation: "The BBC went too far on Thursday when, for the sake of a stunt, they killed off Grace Archer. The stunt was mean, callous and cold-blooded. I accuse the BBC of a shabby trick which has left an unpleasant taste in nine million mouths. I am angry. So is my wife." You have to wonder what his wife would have thought about EastEnders. In the sixties the opponents of change and in particular Greene's style of populism were everywhere. We now see Steptoe and Son as the great turning point in British situation comedy, a seminal series which helped pave the way for Dad's Army, 'Til Death Us Do Part, Fawlty Towers, Only Fools and Horses and many others. But it wasn't always perceived as that. Wilfrid Brambell - the Shakespearean actor who played Steptoe senior said at the time: "I suppose every actor has to get into dustbin drama sooner or later". One wonders if anyone today would ever have heard of Brambell if he hadn't got into "dustbin drama" - I rather doubt it. None of this is new. As the BBC's Chief Archivist described it to me, "The BBC has been accused of dumbing down from the day Reith invented it." Propose any significant change and the BBC is accused of betraying its heritage. The point is that the real genius of the BBC is that it has adapted and changed over the years. Successive generations of leaders have not simply taken the flame of public service broadcasting as a whole and passed it on unchanged. At crucial times in the BBC's history they have recognised that change was essential and have taken the bold decision to introduce it despite loud protests from all around them. By and large history has rewarded their courage and their detractors have been forgotten. No Director-General was more criticised than Greene and yet today his memory is revered - without Greene there would not be the BBC as we know it. Reith invented the BBC for one age. Greene re-invented it for another. John Birt Of course it's pretty obvious why there are so many howls when anyone wants to change even comparatively small parts of the BBC. It was Machiavelli, when writing The Prince, who summed it up when he wrote: "There is nothing more difficult to plan, more doubtful of success, nor more dangerous to manage than the creation of a new system. "For the initiator has the enmity of all who would profit by the preservation of the old institutions and merely lukewarm defenders in those who would gain by the new." Oddly when I looked up that quote in my files written on the same sheet was one which is less philosophical but equally applicable. It was from the former French President General De Gaulle who said, "Never stand between the dog and the lamp post." So given this history, why try to change the BBC? Look at the venom directed at John Birt - the man who had the courage to start the modernisation process at the BBC. Why be radical in an age when attacks from sections of the press are more vicious and more personal than ever before; when the BBC's commercial competitors are more ruthless than they have ever been; and when some politicians and commentators seem more interested in quick headlines than in trying to understand the real issues? The answer, of course, is we have no option. I believe the stark choice facing the BBC today is that we either change or we simply manage decline gracefully and none of us joined the BBC to do that. Digital TV The changes happening in technology; in the wider society; and in our competitive environment are what make this one of those times in history when change at the BBC is essential. Let's take technology first. Digital television, and with it as many as 160 channels in digital satellite homes, has arrived at a pace faster than any could have imagined, certainly faster than I anticipated when I gave this lecture six years ago. But we are only just beginning to see what digital television can really bring. Electronic programme guides are already changing viewing habits in digital homes dramatically, but the real revolution will come with the arrival of the TiVo box and similar in-home, hard disc recording technologies which will give the consumer complete freedom to watch what they want, when they want it. I still believe there will be a role for conventional channels by the end of this decade - at times people will still want informed selection - but the channels are likely to be more focused, and aimed either at particular audience groups or based on particular programme genres. Changing society Secondly society is changing. Huge gulfs have opened up in the attitudes and values of different generations in a way not seen before. In recent research people from different age groups were asked if they agreed or disagreed with the following statement, "There is too much sex, bad language and violence on TV and in cinema today." Amongst the over 45's 72% said they agreed. Amongst the 25 to 34 year olds 79% disagreed. This dramatic polarisation of views creates real challenges for programme makers, broadcasters and regulators alike, particularly in the areas of taste and decency. The people brought up in the Thatcher age are the biggest challenge of all whether you're a politician, the Chief Executive of Marks and Spencer or a television executive. For these are the children of the multichannel age, they are used to choice and love it - whether it's shopping, music or television and they are certainly not deferential to Britain's traditional institutions like the BBC. This generation doesn't complain if they don't like our schedules they simply turn over. "Disgusted of Tunbridge Wells" is disappearing and being replaced by "Not bothered of Newcastle". And as the retiring speaker of the House of Commons reminded us recently this is also a generation with very little interest in conventional politics. However what we know is that they are passionate about many of the important issues of our times, they just don't think Westminster politics can provide the answers. Competition I believe this will become an increasingly serious problem for broadcasters and programme-makers steeped in a tradition of reporting conventional politics. If the BBC is to stay relevant over this decade we have to understand this generation and meet their needs, not only because they matter, but because we are all being influenced by them. In the old days kids wanted to be like their parents. These days parents, terrified of growing old, want to be more like their kids. As Bob Dylan wrote "I was so much older then I'm younger than that now." The third reason the BBC has to change is that the BBC's competitive environment has changed and will be transformed beyond recognition in the next decade. Consolidation and merger are the order of the day amongst media companies. Our competitors today are bigger, richer and more ruthless than at any time in the BBC's history. They are increasingly part of a global media industry which has access to vast capital funds. This is competition on a scale the BBC has never seen before. It's this combination of factors which mean that this is one of those periods when the BBC, and BBC Television in particular, has to go through fundamental change. In the words of Margaret Thatcher, "there is no alternative". Inside the BBC we have been discussing the changes we need to make to our television channels since I first took over, as no doubt many of you have read in Broadcast and elsewhere. One thing I have discovered in that time is that there is no such thing as a confidential debate in the BBC, but if a few headlines are the price you pay for an open and questioning environment it is a price worth paying. At the BBC we all recognise that changing anything is difficult to achieve without controversy. But no-one feels this more keenly than our new Director of Television Mark Thompson who went to make the keynote speech at the Banff festival in Canada a couple of months ago. Mark took the opportunity to outline some ideas about the future of our television services in an intelligent and thought provoking speech. He opened the debate. Within days the forces of darkness came down upon him. He was accused of being a philistine with plans to turn BBC One into an all entertainment channel, which he didn't say and is not true, and relegating all serious programming to the fringes, again which he didn't say and is not true. It was all familiar stuff. Predictably the retired old men of the BBC came out in force to defend yesterday as they always have done and always will. Had they read the speech? I doubt it. Did they understand the arguments? Unlikely. They just want television the way it was in their day. But that simply isn't an option. New plans So what are the changes we plan to make? Well one of the dangers of making this speech here today is, as our Head of Press said to me, I'm bound to disappoint. He told me "people are expecting you to be Moses coming down from the mountain with tablets of stone". Of course Moses had it easy - he only had to carry the stone, someone else had already worked out the messages. Let me make it clear, I haven't come here today with all the answers, there are no new Ten Commandments. What we do have are some exciting ideas for the future of BBC Television in the first decade of a new century which also happens to be the first decade of the digital age. Like all ideas some will succeed and others won't but that doesn't matter, this is only the start of a journey, the process of change is ongoing. Let me explain our plans in three parts. First of all I want to talk about money and what the BBC can and cannot afford to do. Secondly I'd like to talk about our proposals for a portfolio of BBC public service channels, which will eventually be available in every home in Britain. And finally I want to talk about the purpose of the BBC and public service broadcasting in the digital age. Money matters Starting with the money then. One thing I have learned in my years in the television industry is that money matters when you're trying to make outstanding programmes. It's not enough on its own - at some time or other most of us have spent a lot of money producing a very average programme - but trying to make fantastic programmes without the right budget is incredibly difficult. In fact I believe one of the problems of BBC Television today is that too many of our services have been under funded. BBC One certainly needs more money, particularly for drama and quality entertainment and two of our digital services, BBC Choice and BBC Knowledge, were started without enough money to commission truly original and inspiring programmes, programming of the quality people expect from the BBC. If we want to spend more money on our traditional services, and we do need to, there are certain consequences. Firstly we have to find the money and secondly we have to limit our plans for new services to what we can afford. This year's licence fee settlement, which gave us an increase of inflation plus 1.5% every year for seven years was a fair, even generous, award. By 2007 this will produce a real increase

webTitle: You Bet Your Life: week two

fields.headline: You Bet Your Life: week two
fields.trailText: It's the second week of our betting game, in association with Blue Square. Our regular pundits are joined by our first guest gambler - let's wish him luck...
fields.byline: Paul MacInnes, Andy Knott, Scott Murray and Sean Ingle
fields.body:
It's the second week of our betting game, in association with Blue Square. Our regular pundits are joined by our first guest gambler - let's wish him luck...

The standings

Paul MacInnes £111.12
The Football Unlimited readers collective £100
Scott Murray £94.87
Sean Ingle £92.82

Paul MacInnes

Treble: Arsenal to beat Charlton 2/7, Newcastle to draw with Tottenham 9/4 and Wimbledon to draw with Watford 11/5. (£6)

Ok, so I'm getting a little cocky. After all, I won very little money on last week's bet (0 or 1 goals between Leicester and Aston Villa). But with Sean and Scott likely to reveal their true punting colours at some point, I'm going to enjoy my day in the sun with an extravagant (by my standards) treble.

Arsenal beating Charlton speaks for itself. I think the game will be tight, Charlton got a point the last time they played at Highbury, but I think the Gunners will avoid the profligacy that hurt them last weekend and score at least one.

There doesn't appear to be much value (see gambling keywords volume 1) in betting on the Premiership, but 9/4 for the draw at St James' Park doesn't look that bad. Newcastle played some great attacking football against Derby on Wednesday night, but they were also shocking at the back. Tottenham are not quite the opposite but I think their forward line will need a few more games before it becomes as reliable as the defence. So, all in all, a scoring draw.

Finally, I've tipped Wimbledon to put a stop to their struggling start and claim a point in their match with Watford, who already have two (albeit lucky) victories to their name.

It's all going to come off, just you wait and see.

Andy Knott

Manchester City v Coventry: Goals scored 4 or more 2/1 (£10)

Between them they've already leaked 17 goals, and you can guarantee Maine Road to whip up an atmosphere.

Scott Murray

Arsenal v Charlton: Half time - Full time Arsenal - Arsenal 4/7 (£10)

Charlton impressed on the opening day against Manchester City, but: a) they could easily have been behind before they took the lead, and; b) they were playing Manchester City. Since then, they've been comprehensively beaten by run-of-the-mill Everton, and I can't see them holding an Arsenal side who have been creating countless chances against decent opposition for more than ten minutes.

Arsene Wenger's men have been profligate so far, but that can't continue. The straight win at 2/7 looks a safer bet, but unless all the early chances fall to Ray Parlour, going for the better price shouldn't be too much of a risk.

Oh, and I regret using the phrase "cerebral gambler" last week. I really do.

Sean Ingle

Newcastle v Spurs (Asian handicap bet) Spurs + ½ a goal at 8/11, Manchester City to beat Coventry (11/10), East Fife to beat Montrose (4/6), and Birmingham to beat Nottingham Forest (7/4). Four trebles at £1, one accumulator at £1.

The Asian handicap bet is an interesting new innovation from Blue Square. Apparently it's big in Asia - hence the name - and it could soon be big here too, if Blue Square continue to offer the generous odds they do on the Newcastle v Spurs game. The way I see it, with Carl Cort, Nikos Dabizas, Marcelino, Rob Lee and Kevin Gallacher all out, Spurs have an excellent chance of snatching at least a draw. And if that happens, with George Graham's men on a half-a-goal advantage, my 8/11 shot will come off.

Meanwhile Manchester City are good value at 11/10 to beat a Coventry side who - despite beating Southampton - will struggle this year. And speaking of value, surely East Fife, who are third in the Scottish third division, are the pick of the day at 4/6 - especially as they are playing Montrose, who are the Kursk of the Scottish league - they've lost all three of their games this season and they have a goals for/against record of 0-9.

To finish things off I've gone for Birmingham to beat Forest because Trevor Francis's men seem well overpriced at 7/4. And despite Blue Square's advice I'm sticking to my multiple selections, at least for now. So if three out of the four come off I win. Watch me go!

fields.headline: Most everywhere:  bugs
fields.trailText: My best friend's brother is such a fashion slave that he took up smoking when he found out that Yves Saint Laurent made cigarettes with a gold YSL logo. True. In a similar vein, this season's accessories could be just what the doctor ordered for arachnophobes whose love of style outweighs their fear of insects - bugs are everywhere. It started at Giorgio Armani, where outsized beetle and dragonfly brooches encrusted with crystals and jewels convinced even the most squeamish to see the insect world in a kinder light.
fields.body:
My best friend's brother is such a fashion slave that he took up smoking when he found out that Yves Saint Laurent made cigarettes with a gold YSL logo. True. In a similar vein, this season's accessories could be just what the doctor ordered for arachnophobes whose love of style outweighs their fear of insects - bugs are everywhere. It started at Giorgio Armani, where outsized beetle and dragonfly brooches encrusted with crystals and jewels convinced even the most squeamish to see the insect world in a kinder light.

Vintage spider brooches, the gold ones with fake ruby eyes, have been spotted adorning seriously fashionable lapels, though frankly they remind me of sadistic dinner ladies trying to scare small children. For something a little less hardcore, there's a real buzz (sorry) about Tarina Tarantino's colourful "baby bee" earrings (£35, tel 020-77301234 for stockists), Anya Hindmarch's "ant" shopper (£295, 020-7838 9177) or, if you really can't face the nastier creepy crawlies, sleep easy with Debenhams' gorgeous butterfly-strewn bedlinen, designed by Lulu Guinness (from £15 for a pillowcase, 020-7408 4444). Go on, have a flutter.

fields.headline: Most wanted:  McChampers
fields.trailText: Occasionally, those who have fashionable aspirations and therefore have to update their drinks seasonally feel a pang of envy of people who can ask a barman for "my usual". But I don't really believe anyone does that outside of soap operas and anyway you have to suffer for fashion.
fields.body:
Occasionally, those who have fashionable aspirations and therefore have to update their drinks seasonally feel a pang of envy of people who can ask a barman for "my usual". But I don't really believe anyone does that outside of soap operas and anyway you have to suffer for fashion.

Here at Style, we take very seriously our duty to update you on the fashionable ways to drink champagne. Last year, the only way to drink bubbly was in those cute little blue bottles, Pop, with matching straws. But if you've still got any of those hanging around, drink them up as if they're going out of fashion because, well, they are. Right now, it's all about Champagne McNuggets from London bar Match (in Margaret St, W1 and Tabernacle St, EC2): a tray of shot-sized glasses of champagne or champagne cocktails, perfect for a dinky, glam and totally legal Friday night pep-up.

The only problem is, shot glasses are quite small and I suspect the idea is to share the tray with your friends, but there's nothing to stop you having a tray each. Lovely. Can I get fries with that?

fields.headline: Grammar schools scoop GCSE laurels
fields.standfirst:
Selective education continues to dominate league table, achieving even better performances in the top grades

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Selective grammar schools continue to produce the best GCSE results, according to league tables of exam grades of thousands of state pupils in England, Wales and Northern Ireland released yesterday.
fields.body:
Selective grammar schools continue to produce the best GCSE results, according to league tables of exam grades of thousands of state pupils in England, Wales and Northern Ireland released yesterday.

Grammar schools dominate the top 39 schools that obtained a 100% record of all their candidates achieving the government's benchmark of five or more GCSEs at grades A* to C.

Top is the Royal Grammar, High Wycombe, a boys' school that was helped by its large year group. But even those schools that consistently perform well managed to further raise their performance at the top grades, which is not reflected in the government's system of benchmarking or in the tables.

At King Edward VI Handsworth, for example, the top girls' grammar in inner Birmingham, which is in ninth position, there was an improvement of more than 10% in the top two grades, from 62% last year to 72.7%. Of 128 candidates, more than a quarter got all their results at A*/A, and a further 20 had at least nine passes at A*/A.

All 128 passed at least seven subjects at grade C or above, and 124 girls passed at least nine subjects at C or above.

The headteacher, Elspeth Insch, said: "Staff have been giving up a lot of free time to support the girls and help them achieve. Only 5% of the results are below grade B, showing our efforts have been concentrated on all pupils."

In a year when attention has focused on girls out-performing boys, single sex schools have again done very well.

The London Oratory, the Roman Catholic comprehensive where Tony Blair's eldest son, Euan, got his results yesterday, does not scrape into the table, even though 93% of its 178 fifth-formers obtained five or more good grades of C or above. The school (which said the Blair results were a "private matter"), commented that 80% of its candidates got seven or more subjects at grades A* to C. The prime minister's son is understood to have taken a clutch of GCSEs early, last year.

Thomas Telford, a city technology college in Telford, Shropshire, which selects a proportion of its pupils, edged closer to a 100% pass rate of five plus A* to C grades by achieving a 99.4% pass rate at that level. The headteacher, Kevin Satchwell, said: "We believe we are capable of sustaining these standards for some years to come."

Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said the results were further proof that grammar schools provided an excellent education, and urged the government to end the ballots which allow parents and campaigners to try to convert their local grammar into a non-selective school. "The Conservatives are committed to abolishing the ballots, and letting schools get on with the job of improving standards," she said last night.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, said he shared concern about a drop in take-up of general national vocational qualifications (GNVQs). Of those who took them, 115,000 failed to achieve a grade.

"As far as parents and teachers, and therefore pupils, are concerned, because we've been banging on about standards so much there's been emphasis on GCSE, and that may well have thrown people a bit," he said. GNVQs are being replaced by vocational GCSEs.

Mr Blunkett added that he was confident he would still reach his target of 50% of 16-year-olds achieving five or more GCSEs at A to C by 2002.

But even those schools that consistently perform well managed to further raise their performance at the top grades, which is not reflected in the government's system of benchmarking or in the tables. At King Edward VI Handsworth, for example, the top girls' grammar in inner Birmingham, which is in ninth position, there was an improvement of more than 10% in the top two grades, from 62% last year to 72.7%. Of 128 candidates, more than a quarter got all their results at A*/A, and a further 20 had at least nine passes at A*/A. All 128 passed at least seven subjects at grade C or above, and 124 girls passed at least nine subjects at C or above. The headteacher, Elspeth Insch, said: "Staff have been giving up a lot of free time to support the girls and help them achieve. Only 5% of the results are below grade B, showing our efforts have been concentrated on all pupils." In a year when attention has focused on girls out-performing boys, single sex schools have again done very well. The London Oratory, the Roman Catholic comprehensive where Tony Blair's eldest son, Euan, got his results yesterday, does not scrape into the table, even though 93% of its 178 fifth-formers obtained five or more good grades of C or above. The school (which said the Blair results were a "private matter"), commented that 80% of its candidates got seven or more subjects at grades A* to C. The prime minister's son is understood to have taken a clutch of GCSEs early, last year. Thomas Telford, a city technology college in Telford, Shropshire, which selects a proportion of its pupils, edged closer to a 100% pass rate of five plus A* to C grades by achieving a 99.4% pass rate at that level. The headteacher, Kevin Satchwell, said: "We believe we are capable of sustaining these standards for some years to come." Theresa May, the shadow education secretary, said the results were further proof that grammar schools provided an excellent education, and urged the government to end the ballots which allow parents and campaigners to try to convert their local grammar into a non-selective school. "The Conservatives are committed to abolishing the ballots, and letting schools get on with the job of improving standards," she said last night. David Blunkett, the education secretary, said he shared concern about a drop in take-up of general national vocational qualifications (GNVQs). Of those who took them, 115,000 failed to achieve a grade. "As far as parents and teachers, and therefore pupils, are concerned, because we've been banging on about standards so much there's been emphasis on GCSE, and that may well have thrown people a bit," he said. GNVQs are being replaced by vocational GCSEs. Mr Blunkett added that he was confident he would still reach his target of 50% of 16-year-olds achieving five or more GCSEs at A to C by 2002.

webTitle: BT blames mobiles as payphone charges double

fields.headline: BT blames mobiles as payphone charges double
fields.trailText:
The traditional 10p payphone call is to be scrapped and replaced by a minimum fee of 20p, BT said today. The firm will also start charging for 192 directory enquiries and 153 international enquiries calls from payphones, which are currently
free.
fields.body:
The traditional 10p payphone call is to be scrapped and replaced by a minimum fee of 20p, BT said today. The firm will also start charging for 192 directory enquiries and 153 international enquiries calls from payphones, which are currently free.

BT blamed the rise of mobile phones for the changes, which will come into force on October 3. It said the present 10p minimum charge for local payphone calls - in force since 1984 - did not even cover its costs.

Calls from BT payphones will cost 11p a minute, giving callers 110 seconds for the 20p minimum charge, with 55 seconds for each subsequent 10p top-up.

The changes will benefit those making national calls, who currently get only 43 seconds for 10p - equivalent to a charge of 14p a minute. But local callers stand to lose out: they currently get 67 seconds for their 10p - working out at 9p a minute.

Malcolm Newing, director of BT Payphones, said the costs of cleaning and repairing vandalism to payphones had also helped drive the fee up.

"We have kept the minimum fee at 10p since 1984 and over the same period increased both the number of payphones by 83% and the level of service - with an average of 19 out of every 20 payphones working.

"This is a remarkable achievement but there is increasing competition, particularly from pre-pay mobile phones, and we need to safeguard the future of the payphone service."

He continued: "The mobile phone has completely changed the way people communicate away from home or office. People once used payphones for all those calls, but although the number of calls has increased massively, payphones are used for only 6% of those calls."

The new fee would also help keep underused payphones in rural areas, Mr Newing added. Disabled callers registered for the 195 free directory enquiries service will not be affected by the changes.

webTitle: FA want McAllister's red to turn yellow

fields.headline: FA want McAllister's red to turn yellow
fields.trailText: The FA's new video review panel have recommended that Gary McAllister's red card at Highbury last Monday should be reduced to a yellow card.
fields.body:
The FA's new video review panel have recommended that Gary McAllister's red card at Highbury last Monday should be reduced to a yellow card.

The panel also decided to charge Gilles Grimandi with misconduct following his stamp on McAllister's hand during the game - but they have recommended that Patrick Vieira's controversial red card at Sunderland last Saturday should not be overturned.

In their final decision the panel charged Preston and Sheffield United following a mass confrontation during their game last weekend.

The weekly video review panel's recommendations still have to be confirmed by an FA disciplinary commission who could technically over-rule them. But the FA are bound to take the views of the panel - made up of one ex-player, one former referee and one ex-manager - seriously, and seem unlikely to overturn them.

fields.headline: Police cell death ruled unlawful
fields.standfirst:
Black ex-para 'unlawfully killed'

Special report: race issues in the UK
fields.trailText: Minor charges against five police officers who stood by while a black former paratrooper choked to death on his own blood are to be reviewed by the crown prosecution service after an inquest jury's unanimous verdict of unlawful killing.
fields.body:
Minor charges against five police officers who stood by while a black former paratrooper choked to death on his own blood are to be reviewed by the crown prosecution service after an inquest jury's unanimous verdict of unlawful killing.

Relatives of Christopher Alder, who was filmed by security cameras half-naked, handcuffed and dumped on a police station floor in Hull, cheered and jumped from their seats as the jury foreman described the death as happening "while in a police van and being laid on the floor of the custody suite".

Calls for an independent body to examine all deaths in police custody, and particularly why so many involve members of ethnic minorities, were galvanised by the decision yesterday at Hull coroner's court.

The jury of five men and three women - reduced by one after a member was discharged for allegedly making a racist remark - reached its decision after watching the graphic police video of the last 12 minutes of Alder's life.

They also heard fresh medical evidence from the state pathologist of Northern Ireland, Prof Jack Crane, and a leading expert in deaths under restraint, Dr Nathaniel Cary, which will form part of the CPS review. Both experts concluded that Alder, who was accused by one officer on the videotape of faking and being "as right as rain", died because of blocked air passages that might have been cleared by emergency medical help.

The four constables and a sergeant shown on the video as Alder lay dying on the floor of the custody suite at Queen's Gardens police station in Hull are currently suspended and face criminal charges of misconduct in public office amounting to wilful neglect. They declined to answer potentially incriminating questions at the inquest on more than 150 occasions. The inquest heard that Sgt John Dunne and PCs Nigel Dawson, Neil Blakey, Mark Ellerington and Matthew Barr all thought that Alder was play-acting or asleep until Barr suddenly noticed he had stopped breathing and a vain life-saving attempt was organised.

Alder's sister Janet said: "Justice has been done at last, but it has taken 28 months to get to the only true verdict which could have been given. I want to thank the jury and send them my compliments, and let's hope now we get a proper prosecution."

Ms Alder's solicitor, Ruth Bundy, said the CPS should be looking at the possibility of gross negligence or manslaughter charges against the Humberside officers, after the evidence that emerged during the six-week hearing. She also criticised the Hull coroner, Geoffrey Saul, for concluding his instructions to the jury with a statement that the inquest - the longest to be held into a death in police custody - had seen no evidence that "what happened that night had anything to do with the colour of Christopher's skin".

Ms Bundy, whose case was one of the first to be funded under new legislation extending legal aid to inquests of particular public interest, said: "When is racism ever overt in these cases? The MacPherson report has taught us all about institutional racism, and that terrible image on the film of a black man left like a sack of potatoes to die on the floor speaks volumes about skin colour."

The jury had been warned by Mr Saul not to allow the video to overshadow other evidence, including the fact that the police had been told by emergency staff at Hull royal infirmary that Alder was fit to go home. He was arrested after refusing to leave the hospital, where he was taken after a fight outside the Waterfront, a club in Hull city centre.
