webTitle: Hollick joins big business names in pro-euro push

fields.headline: Hollick joins big business names in pro-euro push
fields.standfirst: Special report: Economic and Monetary Union
fields.trailText: Clive Hollick, the Blairite media mogul, will be named next month as one of the most generous supporters of the cross-party Britain in Europe pressure group, which is campaigning to take Britain into the single currency.
fields.body:
Clive Hollick, the Blairite media mogul, will be named next month as one of the most generous supporters of the cross-party Britain in Europe pressure group, which is campaigning to take Britain into the single currency.

In an attempt to counter claims that big businesses are shunning its campaign, Britain in Europe (BiE) is to publish a list of blue chip companies that have donated more than £5,000 to the group, launched last year by Tony Blair.

Lord Hollick, the chairman of United News and Media, which owns the pro-Blair Express group of newspapers, will be one of the most prominent names on the list, which also includes the former CBI chairman, Sir Brian Nicholson, whose Cookson engineering is supporting the cam paign, British American Tobacco, Unilever, Philips, BAE Systems, BP, ICL and KPMG.

Unilever and BAE are each understood to have donated £100,000. BAT gave £50,000, and the science minister, Lord Sainsbury, gave £400,000.

The disclosure of Lord Hollick's support came as BiE inflamed the euro debate by naming a wide range of companies already using or planning to use the single currency. The decision of household names, such as Orange and Gillette, to adopt the euro suggests Britain will not be able to resist "euro creep" - the use of the euro as a parallel currency to the pound - even if its opts to stay out of the eurozone.

The move follows the revelation this month that Toyota, the Japanese motor giant, has asked its suppliers to invoice the company in euros to protect itself against fluctuations in the value of the pound and that Unilever, the Anglo-Dutch food and household goods group, is "encouraging" its contractors to do the same.

Gillette, the shaving product manufacturer, says it is already able to make and receive payments in euros and Orange, the mobile phone company, is planning to offer corporate and business customers a euro billing service.

Nick Herbert, chief executive of Business for Sterling, the anti-single currency lobby group, dismissed the "euro creep" story as a red herring.

"British businesses use all sorts of currencies, including the dollar. It does not affect the argument about whether we should join economic and monetary union," he said. "Indeed, you could say if British businesses are using the euro successfully, there's no need to join and lose control of our economy. The euro creep argument cuts both ways."

webTitle: Russian submarine disaster: Film shows a mother's fury stifled

fields.headline: Film shows a mother's fury stifled
fields.standfirst:
Television moguls blamed for disinformation as public anger at tragedy continues
Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: The distraught mother of a dead Russian sailor moved centre stage in the Kursk submarine drama yesterday as the symbol of national grief at the loss of 118 seamen and the Russian authorities' response.
fields.body:
The distraught mother of a dead Russian sailor moved centre stage in the Kursk submarine drama yesterday as the symbol of national grief at the loss of 118 seamen and the Russian authorities' response.

Local television showed the woman being involuntarily sedated by injection as she abused a deputy prime minister, Ilya Klebanov, who heads the inquiry into the disaster. She blamed navy chiefs and the government for her son's death.

Examination of the footage, said to be filmed by local television in the northern port of Murmansk, revealed that the screaming woman collapsed after a medic apparently administered a sedative.

The scene increased the criticism of the handling of the tragedy as inept. Captain Vladimir Navrotsky, spokesman for the northern fleet, last night dismissed suggestions that the woman had been silenced for political reasons.

"I'd be surprised if there had been an injection purely to keep her from talking. Probably the woman was worked up because of the conditions in the crowded hall," he said.

The incident occurred last Friday in the Kursk's home port, Vidyayevo, north of Murmansk, as Mr Klebanov was confronted by furious relatives voicing their anger at the loss of their loved-ones.

Although the Kremlin has imposed an almost total media blackout, a cameraman filmed the woman telling navy officers to tear off their epaulettes.

The footage appeared to expose a chilling act of arbitrary crowd control in the traditions of Soviet-era medical abuse.

But while the film confirmed the views of those who see the Russian military authorities as carrying on many of the practices of the repressive Soviet authorities, others saw the furore as a yardstick of how far Russia has travelled beyond the habits of the Soviet era.

Dozens of the relatives of the Kursk seamen have been on tranquillisers since the tragedy.

That the film was shot at all and then shown extensively, illustrated how far Russia has advanced.

If the incident reflected badly on Mr Klebanov, he endured worse on Tuesday when he was attacked by the wife of one of the dead, according to a Moscow journalist who clandestinely recorded the scene.

Relatives asked Mr Klebanov when the bodies would be recovered. "In a few months - maybe. a year. I don't know exactly," he replied.

"'The room erupted," reported Andrei Kolesnikov of the Kommersant newspaper. "A woman shook him. 'You swine, get out there and save them.' Officers rushed to drag her away. It wasn't easy. She clung to Klebanov and shouted, 'You're nothing but scum'."

webTitle: Jonathan Steele: Russian military's cruel disregard for life

fields.headline: Battleship Indifference
fields.standfirst:
Jonathan Steele in Moscow: What the Kursk tragedy dramatised was the military's cruel culture of disregard for life
Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Jonathan Steele in Moscow: What the Kursk tragedy dramatised was the military's cruel culture of disregard for life
fields.body:
The downing of the Kursk brought Russians of all ages and backgrounds together in a drama of solidarity that the country has not known for a decade.

Behind the facade of the collective motherland with its serried ranks parading through Red Square on May Day, the main feature of Soviet society was its atomisation. Fear of the informer as well as the crushing power of unaccountable bureaucracy left people cut off from each other and bound only to family and trusted friends. The chaos of post-communism increased alienation as budget cuts devastated free health and education services and grab-grab-grab privatisation destroyed the last vestiges of the headline Soviet culture of equality and civic concern.

Like a tragic television soap-opera, the Kursk disaster created a national focus for years of pent-up frustration. As the days went by, viewers became familiar with the cast of characters. While the heroes struggled for their lives underwater, the constant replaying of the video of them on deck before they sailed off for the last time, and interviews with their desperate relatives, turned them into icons.

Not since the televising of the first freely elected Soviet parliament's two-week opening session in May 1989 had the nation united so intensely. But that was a good-news fiesta of glasnost. The Kursk encapsulated all the subsequent disappointments and loss of faith - an inferiority complex in relation to the west, depression over poor living conditions, the collapse of the armed forces, technological backwardness, and a feeling of national and individual humiliation.

Russians have always had a love affair with pessimism. The hackneyed epithet "long-suffering" has been much in use this past week and rarely has it seemed more true. Over-riding it all, in a refrain which long predates communism and makes government by consent so hard to achieve in Russia, the feeling persists that vlast (the authorities) were, are, and always will be the enemy.

Every Russian citizen knows Sergei Eisenstein's magnificent film Battleship Potemkin, with the scene where Tsarist troops disband a revolutionary protest, kill men and women with equal ruthlessness and send a pram with a baby careering to its doom down the Odessa steps. This week, in a devastating comment on President Putin's initial reaction to the Kursk disaster, Russia's highest-circulation weekly carried a front-page cartoon of a huge boat with its superstructure shaped like the Kremlin. The name on its mighty prow was Battleship Indifference.

For younger people who hope for a new and more democratic Russia, this was the biggest element in the tragedy. Vladimir Putin appeared even more stereotypically "Soviet" in his frigid remoteness than his two predecessors.

At a personal level, his inadequate behaviour was a reminder that, unlike Gorbachev and Yeltsin who were experienced politicians, he was no more than a mediocre KGB colonel until his unexpected rise to power.

Politically, his ill-judged reactions marked the eclipse of the "family" which surrounded Yeltsin and nominated Putin last year as his successor. Yeltsin's coterie of advisers in the media and big business kept his image as polished as possible given his ill-health, impetuosity, and alcoholism. Since managing Putin's successful election, some of this team have left. Others have been sidelined and the new president is surrounded by cronies from the KGB and the military. Schooled in secrecy, their forte is not image-making.

Can Putin recover? His courage in finally facing the relatives has helped fill some of the sensitivity gap. It was done behind closed doors, but a reporter from Kommersant, who sneaked in posing as a relative, said the president managed to win grudging support. Putin's television interview on Wednesday was also effective. Electing to be questioned rather than give a formal speech which would have required eye contact with viewers, he kept his head lowered and chose his words slowly. This reinforced a picture of contrition to accompany his verbal acceptance of blame.

Beyond the improvement in style, what lessons of substance has he drawn? The answer is not encouraging. Without naming them, Putin attacked the forces "who have brought about the collapse of the army, the navy, and the state". His views chime with a typically doom-laden "appeal" this week in Sovietskaya Rossiya, the mouthpiece of the "national-patriotic" and Russian Orthodox forces. In it the Communist party leader, Gennady Zyuganov, and a dozen other well-known figures raised the spectre of "enemies within" who are trying to destroy Russia. Putin's remarks were ostensibly a rebuke to all the oligarchs, but he had in mind the media tycoons who have been criticising the Kremlin.

In promising money to make the army and navy more compact and efficient, Putin will also have disappointed those Russians who felt the Kursk disaster highlighted a more profound problem which he has not touched on, and cannot, given his record in Chechnya, without a massive change of heart - the military culture of cruelty and disregard for human life, even of one's own servicemen.

The navy's refusal to give anxious relatives the names of the stricken crew was a terrible feature of the disaster. Next month, in the regular half-yearly call-up, this cannon-fodder mentality will be repeated in centres across Russia as 18-year-olds are dragooned into barracks rife with bullying and corruption. Until Battleship Indifference understands that the state belongs to the people rather than people to the state, Russia will not achieve contentment or strength.

webTitle: Scots minister told to resign over 'fundamental' errors

fields.headline: Scots minister told to resign over 'fundamental' errors
fields.standfirst:
Attempts at limitation of damage show little effect

Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Scotland's education minister, Sam Galbraith, is to face a motion of no confidence in the Scottish parliament over the exam results crisis.
fields.body:
Scotland's education minister, Sam Galbraith, is to face a motion of no confidence in the Scottish parliament over the exam results crisis.

The motion was tabled yesterday by the Conservatives who say Mr Galbraith must be held accountable for the debacle that has thrown the education system into disarray.

The development comes as the Scottish qualifications authority said it had almost finished clearing the backlog of incomplete results and giving universities the information they need to confirm admissions.

But the crisis in Scottish education shows no signs of abating and teachers and parents said the fallout could blight the future for a generation of children.

It is two weeks since the SQA admitted problems with the results for the class of 2000. Six thousand certificates failed to arrive on time, and thousands more were incomplete or made no sense.

The SQA initially blamed the chaos on implementation of a radical new exam structure and a complicated computer system, then on data management failures. The authority said only 5% of pupils had been affected and all the marks awarded for higher, in termediate and standard grades were sound.

But teachers across Scotland have reported entire classes with erratic and unbelievable results, and instances of top pupils failing their best subjects and others being awarded grades for exams they never sat. Children have spoken of academic and career choices in ruins.

Even those involved in the marking of this year's papers have raised concerns about the integrity of the system. At one Edinburgh school, a Russian-born pupil and fluent Russian speaker was told he had failed his higher in Russian.

"The truth is that no one knows what has happened" said Lindsay Paterson, professor of education at Edinburgh University. "It's quite clear the SQA does not know but it is also clear it is a lot more than 5% errors they are talking about. Something far more fundamental has gone wrong."

Jim Dalziel, headteacher of Eastbank academy in Glasgow, has spent the last fortnight comforting distraught pupils.

"There are so many stories going round I can't see how the SQA can sit there and say everything is as it should be," he said. "The number of appeals from this school is going to soar because of a lack of confidence and the disparity between our estimate of the grades and what the pupils actually got."

An Eastbank pupil, Candice Napier, plans to appeal but does not trust the SQA to give her the grades she deserves.

The 17-year-old was predicted to get four Bs in her highers but was awarded three Cs and told she had failed chemistry, ruling out any chance of a place at university to study occupational therapy.

"When I saw my results, it was like someone had hit me in the stomach. I cried for two hours. I feel really cheated and really let down," she said. "This is my career we're talking about. I need these results and I'm going to have to do them again next year. There are other people I know who have lost their places at university. This is destroying a lot of lives."

It has been estimated that the number of appeals could reach 100,000 this year, a five-fold increase on previous years.

The SQA insisted that its marking standards were rigorous, despite growing concerns about the integrity of the system. There have been reports of people being asked to mark hundreds of papers at short notice, and of inexperienced markers being pressurised to take part.

"There were a lot of irregularities this year," said David Cooney, a teacher and exam marker with 24 years' experience.

The Scottish executive has confirmed that marking will be examined by an independent inquiry, one of three separate investigations into the debacle. But the inquiries will not examine the role of the education minister.

Mr Galbraith has accepted responsiblity for the crisis but has refused to resign despite repeated calls from opposition parties for him to stand down. The Conservatives' motion of no confidence will be debated when the parliament resumes next week.

"The public has lost faith in our examination system and in the minister in particular," said the Tories' Brian Monteith. "He must take responsibility for the worst education crisis in living memory."

Some suspect Mr Galbraith might quit before any vote can be taken. Others say he is not the only one who should shoulder the blame.

"The extraordinary thing is that the parliament has not been recalled, let alone the education committee," said John Curtice, professor of politics at Strathclyde University. "People will ask: 'What did the Scottish executive do at this biggest ever cock-up in education?' The long-term danger is that unless they can turn this around, they are failing a generation."

Mr Dalziel feared they might already have done that. "Apart from trying to get children through exams, we encourage them to see education as the way forward. For many of the children, it has been soul destroying."

fields.headline: The rat race
fields.standfirst: What's happening in Big Brother
fields.trailText: It's been a tough old week for the residents, what with the exorcism of Resident Evil from their midst and everything, but that's nothing compared to the trauma that new housemate Claire's arrival has caused for the rest of us.
fields.body:
It's been a tough old week for the residents, what with the exorcism of Resident Evil from their midst and everything, but that's nothing compared to the trauma that new housemate Claire's arrival has caused for the rest of us.

It was a stroke of genius by Channel 4 not to opt for "some mature lady", as the housemates predicted, and plump instead for the honest-to-god tabloid charms of Busty Claire, 25. Five weeks in, the housemates have comprehensively run out of chat and have taken to reading books in the garden.

Luckily, however, good old sexual frustration may yet save the day. Claire's been leapt on by Comedy Scouser Craig like fresh meat flung to a starving man; even Darren showed a momentary interest before retreating back into high-camp distraction and his increasingly unsettling preoccupation with Marjorie the chicken. (Tom, for whom it takes some time to broach with a lady the possibility of "intimate moments", has been rather eclipsed on this one). The women don't like her at all, of course - but that, as Mel pointed out, "is what women do".

And viewers may yet come round to Claire and her giggling ways. Because however successful the Big Brother format around the world, it does have one fundamental flaw that's only just beginning to dawn on us Brits. Namely, that as the series builds to its supposed climax, with fewer and fewer housemates remaining, it also becomes (whisper it) really quite dull to watch. The public has been rather mumsy and moral about the whole thing so far (hence motherly Anna's seemingly inviolable position as the bookies' favourite), but with the prospect of the programme turning into a worthy BBC2-style social documentary on sunbathing, cookery and sleep, we'll become increasingly thankful for a bit of Claire's tabloid tomfoolery to spice up the main business of paranoia, bitchiness and bad tie-dyed clothing. Thank god for that hot tub.

fields.headline: Landlady mystery solved
fields.trailText: Human remains discovered in a pub outhouse have provided the key to the mysterious disappearance of landlady Barbra Maddock 27 years ago.
fields.body:
Human remains discovered in a pub outhouse have provided the key to the mysterious disappearance of landlady Barbra Maddock 27 years ago.

Tests by a Home Office pathologist confirmed bones found by workmen in the outbuildings of the Aubrey Arms on Monday were those of the 45-year-old who vanished in 1973.

When police investigated Mrs Maddock's disappearance her husband, Bill, who died of natural causes 10 years ago, insisted he knew nothing about it.

A Dyfed Powys police spokeswoman said yesterday: "It is now confirmed that the remains are those of Barbra Maddock.

"The postmortem was inconclusive and further forensic tests will be undertaken at the Home Office forensic science lab."

Police are renewing their appeal to trace anyone who had access to the outbuilding.

The landlady's son, Hywel Maddock, was a teenager when his mother disappeared and has since taken over the running of the pub.

webTitle: Heat, humidity and thunderstorms forecast for bank holiday weekend

fields.headline: Heat, humidity and thunderstorms forecast for bank holiday weekend
fields.standfirst: Special report: the weather
fields.trailText: Up to 1.5m people will leave Britain for the bank holiday weekend, avoiding the foul conditions forecast for the whole of the country.
fields.body:
Up to 1.5m people will leave Britain for the bank holiday weekend, avoiding the foul conditions forecast for the whole of the country.

Warm, humid weather and heavy rain and thunderstorms were likely in most areas tomorrow, according to the meteorological office. But conditions might improve for Monday, it said.

A spokesman for the London weather centre elaborated: "[Today] will start off quite fine, but across the south-west and parts of south Wales it is going to get much cloudier, and a south-easterly breeze will bring showery rain later.

"There will then be more showery rain and thunderstorms on Saturday. There could be some heavy localised storms, and it will feel quite humid. Eventually the humidity will clear.

"The weather will improve on Sunday in southern and western areas, and Monday doesn't look too bad. Temperatures will be in the region of 21C [70F] to 23C [73F]."

Heathrow airport expects 800,000 passengers over the weekend, with New York, Dublin, Paris and Amsterdam being the most favoured desti nations. Gatwick will handle 480,000 passengers.

Crowds will head for the Notting Hill carnival in London over the weekend and the Reading festival in Berkshire. Tomorrow will also see the NatWest Trophy cricket final between Gloucestershire and Warwickshire at Lord's - sub ject to the vagaries of the weather.

The AA said it expected to help more than 40,000 stranded motorists over the weekend. The south coast of England, the west country, and the west coast of Wales were the most likely areas to be heavily congested.

fields.headline: SurfControl rides high
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Shares in SurfControl, formerly know as JSB Software, surged 212.5p to £21.25 yesterday, after heavyweight broker UBS Warburg gave the company its seal of approval.
fields.body:
Shares in SurfControl, formerly know as JSB Software, surged 212.5p to £21.25 yesterday, after heavyweight broker UBS Warburg gave the company its seal of approval.

Loss-making SurfControl is one of the world's leading providers of so-called snooping software packages, which allow firms to monitor the websites their employees are visiting. The software can also restrict access to websites.

UBS expects the market for SurfControl's products to grow at 50% per annum over the next three year as companies seek to clamp down on the amount of time workers spend surfing the net.

With its robust technical offering and content alliances with companies such as Dun & Bradstreet and Autonomy, UBS believes the company is well positioned to continue capturing market share.

UBS Warburg rates the shares as a "strong buy" and has set a £25 target price.

fields.headline: The generations game
fields.trailText: In the dying days of the 1950s, Denise failed her 11-plus, Martin had been led astray by the evils of rock 'n' roll and Richard was yet to leave Nottingham.
fields.body:
In the dying days of the 1950s, Denise failed her 11-plus, Martin had been led astray by the evils of rock 'n' roll and Richard was yet to leave Nottingham.

In the following 40 years, Denise would marry four times, Martin would be kicked out of university for having an affair with a lecturer's wife, live for three years in Madagascar and eventually marry a woman many years his senior, and Richard would never leave Nottingham. These events may not be entirely unconnected.

Epic and intimate, Family Century (C4) finally reached 1999 and challenged Oscar Wilde's misanthropic musing that "relations are simply a tedious pack of people who haven't got the remotest knowledge of how to live, nor the smallest instinct about when to die."

Quite an ordinary family, the Carpenters - began by Alice and Charles way back in 1900 - were an extraordinary lot, full of wisdom, sorrow, humour and poetry, particularly from wistful Richard. "To see a steam engine in full flow," he said through his milk-bottle glasses, "you couldn't wish for a better sight." The sisters - Joyce, sculpted by Nick Park; Margaret the intellectual rebel; prim Sheila; and baby Aline - shone as magnificent people, together symbolic of Britain over the last 100 years. As the Carpenter family expanded, they found how the fairy tales they were brought up on dissolved, how love hurts, how loss is worse, and what it's like to be a human being - how we are hostages to nature and nurture.

As informative about the human experience as Brain Story was in its way, Family Century was a tender, often brutally honest portrait of how we are. Or rather, how we used to be - in 2000 it's hard to imagine the family ethos as embodied by the Carpenters living on. Friends as the new family, small, discrete family units, economic independence, and possibilities of mobility and migration, globalisation all mean that in 100 years time a documentary like this would be impossible to make, not to mention irrelevant. It seems a sad thought, but only if you believe the fairy tales of happy ever afters, I guess. But when nothing surprises you any more, it's all too tempting to lock yourself in the bathroom and cry yourself blind, back against the bath.

"Diesel changed everything," Richard noted. "And it made the washing on the lines black." Bank holiday fever upon us and what better than two programmes about that great British tradition, motoring. Or, more specifically, sitting in traffic jams. What better? How about root canal work? With Gridlock to look forward to tonight, Motoring Madness (ITV) took the low road of cheap voyeurism with hilarious stories of crazed wannabe bus drivers and boy racers. Very amusing. If only they'd had footage of a drunken chauffeur careering into a Parisian tunnel at literally breakneck speed, Motoring Madness could have had the whole side-splitting set. It's not so funny when you think about it like that.

Britain Behaving Badly (C5), presenters dressing horrendously. With Richard Fairbrass in a suit cut from Miss Marple's curtains and Kate Charman in a nasty red dress and postbox-red Dulux gloss lipstick, each doing their best to out-cheese the other (Charman won), the tone was set for "a true test of 21st-century morals". Fairbrass, who you mistakenly thought could fall no further than Gaytime TV, and Charman, who, all cheeks and no chin, looked like a fish, supervised as the studio audience voted on questions like "Would you snog a famous footballer for £50?" and "Would you give back too much change?" Brace yourself for the shock answers that a) they would, and b) they wouldn't.

Amazingly, it was an hour long; you could hear the elastic stretched to breaking point. By the first ad break we had established beyond any reasonable doubt that we Brits are, in the main, a selfish, opportunistic money-grabbing lot (and there's a revelation for those of you who haven't set foot outside your house in 40 years).

The show's first experiment said it all: a birthday card with a fiver in it was "dropped" in a busy street. Would passers-by post the card, take the money and post the card, or take the money and bin the card? In this test of the nation's morals, most people in Scotland and Yorkshire kept the money while people in Wales and the Westcountry posted the card with the money in it. Does that make them better people? Only if they're not watching Channel 5. That's the ultimate taste test.

webTitle: Dyke stakes all on seven channels

fields.headline: Dyke stakes all on seven channels
fields.standfirst:
BBC chief seeks 10pm slot for main news

Special report: the future of the BBC
fields.trailText: Greg Dyke will tonight stake his reputation as the BBC's director general on a seven-channel digital plan, in an important speech that will signal his intention to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm and launch two new children's services.
fields.body:
Greg Dyke will tonight stake his reputation as the BBC's director general on a seven-channel digital plan, in an important speech that will signal his intention to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm and launch two new children's services.

Warning that the BBC must transform if it is to survive the onset of mass-market digital broadcasting, he will provoke a political storm with his plans to revolutionise the corporation's television channels.

In the keynote MacTaggart lecture at the start of the Guardian Edinburgh international television festival, Mr Dyke will outline a vision of the BBC in which its Reithian public service tradition is merged with the realities of the digital age. The corporation must continue to be available free to everyone, to avoid the emergence of a "digital underclass", he will argue.

The plans will meet with strong opposition. Proposals to launch new services require the approval of the BBC's governors and the culture secretary, Chris Smith. At the moment, Mr Dyke has neither.

Despite Mr Dyke conceding that the BBC "cannot possibly afford to have a tank on every lawn", the corporation's commercial rivals will be furious if it is allowed to expand its services in such a radical way. They believe its privileged method of funding - the licence fee - affords it at an unfair commercial advantage.

Recently Mr Smith toughened the criteria that the corporation must satisfy if it wants to make major changes. And the BBC's intention to create dedicated children's services has been thwarted before - there are already a number of children's channels on cable and satellite TV. It is also understood that ministers are deeply sceptical about moving the Nine O'Clock News, a national institution, to 10pm.

Mr Dyke will attempt to justify moving the bulletin by saying that it will result in improved viewing figures. Executives also hope that by opening up BBC1's evening schedule, it will fare better against its rivals in the key drama and entertainment battleground.

There was support last night from leading BBC figures. Peter Sissons, who presents the 9pm programme, said: "It is a gamble, but a small gamble. I think it is a courageous decision: 10pm is simply a very, very good time for news in this country because of late votes in parliament and because of our special interest in America. When the News at Ten slot was vacated we should have said, 'Thank you very much, we'll have that.' "

John Humphrys, who was the first journalist to anchor the Nine O'Clock News after 11 years in which actors and professional presenters read the bulletins, said: "ITV were mugs for giving up on News at Ten and I don't think they will ever recover from that. They made a lot of grandiose claims about the programmes that would replace it, and they just didn't deliver the goods."

Sir David Nicholas, a former editor of News at Ten, who campaigned for its restoration on ITV, said: "It is a devastating blow to broadcast journalism in ITV. They lost their advantage when they scrapped News at Ten and the BBC is exposing this huge strategic blunder."

Tonight, Mr Dyke will flesh out his plans for the BBC's future after the traditional analogue signal is switched off - probably by the end of this decade - and all viewers watch television through a digital system.

BBC1 will remain the "gold standard" of mainstream television, he will say, but it will be more focused on heavy-hitting entertainment, drama and factual programmes. Inevitably, some programmes that are now on the margins of the BBC1 schedule will move to higher-profile slots on BBC2, he will say, although he will not highlight individual shows.

BBC2 will become the home for some of the more specialised factual programmes, BBC3 will be a youth-oriented channel and BBC4 will be a combination of Radio 3 and Radio 4 on television, with heavyweight cultural and arts programming.

During the day on the third and fourth networks, the BBC will broadcast two new children's channels. One will be for pre-school children, and the other for those aged six to 13. BBC News 24, the rolling news service, forms the seventh service. It will be the first time that Mr Dyke speaks in detail about the plans.

He will confess to having toyed with the idea of abolishing the licence fee and turning the corporation into a subscription service. This was rejected because it would have disenfranchised a whole section of British viewers.

But if his plans for a "universal" BBC are to succeed, Mr Dyke will have to tread a difficult balancing act, competing in a cut-throat marketplace while continuing to meet the corporation's public service obligations.
fields.bodyText: Greg Dyke will tonight stake his reputation as the BBC's director general on a seven-channel digital plan, in an important speech that will signal his intention to move the Nine O'Clock News to 10pm and launch two new children's services. Warning that the BBC must transform if it is to survive the onset of mass-market digital broadcasting, he will provoke a political storm with his plans to revolutionise the corporation's television channels. In the keynote MacTaggart lecture at the start of the Guardian Edinburgh international television festival, Mr Dyke will outline a vision of the BBC in which its Reithian public service tradition is merged with the realities of the digital age. The corporation must continue to be available free to everyone, to avoid the emergence of a "digital underclass", he will argue. The plans will meet with strong opposition. Proposals to launch new services require the approval of the BBC's governors and the culture secretary, Chris Smith. At the moment, Mr Dyke has neither. Despite Mr Dyke conceding that the BBC "cannot possibly afford to have a tank on every lawn", the corporation's commercial rivals will be furious if it is allowed to expand its services in such a radical way. They believe its privileged method of funding - the licence fee - affords it at an unfair commercial advantage. Recently Mr Smith toughened the criteria that the corporation must satisfy if it wants to make major changes. And the BBC's intention to create dedicated children's services has been thwarted before - there are already a number of children's channels on cable and satellite TV. It is also understood that ministers are deeply sceptical about moving the Nine O'Clock News, a national institution, to 10pm. Mr Dyke will attempt to justify moving the bulletin by saying that it will result in improved viewing figures. Executives also hope that by opening up BBC1's evening schedule, it will fare better against its rivals in the key drama and entertainment battleground. There was support last night from leading BBC figures. Peter Sissons, who presents the 9pm programme, said: "It is a gamble, but a small gamble. I think it is a courageous decision: 10pm is simply a very, very good time for news in this country because of late votes in parliament and because of our special interest in America. When the News at Ten slot was vacated we should have said, 'Thank you very much, we'll have that.' " John Humphrys, who was the first journalist to anchor the Nine O'Clock News after 11 years in which actors and professional presenters read the bulletins, said: "ITV were mugs for giving up on News at Ten and I don't think they will ever recover from that. They made a lot of grandiose claims about the programmes that would replace it, and they just didn't deliver the goods." Sir David Nicholas, a former editor of News at Ten, who campaigned for its restoration on ITV, said: "It is a devastating blow to broadcast journalism in ITV. They lost their advantage when they scrapped News at Ten and the BBC is exposing this huge strategic blunder." Tonight, Mr Dyke will flesh out his plans for the BBC's future after the traditional analogue signal is switched off - probably by the end of this decade - and all viewers watch television through a digital system. BBC1 will remain the "gold standard" of mainstream television, he will say, but it will be more focused on heavy-hitting entertainment, drama and factual programmes. Inevitably, some programmes that are now on the margins of the BBC1 schedule will move to higher-profile slots on BBC2, he will say, although he will not highlight individual shows. BBC2 will become the home for some of the more specialised factual programmes, BBC3 will be a youth-oriented channel and BBC4 will be a combination of Radio 3 and Radio 4 on television, with heavyweight cultural and arts programming. This was rejected because it would have disenfranchised a whole section of British viewers. fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText:
Au Revoir Les Enfants
(Louis Malle, 1987)
8pm, FilmFour
fields.body:
Au Revoir Les Enfants
(Louis Malle, 1987)
8pm, FilmFour

Malle's restrained and deeply moving autobiographical tale is set in a Roman Catholic school in occupied France. Gaspard Manesse plays the 12-year-old Julien, who is deputed to look after an introverted new boy, Jean (Raphael Fejtö). After a halting start, a close friendship develops, and Jean's secret is revealed: he's Jewish, and is being hidden from the Germans by the head (Philippe Morier-Genoud). A sombre, delicate film that ranks alongside Malle's other masterpiece of the Occupation, Lacombe Lucien.

Under Suspicion
(Simon Moore, 1992)
11.15pm, Carlton Cinema

Murder mystery set in seedy 50s Brighton. Liam Neeson plays a private eye specialising in divorce (errant hubbies in flagrante and so forth), but the murder of his wife and the appearance of dangerous-to-know Laura San Giacomo raise the stakes. There's a breathless, old-fashioned race against time to save Neeson from the noose, and that's not the final twist.

Eyes Without A Face
(Georges Franju, 1959)
12midnight, FilmFour

Franju's horror classic must rank as the goriest film of its time - not counting his earlier abattoir documentary. Written by the Vertigo authors, there are similar obsessive overtones in Pierre Brasseur's deranged skin surgeon, determined to restore his daughter's missing face at any cost - including murdering young women and stealing theirs. Surgical details aside, the funereal atmosphere is unnervingly effective.

Blow-Up
(Michelangelo Antonioni, 1966)
1am, TCM

During a fashion shoot in a London park, ultra-hip 60s snapper David Hemmings inadvertently captures what he suspects to be a murder on film. Is Vanessa Redgrave (pictured) kissing or killing her victim in the shot's blurry background? At any rate, she sleeps with him in a failed attempt to recover the "evidence". So far, so Hitchcockian, but the mystery fades into the psychedelic background of swinging London, and an extravagantly visual exploration of truth and subjectivity.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Stella Artois ad says about you
fields.trailText: The ad: Two young men return home from some war or other to a rapturous welcome from the locals. One is the son of a publican and is greeted warmly by his father. They all enter a bar and the son recounts how his friend Henri saved his life in battle. His father thanks him and says they should celebrate, plonking a bottle of wine on the counter. "Ah non, Papa - une Stella Artois," insists his son. The father pauses for a second, then reluctantly serves him a glass. But Henri, too, wants a Stella. The sneaky barman then secretly stands on the pipe behind the bar and claims the barrel is empty, pouring him instead "une verre de vin".
fields.body:
The ad: Two young men return home from some war or other to a rapturous welcome from the locals. One is the son of a publican and is greeted warmly by his father. They all enter a bar and the son recounts how his friend Henri saved his life in battle. His father thanks him and says they should celebrate, plonking a bottle of wine on the counter. "Ah non, Papa - une Stella Artois," insists his son. The father pauses for a second, then reluctantly serves him a glass. But Henri, too, wants a Stella. The sneaky barman then secretly stands on the pipe behind the bar and claims the barrel is empty, pouring him instead "une verre de vin".

The jargon: This mini-epic continues in the fine Provençal tradition established by previous Stella films. Once again it positions the lager brand as one of supreme, premium quality (you still don't get a free one even after saving someone's life) combined with a pukka continental heritage.

Personality: You're an 18-34-year-old mid-market male. Far from being a laddish lager lout or real ale-swilling beer bore, you are a bloke with a bit of integrity and fancy you're rather sophisticated, priding yourself on the fact that you understand the ad (which is all in French).

Financial status: Stella Artois may be positioned as "Reassuringly Expensive" but it doesn't, in fact, cost any more than other bottled lagers such as Kronenbourg and Becks. It's basically an everyday luxury and, as such, is meant to be accessible to the masses.

Telling lifestyle detail: You appreciate good quality and are no fashion victim, hence you aspire to drive a Saab or Audi rather than a more predictable badge brand, and your chosen holiday destination is more Mexico than Majorca.

Other relevant data: Real peasants from southern France were cast in the commercial to add authenticity. Also, recent econometric modelling (whatever that is) has shown that every £1 spent on advertising Stella generates a revenue return of £19, according to agency Lowe Lintas.

webTitle: What the children must never know

fields.headline: What the children must never know
fields.standfirst: On worrying about pets
fields.trailText: How to go on holiday, in the days of wine and roses: put credit card and toothbrush in back pocket, passport down side of boot; get on motorbike; ride south.
fields.body:
How to go on holiday, in the days of wine and roses: put credit card and toothbrush in back pocket, passport down side of boot; get on motorbike; ride south.

How to go on holiday in days of responsibility and parenthood: worry about pets.

Recently I found myself not just hearing, not just agreeing with, but actually uttering the phrase: "You need a holiday to get over it, don't you?"

We have four pets. Pet one is a dead (empty, even) tortoise that we found in a field in Italy - about as low-maintenance as you can get, and suitable for asthmatics. Perfect. Pets two, three and four are goldfish. Hardly demanding. I enter into negotiations with various neighbours, friends and the man undergoing a domestic crisis who is currently kipping under my desk, to see who will look after them.

I have just had a cousin's rabbit for a week. It gave my daughter asthma, even though it was in the garden, and me ridiculous agricultural fantasies. But then one dawn the domestic-crisis man, coming back from an evening out, found it having a Mexican stand-off with a giant bandit cat, which would definitely have had him if we hadn't scared him off. A Zen bunny-catching scenario developed, with the man smoking, me lounging nonchalantly on the garden furniture pretending to the rabbit that I wasn't there at all and the rabbit hippitty-hopping all over the place.

It was a fine old romantic-comedy interlude: Cary 'n' Katharine; Meg 'n' Tom - the pyjamas, you know, the tousle-headed thing. For an hour. Five till 6am. Then one successful lunge and the creature was back in the hutch. When the cousin came to fetch it she said, "I wasn't really worried," in a voice that told me she had been, a bit, in a quiet, low-level way.

Pet-care credentials established, the man living under my desk accepted care of the fish while child and I absconded to the Med. In a quiet, low-level way I was a little worried about them, but when we returned the house was pristine, the fish frilly and the man absent. How delightful!

He reappeared on the telephone. "There's been a domestic crisis," he said. (What, another one? How many wives do you have to throw you out?) "I don't know if you've noticed."

The only thing I'd noticed, I told him, was that he seemed to have cleaned out the fish, and how touched I was, and that this was really beyond the call of duty... the beeps went and the phone cut off.

Half-an-hour later he turns up. "How could you tell? How?"

Tell what? Oh the fish - well, the stones were in different places. They were shovelled in a pile in the middle, whereas I arrange them in a classical landscape, falling away from the horizon (the kitchen wall) like some photogravure of a Byronic gorge, laws of proportion and perspective applied, and pond weed placed just so. Like Alan Bennett cleaning the gunk off the tip of the handcream tube, I have curious little ways of avoiding work.

"And?" he said. And what?

Later it comes out. He had indeed cleaned them out - in the gangster sense. He'd killed them. They died all three, floating one morning in fishy eternity, sleeping, as it were, with the fishes. Holding his nose, he'd garnered their smelly little bodies and taken them down to the pet shop in the market. There they were laid out and their identifying marks noted. And three ringers were selected from the tank out the back. Goodbye to Amber, Bamber (short for Cochabamba) and Maud; hello to - well, Amber, Cochabamba and Maud. Because the Child Must Never Know.

Apparently the polite thing to do with a pet that dies in your care is to freeze it. My sister - whose hamster is 105 in hamster years, has alopecia and is in the neighbour's care (she is quietly, low-level worried about it) - says the worst thing is to deny a proper funeral. Alice Thomas Ellis put it succinctly: men love women, women love children, children love hamsters.

And do I mind about the fish? No. No, I remember Stanley, the puppy who used to ride inside my leather jacket, and I just... don't.

 Louisa Young's novel Tree of Pearls is published by Flamingo at £9.99.

fields.standfirst: Knorr New World Sauces
fields.trailText: Form: Coloured gloops in pouches. The New World turns out to be South Africa. Four cook-in variations on a curry theme and one non-curry - Kwazulu Pineapple and Red Pepper, Spicy Durban, Cape Malay, Franschoek Fruity and Karoo Tomato Bredie.
fields.body:
Form: Coloured gloops in pouches. The New World turns out to be South Africa. Four cook-in variations on a curry theme and one non-curry - Kwazulu Pineapple and Red Pepper, Spicy Durban, Cape Malay, Franschoek Fruity and Karoo Tomato Bredie.

Flavour: Most of the spicy subtlety is lost among the stabilisers, flavour enhancers and general goo.

Verdict: There are far better curry pouches (eg Tamarind). Best: Cape Malay. Worst: Karoo Tomato Bredie.

Price: About £1.49 per 500g pouch.

webTitle: Branson must guarantee his lottery dream

fields.headline: Branson must guarantee his lottery dream
fields.standfirst:
Notebook: A further £50m should do it

Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Just another month with his lawyers' meter ticking and Sir Richard Branson should have landed his dream of the People's Lottery. Queue the dewy eyes and the perma-grin.
fields.body:
Just another month with his lawyers' meter ticking and Sir Richard Branson should have landed his dream of the People's Lottery. Queue the dewy eyes and the perma-grin.

In the wake of Wednesday's Lottery Commission antics, it seems to be clear that so long as Sir Richard's consortium can stump up a further £50m in underwriting, the contract has been won.

The entrepreneur indicated yesterday that there would be no problem providing the finance. There are 200 Virgin companies that have made lots of money. Sir Richard has personal assets - and, if necessary, a portion of these will now be earmarked as a guarantee that whatever the eventuality, the lottery prize winners will always get their money.

Sir Richard's personal cheques, of course, presumably come in rather exotic colours, since much of his wealth - and the beneficial ownership of his far-reaching business empire - is squirrelled away in numerous offshore financial havens, getting tanned rather than taxed.

These personal assets are secret, and a portion presumably avoid the British exchequer. And whatever ring-fenced trusts and undertakings and promises Sir Richard and his advisers come up with to convince the lottery regulator that the People's Lottery will always be immunised against possible problems elsewhere in the Virgin empire, the Byzantine structure of his finances means Sir Richard will always lack that crucial intangible - trust.

It is rumoured that the hostile biography of the entrepreneur by the investigative author, Tom Bower, is slated for publication in three weeks' time.

The book may or may not contain disturbing revelations about Sir Richard's business affairs. There may be nothing substantive to reveal. But the zeal with which his libel lawyers have pursued Mr Bower's publishers Fourth Estate - until recently part-owned by the Guardian - has ensured that the tome is eagerly (and long-) awaited.

Such timing could not be more uncomfortable for Sir Richard. But then it is well within his means to trump any of Mr Bower's claims with a simple declaration that yes, the time has come to move his financial affairs back on-shore.

Britain, after all, is where the man made his name and his money.

Rolls recoils

Its not often you see a Rolls-Royce chairman eating humble pie. But yesterday Sir Ralph Robins was there with large knife and fork, tucking in diligently as a catalogue of problems enveloped the aerospace and marine propulsion group, forcing it to post what amounts to a profit warning for 2001.

The display of humility did little to save the share price, which dropped more than 20%. The pride of Britain's manufacturing sector was given the blunt hammer treatment, with unusually high volumes changing hands.

It did, however, at least help in a sentimental sort of way, and barring further trouble the share price should recover gradually.

The problems announced by Rolls yesterday were contemporary issues and ones that should be out of the way by 2002, when Sir Ralph predicts strong growth in earnings will return.

But the seeds of destruction were sewn far back. Rolls has maintained double-digit profit growth for the last couple of years and led everyone to expect it.

But while the City always has appreciated the company's performance, it has never quite understood how it was accomplished. The figures seemed fuzzy.

That fuzziness mattered yesterday, when things went wrong. Nobody wanted to hear that problems with the industrial Trent engines would cost it £120m in the first half of this year.

Nobody expected such high figures for restructuring - £50m per annum for three year.

And nobody can quite understand how Rolls can make £156m in the first six months from its revenue share partners and yet only made £166m in total from its aerospace division. Does that mean all those aero-engine sales only produced £10m?

Apparently not, but nobody seems to understand why .

Then there is the phasing out of aircraft by BA and others proving more quickly than expected. Many Tristars and B747s suddenly are to be removed from service as airlines bring in more fuel-efficient and upmarket craft in a bid to hold market share. Bad news for Rolls, in terms of supplying spares and the like, but hardly its fault.

Sadly, all this took the shine off what were some pretty decent interim results for the company - with sales up some 33%, underlying profits up 26% and a dividend up 11%.

In the long run it might all be in the company's interest as Rolls has suffered in the past for being deemed arrogant. Yesterday, the aerospace management was down to earth. It should stay there.

Britain, after all, is where the man made his name and his money. Rolls recoils Its not often you see a Rolls-Royce chairman eating humble pie. But yesterday Sir Ralph Robins was there with large knife and fork, tucking in diligently as a catalogue of problems enveloped the aerospace and marine propulsion group, forcing it to post what amounts to a profit warning for 2001. The display of humility did little to save the share price, which dropped more than 20%. The pride of Britain's manufacturing sector was given the blunt hammer treatment, with unusually high volumes changing hands. It did, however, at least help in a sentimental sort of way, and barring further trouble the share price should recover gradually. The problems announced by Rolls yesterday were contemporary issues and ones that should be out of the way by 2002, when Sir Ralph predicts strong growth in earnings will return. But the seeds of destruction were sewn far back. Rolls has maintained double-digit profit growth for the last couple of years and led everyone to expect it. But while the City always has appreciated the company's performance, it has never quite understood how it was accomplished. The figures seemed fuzzy. That fuzziness mattered yesterday, when things went wrong. Nobody wanted to hear that problems with the industrial Trent engines would cost it £120m in the first half of this year. Nobody expected such high figures for restructuring - £50m per annum for three year. And nobody can quite understand how Rolls can make £156m in the first six months from its revenue share partners and yet only made £166m in total from its aerospace division. Does that mean all those aero-engine sales only produced £10m? Apparently not, but nobody seems to understand why . Then there is the phasing out of aircraft by BA and others proving more quickly than expected. Many Tristars and B747s suddenly are to be removed from service as airlines bring in more fuel-efficient and upmarket craft in a bid to hold market share. Bad news for Rolls, in terms of supplying spares and the like, but hardly its fault. Sadly, all this took the shine off what were some pretty decent interim results for the company - with sales up some 33%, underlying profits up 26% and a dividend up 11%. In the long run it might all be in the company's interest as Rolls has suffered in the past for being deemed arrogant. Yesterday, the aerospace management was down to earth. It should stay there.

webTitle: First victim of loyalist feud buried

fields.headline: 'It is friend against friend'
fields.standfirst:
First victim of loyalist feud buried

Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: They laid Bobby Mahood to rest in a cemetery on a hill overlooking Belfast just after 3pm yesterday, the first - but not the last - victim of the city's latest bloody internecine feud between rival loyalist gangs to be buried.
fields.body:
They laid Bobby Mahood to rest in a cemetery on a hill overlooking Belfast just after 3pm yesterday, the first - but not the last - victim of the city's latest bloody internecine feud between rival loyalist gangs to be buried.

The feud has already claimed three victims. Mr Mahood and Jackie Coulter, a prominent Ulster Defence Association member, were gunned down while they sat in a car on the Crumlin Road on Monday afternoon.

In retaliation, the Ulster Freedom Fighters - a faction of the UDA - shot dead Samuel Rocket, 22, whose family had UVF links, on Wednesday night.

There had been speculation that the arrest of UFF leader Johnny Adair on Tuesday might help ease tensions and end the bloodletting, but Mr Rocket's death made that seem less likely.

Among the several hundred mourners who gathered yesterday outside Bobby Mahood's small terraced house on Snugville Street nobody seemed quite sure why he had been killed. Mahood, 48, was a popular figure among all sides on the Shankill Road, where many of the shops shut during the funeral as a mark of respect. The press had often used him as a fixer because he knew and got on with everybody, and while he had been a member of the UVF, he was non-active and refused to allow paramilitary songs or regalia in The Sportsmans, a pub he ran a few doors down from his house.

Not surprisingly his family had asked the UVF to stay away from the funeral, but other loyalist paramilitaries were out in force. The UFF officer William "Winky" Dodds, Johnny Adair's best friend, was there, flak jacket bulging underneath his dark suit. John White, chairman of the Ulster Democratic Party, the political wing of the UFF, helped to carry the coffin, while a contingent of the Loyalist Volunteer Force, to which Mr Mahood's brother Jackie defected from the UVF in 1997, had made the trip from Portadown to pay its respects.

Alistair Simpson, governor of the Apprentice Boys of which Mr Mahood was a member, led a guard of honour around his coffin. Mr Mahood's sons, Robert, 22, and David, 15, wept as they walked at the front of the cortege.

Inside the hearse was a wreath from the officers and men of A Company UFF and one from prisoners at Maghaberry jail, now the home of Johnny Adair. The coffin passed by the symbols of the warring factions: a UVF flag hanging from a lamppost and a UFF mural depicting two masked men shouldering rifles.

While the killing of Samuel Rocket has effectively evened the score between the two sides, few people on the Shankill Road believe his death will mark the end of the bloodletting.

Local minister Pastor Jack Mckee, who has called for a meeting of all clergy to try to stop the feud, said there were those on both sides determined to continue the feud. "This is friend against friend and in many respects it is ripping families apart, fathers and sons. There's a numbness within the community."

Ulster Unionist councillor Chris McGimpsey warned the feud could destabilise the peace process. "The community is going to destroy itself if it keeps on killing.The more the violence goes on, the harder it is to stop."

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: "The Scottish A-level exams fiasco gets worse and worse," declared a leader on page 23, August 23. Save for those at some fee-paying schools, students in Scotland do not sit A-levels, but Highers.
fields.body:
"The Scottish A-level exams fiasco gets worse and worse," declared a leader on page 23, August 23. Save for those at some fee-paying schools, students in Scotland do not sit A-levels, but Highers.

A comment piece yesterday, page 23, had Winston Churchill reflecting on his time as a "profoundly unsuccessful schoolboy at Marlborough". He went to Harrow.

Illustrating its feature on the Blitz, Society, August 23, carried a picture of the wrong bomb. The Blitz was the work of German bomber aircraft and ran from 1940-41. The missile shown was a German V-1 flying bomb; it had no pilot and came into use only in 1944. A statistical panel implied that a raid burned the House of Commons chamber in 1944; it was in 1941.

On the same subject, an obituary of the author Constance Babington Smith, who worked in wartime photographic intelligence (page 24, August 12), said that a ram-jet engine powered the V-1. It was a pulse-jet engine.

In our article yesterday, page 29, on the pay of the Energis boss, Mike Grabiner, we said the company had bought Racal's telecom business last year. In fact, it was pipped at the post by the US corporation Global Crossing.

Editing changes made the G2 cover story on Madonna yesterday seem to suggest that Norma Jean/Marilyn Monroe owed her success to effort rather than talent. The passage should have read: "We have seen imitators as apparently diverse as the Spice Girls and Courtney Love - another girl with not much of a voice, not much of a face and no "star quality" (ironically, the one who did have all of these, Kurt Cobain, couldn't stand it and killed himself; it was ever thus, whispers the ghost of Norma Jean) who made herself a star through sheer effort." In the same piece, the essayist who claimed all the arts aspire to the condition of music should have been given as Walter Pater, not Edward.

A classical music review (Philharmonia/Ashkenazy) was printed in error, page 20, August 23. The concert it concerned was given in April.

fields.headline: On message
fields.standfirst: Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Alliance Music promoter Vince Power's website, Meanfiddler.com said yesterday it would link up with Amazon.co.uk to sell its CDs and other related music products online.
fields.body:
 Alliance Music promoter Vince Power's website, Meanfiddler.com said yesterday it would link up with Amazon.co.uk to sell its CDs and other related music products online. Meanfiddler said the deal would further consolidate its presence on the web and would help drive revenues in the first year of trading.

 New chip Bill Gates' Microsoft has designed a powerful new chip to run its WebTV interactive television service as it races for a head start in the sector, a source said yesterday. The chip, called Solo2, is the latest in a string of special processors designed by the WebTV team to combine internet browsing, interactive TV and video recording on a television.

fields.headline: Mail rumbled in the jungle
fields.trailText: It was a juicy exclusive. Under the headline "Exclusive: William, king of the jungle", the front page of yesterday's Daily Mail carried a picture of the young prince clutching a rifle, his face smeared with camouflage paint, apparently on manoeuvres in the wilds of Belize.
fields.body:
It was a juicy exclusive. Under the headline "Exclusive: William, king of the jungle", the front page of yesterday's Daily Mail carried a picture of the young prince clutching a rifle, his face smeared with camouflage paint, apparently on manoeuvres in the wilds of Belize.

On page three, under a fuller version of the picture showing the prince standing with six Welsh Guards, the paper's royal correspondent wrote: "Deep in the Central American jungle and surrounded by the fighting men of the Welsh Guards the 18-year old was clearly enjoying himself in this remarkable photograph taken during a training exercise in Belize."

There was just one problem; far from being taken last week in central America the picture was actually taken over a year ago on Salisbury Plain while the prince was at Eton.

Last night, as the embarrassed newspaper launched a damage limitation exercise, St James's Palace expressed its "disappointment" and privately indicated that an official complaint against the newspaper to the press complaints commission was possible. As the prince was under 18 and still at school at the time the photograph was taken publication potentially breaches the PCC code.

The error came about despite liaison between the palace and the Daily Mail late on Wednesday. Prince William returned from the central American state on Tuesday following a four-day survival course, and executives at the newspaper mistakenly believed the photograph, which includes a stand of silver birch trees in the background, depicted the prince in a tropical rainforest.

The army also pointed out that the prince was not wearing tropical uniform, had a rifle that would not have been used in jungle warfare and looked a lot younger than he appears today

Lawrence Sear, the Mail's managing editor, last night said: "The picture of Prince William was obtained from a reputable news agency. It was published in good faith.as having been taken in Belize. The Mail sought approval from St James's Palace to publish the picture."

St James's Palace said: "We did not see the photograph but it is easy to see how confusion could have arisen... we did not consider that we could object to its publication under the terms of the PCC's code of practice."

Last night it emerged that a news agency, South West News Service, offered the Daily Mail the picture after being approached by a source who claimed to have taken it in Belize. "We deeply regret any offence," said a spokesman.

webTitle: Shayler bailed in time to support his soccer team

fields.headline: Shayler bailed in time to support his soccer team
fields.standfirst:
Special report: David Shayler
Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: The former MI5 officer David Shayler appeared in court for the first time yesterday, three years to the day after making the disclosures which are the subject of the charges against him.
fields.body:
The former MI5 officer David Shayler appeared in court for the first time yesterday, three years to the day after making the disclosures which are the subject of the charges against him.

Carmen Dowd, for the crown prosecution service, said Mr Shayler was charged under the Official Secrets Act with disclosing information in the Mail on Sunday on August 24, 1997, which was damaging to national security and to MI5's capability to carry out its work.

She also said Mr Shayler had passed 62 "sensitive" documents to the newspaper relating to the activities of the security services.

The subjects of the disclosures in the newspaper ranged from MI5's practice of keeping files on prominent Labour politicians, including Peter Mandelson and Jack Straw, as well as pop musicians - including John Lennon - to MI5's alleged incompetence in tracking Khalifa Ahmed Bazelya, a suspected Libyan intelligence officer then based in London.

It is understood that as recently as last month, the prosecution was actively considering further charges including Mr Shayler's more serious and embarrassing allegations, namely MI6 involvement in a plot to assassinate the Libyan leader, Colonel Gadafy.

It is not known whether these charges were abandoned after the intervention of Lord Williams, the attorney general. Charges under the Official Se crets Act require the attorney's consent.

The two offences with which Mr Shayler is charged were agreed by John Morris, Lord Williams's predecessor, at the time of the failed attempt to extradite the renegade MI5 officer from Paris in August 1998.

A CPS spokeswoman said yesterday that the case papers had been reviewed and it was decided to choose two charges on the basis of the evidence.

It is clear, however, that MI5 and MI6 would not welcome argument about the Gadafy plot and other sensitive allegations in open court.

Much of the brief hearing at Bow Street magistrates' court in central London yesterday was taken up with discussion about Mr Shayler's bail conditions, notably whether he must stay with his brother in south London.

"He is a supporter of Middlesbrough football team, and the season has started, and he wishes to go to see Middlesbrough play this Saturday," said John Wadham, his lawyer, who is the director of Liberty, the civil rights group.

"Just imagine the publicity if the chief magistrate stopped him," replied London's chief stipendiary magistrate, Graham Parkinson.

Mr Parkinson agreed to lifting of reporting restrictions.

Mr Wadham told Mr Parkinson that Mr Shayler had returned voluntarily to Britain.

Mr Shayler said after the hearing: "I am glad the magistrate was sympathetic enough to let me go and see Middlesbrough play."

He added: "It is good to have the opportunity to appear in open court. I am glad that the legal process has begun.

"It gives us all the chance to examine the Official Secrets Act in the light of the human rights legislation."

fields.headline: Telecoms steal the show
fields.trailText: Trends come and go in the City, almost as quickly as they do on the catwalks of Paris and Milan. Yesterday the fashionable thing to do was to rotate: sell the outperformers to buy the underperformers. So telecom shares were de rigueur and oil and banking stocks were old hat.
fields.body:
Trends come and go in the City, almost as quickly as they do on the catwalks of Paris and Milan. Yesterday the fashionable thing to do was to rotate: sell the outperformers to buy the underperformers. So telecom shares were de rigueur and oil and banking stocks were old hat.

The net result of the rotation was that the FTSE 100 index ended almost unchanged, down 9.2 points at 6,557, as the gains in one sector were cancelled about by losses in another. Market turnover, however, was heavy at 1.8b.

US investment bank Morgan Stanley Dean Witter was said to have started the rotation, after it encouraged clients to pile into telecoms group Cable & Wireless .

Citing the strength of the company's balance sheet and rather cryptically "further corporate activity", MSDW lifted its investment recommendation on the stock to "strong buy" and set a £14.50 price target. C&W shares ended 60p higher at £11.86 - the best performer in the FTSE 100.

Meanwhile, Investec Henderson Crosthwaite was said to be out banging the drum for embattled BT . Analysts at the brokerage believe the stock is worth around £14 on a sum-of-the-parts basis. At the close BT shares, which have fallen sharply this week on fears about debt levels, were 23p better 819p.

Market heavyweight Vodafone also joined in the fun. It was lifted by news that Verizon Wireless, in which it has a 45% stake, has filed with US regulators to raise $5bn (£3.3bn) in an initial public offering and that Hong Kong conglomerate Hutchison Whampoa has no plans to sell its 3.4% holding in the company.

With investors looking at these factors and not the cost of third-generation mobile phone licenses, Vodafone shares rose 7.5p to 262p - equivalent to 22.5 points on the FTSE 100.

Energis , the long-distance telecoms group, added 9p to 500p. According to Dresdner Kleinwort Benson, if Richard Branson's People's Lottery takes over the running of the National Lottery, Energis, which will provide the data networking services, could see its revenues rise 3%-5%.

And the feel-good factor even extended to the FTSE 250 index. Atlantic Telecom shares put on 32p to close at 282p helped by an ABN Amro "buy" note and Thus ended 2p higher at 122p.

The flip side of the telecoms surge was of course weakness in the oil and banking sectors.

JP Morgan spoke for many when it lowered its ratings on BP (down 10.5p to 636p) and Shell (off 19p at 591p). "We believe the sector strength, which has taken several shares to new highs, is being driven by peak commodity pricing which is likely to prove unsustainable, rather than by fundamental valuation," the brokerage said in a research note.

A touch of reality also returned to the banking sector as analysts at UBS Warburg and Deutsche Bank warned investors not to get carried away be recent gains.

Although the sector has rallied strongly in the past month, helped by a supportive bond market and Barclays (off 41p to £17.59) bid for Woolwich (6p lower at 362p), things remain tough. Analysts believe the impact of increased competition has yet to feed through to the bottom line.

Lloyds TSB , which has risen 15% in the past week, fell 20p to 640p, while Bank of Scotland lost 4p to 596p and Royal Bank of Scotland eased 30p to £13.16.

Aero-engineer Rolls-Royce fell 49p to 169.5p after issuing a surprise profit warning, while Hilton eased 9.5p to 235.5p after disappointing interim figures.

But ARM Holdings advanced 30p to 759p following news that industry leader Intel will be using one ARM's designs in its new XScale processor. Merrill Lynch has a £10.80 price objective for the shares.

Logica rose 45p to £17.71, Sema added 21.5p to £11.10 and Bookham Technology gained 89p to £38.14.

Although the sector has rallied strongly in the past month, helped by a supportive bond market and Barclays (off 41p to £17.59) bid for Woolwich (6p lower at 362p), things remain tough. Analysts believe the impact of increased competition has yet to feed through to the bottom line. Lloyds TSB , which has risen 15% in the past week, fell 20p to 640p, while Bank of Scotland lost 4p to 596p and Royal Bank of Scotland eased 30p to £13.16. But ARM Holdings advanced 30p to 759p following news that industry leader Intel will be using one ARM's designs in its new XScale processor. Merrill Lynch has a £10.80 price objective for the shares. Logica rose 45p to £17.71, Sema added 21.5p to £11.10 and Bookham Technology gained 89p to £38.14.

fields.headline: At this price?  Cattles
fields.trailText: It must be the compliment all departing chief executives seek: a sudden fall in the share price on the day they announce their decision. It happened yesterday to Eddie Cran, the chief executive of Cattles, the company often described as a "loan shark".
fields.body:
It must be the compliment all departing chief executives seek: a sudden fall in the share price on the day they announce their decision. It happened yesterday to Eddie Cran, the chief executive of Cattles, the company often described as a "loan shark".

Despite a 16% rise in first-half, pre-tax profits to £27.8m, the shares fell by 12% to £2.60 yesterday, apparently for little other reason than Mr Cran's exit. Chief executive for a decade, he will leave next May and named his replacement as Sean Mahon, four years his elder at 54 and also chairman of PricewaterhouseCoopers' northern practice.

Mr Cran was bemused yesterday, describing the share price fall as an "over-reaction". It is difficult to disagree.

Even though the government is putting pressure on banks and building societies to provide financial services to customers they have previously shunned, this is unlikely to affect Cattles' business of making loans to people shunned by familiar names on the high street.

Shopacheck, its weekly collection business, achieved a 7% rise in profits to £12.8m while Welcome, the monthly repayment version, reported a 38% rise to £14.5m.

Unlike many other finan cial services providers, Cattles is opening new branches at the rate of one a week, Mr Cran boasted yesterday.

He is about to embark on a charm offensive in the City, introducing his successor before he leaves.

Certainly, the shares have been unloved for sometime, underperforming the sector by 35%, although fairly slightly less badly against the wide All-Share index with a 6% underperformance.

Mr Cran's departure might be just the right moment to start considering investing in the business. The bad debts may be rising a little faster than the company itself would like, but this does not seem to be enough to set the alarm bells ringing. Being saddled with a loan shark tag might be unpleasant but little reason to avoid the shares.

webTitle: Break for Bonfield as BT suffers

fields.headline: Break for Bonfield as BT suffers
fields.trailText: Sir Peter Bonfield, BT's chief executive, is expected to depart for a two-week break today, leaving behind the ignominy of a credit downgrade by Standard & Poor's and a backlash from investors seeking an improvement in the company's dismal share price.
fields.body:
Sir Peter Bonfield, BT's chief executive, is expected to depart for a two-week break today, leaving behind the ignominy of a credit downgrade by Standard & Poor's and a backlash from investors seeking an improvement in the company's dismal share price.

S&P confirmed that BT's long-term credit rating would fall from AA+ to A. Sir Peter is said to have held discussions with S&P in the past week to avoid BBB status.

S&P had threatened BT's rating could fall that low if assets were not sold and debt reduced. The agency made the downgrade with a negative outlook warning.

Many in the Square Mile blame BT's management. One senior fund manager said: "They haven't shown enough urgency about implementing their plan. Many people have high regard for Peter Bonfield but, for each month that goes by, the temperature rises."

BT's debt may rise to £30bn by the middle of next year, after the decisions to spend more than £9bn buying a German third generation mobile phone licence and doubling to 90% its stake in Viag Interkom.

Standard &Poor's rating downgrade takes into account BT's plan to bid in the Italian and French mobile phone auctions. The rating agency remains concerned by the heavy up-front licence costs and spending on networks and how much of this will be recouped through future revenues.

fields.headline: Organic foods 'not more nutritious'
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: The debate over the benefits of organic foods took a new twist yesterday after the government's food standards agency played down suggestions that they were healthier than conventionally grown alternatives.
fields.body:
The debate over the benefits of organic foods took a new twist yesterday after the government's food standards agency played down suggestions that they were healthier than conventionally grown alternatives.

Despite 40% a year increases in sales of organic produce, worth about £540m last year, the agency said there was no evidence to suggest it was safer or more nutritious. But claims that organic crops were more prone to toxins were disputed in a paper the agency described as "balanced".

The Soil Association, a standard bearer for the organic movement, was disappointed by the agency paper.

Advocates of organics have argued that food grown without chemical fertilisers or pesticides must be healthier while critics have said they may be more risky because of naturally occurring infections and because of the liberal use of cow dung.

The agency said: "There is not enough information available at present to be able to say that organic foods are significantly different in terms of their safety and nutritional content ... '

"A varied and balanced diet which includes plenty of fruit, vegetables and starchy foods should provide all the nutrients that a healthy individual requires, regardless of whether the individual components are produced by organic or con ventional methods," the report continued.

Comparisons had proved difficult in a government study into nutritional composition of organic and conventionally-grown fruit and vegetables 10 years ago.

Research from Copenhagen University this year suggesting higher levels of nutrients in organic foods had only looked at one small component - polyphenols - in a few foods.

There was also insufficient evidence that organic produce was likely to cause more food poisoning. Most illnesses appeared to be caused by viruses which would not have originated from animal waste used as fertiliser.

Similarly the idea that organics were more prone to toxins from mould had not been conclusively proved.

A spokesman for the agency said its stance might change as more information became available. "Organic foods are a constant source of questions and worries so we felt we ought to put a position paper on our website."

Henry Hathaway, of the Soil Association, said the agency should be seeking to join European research into the benefits of organics.

"We don't think it has taken into account the cumulative effects of a daily mixture of pesticides and veterinary medicines people are eating. The issue has not yet been adequately investigated scientifically," he said.
