fields.headline: Anglian Water pays £262m for Morrison
fields.trailText: Anglian Water yesterday surprised the City by announcing plans to diversify into construction, through a £262m takeover of the Scottish family-run building firm Morrison.
fields.body:
Anglian Water yesterday surprised the City by announcing plans to diversify into construction, through a £262m takeover of the Scottish family-run building firm Morrison.

The move, which means a £115m fortune for the two brothers who manage the Edinburgh-based company, will allow Anglian to compete for large infrastructure projects - such as building sewage works, gas pipelines and hospitals.

Anglian's managing director Chris Mellor described the deal as a "quantum leap forward" for the group.

"What we're up to is creating a new sort of company which really doesn't exist at the moment," he said.

The takeover is part of Anglian's strategy of reducing its reliance on the more tightly regulated water supply business. The company wants to provide an all-round service of designing, constructing and managing facilities, both inside and outside the water industry.

Mr Mellor said: "There's a trend towards more and more outsourcing, continuing across all the utilities."

He said that by pooling the two businesses' expertise, the group could tackle projects in a more coordinated way. "The water industry is littered with projects designed by consultants, constructed by contractors and which turn out to be very difficult to operate."

The takeover, however, attracted a mixed reception - Anglian's shares fell 13p to 592p, as analysts said the short-term benefits would be limited.

Robert Miller-Bakewell of Merrill Lynch said: "It's about winning business next year, which could affect the bottom line two years later. The deal's got more merit than immediately appears to be the case, but they're going to have to work hard to sell it to the market."

Morrison Construction announced last week that it was in takeover talks, triggering speculation of a bid from the Scandinavian group Skanska, or the civil engineering company WS Atkins. Yesterday's deal values the business at 385p a share in cash, with an option of taking Anglian shares at a rate of 630p each.

Chairman Sir Fraser Morrison admitted he had held "a number of discussion" with other companies. Sir Fraser and his brother Gordon Morrison each have a 22% stake.

The company was established by their father, a Highland joiner, in 1948. It was bought by an international mining group in 1974 but the family bought it back in 1980. Morrison was floated on the stock market five years ago, valued at £75m.

Under the terms of the takeover, Sir Fraser and his brother will each get £22m in cash and £22m in shares giving them a combined 3% stake in Anglian.

Sir Fraser said he "hadn't begun to think about" what he would do with the money. He added: "I'm absolutely thrilled by this - it creates a very exciting prospect."

The two companies said Morrison was cheap, because it was wrongly regarded by the market as a pure construction business, rather than as a facilities management group. Its shares rose 30p to 384p.

Morrison has worked on a diversity of projects, ranging from building a bridge across Loch Glendhu in Scotland to turning a Russian palace in St Petersburg into a hotel. It was among the first western construction firms to begin rebuilding Kuwait's infrastructure following the Gulf War.

webTitle: Jersey grows wary of Caymans and Malta

fields.headline: Jersey grows wary of Caymans and Malta
fields.trailText: Jersey yesterday warned local banks to be wary of doing business with companies from the Cayman Islands and Malta because of concerns about money laundering.
fields.body:
Jersey yesterday warned local banks to be wary of doing business with companies from the Cayman Islands and Malta because of concerns about money laundering.

Underlining a determination to clean up its financial services industry, the Jersey financial services commission advised local firms that neither country's financial crime regulations were up to international standards and that they should check any business was legitimate before accepting it.

Jersey has been under investigation by the financial action taskforce (FATF) combatting white-collar crime, but in June escaped being listed among countries not complying with international efforts to stamp out money laundering.

This latest move marks an attempt to distance itself from countries still not cooperating with the FATF's work.

"Jersey is determined to pro tect itself from money laundering," said Richart Pratt, director general of the commission. "This determination has kept us off the FAFT's non-cooperating jurisdiction list."

The UK regulatory authorities already issue a similar warning to both countries. The Caymans were on the FATF's list of 15 countries not cooperating in the fight against money laundering, while Malta was one of the countries being investigated.

"The international regula tory and law enforcement agencies remain interested in what Jersey does," said Mr Pratt. "To maintain our reputation and keep off the FATF's non-cooperative list, we must and will press on with our reform agenda."

Jersey officials feared that inclusion on the list would have proved damaging the island's economy.

Banks are increasingly wary about operating in jurisdictions which are thought to be soft on money laundering. The American authorities have warned their financial services industry to take care in their dealings with all the countries named by the FATF.

But some of the countries included on the list complain that they were not properly consulted by the FATF ahead of publication.

The Caymans and the Bahamas both expressed disappointment at still being "named and shamed" after their discussions with the financial action taskforce.

webTitle: Go-Ahead chief rejects French bid for rail group

fields.headline: Go-Ahead chief rejects French bid for rail group
fields.trailText: Martin Ballinger, the founder and managing director of Go-Ahead, yesterday rejected a hostile bid for his bus and rail company which would net him over £23m.
fields.body:
Martin Ballinger, the founder and managing director of Go-Ahead, yesterday rejected a hostile bid for his bus and rail company which would net him over £23m.

A French consortium has made a 650p a share offer valuing the company - which was at the centre of the Paddington rail disaster through its Thames Trains subsidiary - at £326m.

Last year Mr Ballinger was paid a salary of £175,000, and he is on a two-year contract which would have to be bought out if the French succeed in their bid.

Last night City analysts said an increased offer might be needed to win control of the company, which operates some London buses as well as rail services to the capital.

Go-Ahead management said it was unanimous in rejecting the offer, which "fails to recognise the strategic value of Go-Ahead, its performance to date and future prospects."

The Newcastle-based company is chasing the South Central rail franchise as well as the two it controls through its holdings in the Thames Trains and Thameslink operations.

Go-Ahead chairman Sir Frederick Holliday said the bid by Caisse des Depots-Developpement, or C3D, and Rhone Capital was purposely timed to precede the Strategic Rail Authority's decision on South Central.

The French have turned aggressive after informal appoaches were made but rebuffed last month. C3D chairman Patrice Garnier accepted the bid was politically sensitive but said: "We remain keen to reach agreement with the Go-Ahead board." The French company wants to combine Go-Ahead with its Transdev subsidiary and use it as a platform to expand in Europe.

Shares in Go-Ahead soared 20% after the initial approach from C3D but yesterday they dropped a 1p at 675p. The 650p a share offer represents a 50p premium over its 433.5p price on July 6, when the predators first made their approach.

Go-Ahead shares had reached 920p last year before they were hit by the negative publicity surrounding the crash of a Thames train near London's Paddington station.

If Go-Ahead does fall it would give French companies a tighter grip on London transport because Connex holds the franchise for South Central and South Eastern trains.

The French presence is not the only other controversial aspect of the deal. Sir Patrick Brown, a civil service bureaucrat with a hand in the rail privatisation process, is on the board of Go-Ahead.

webTitle: Tiger Woods helps drive Clubhaus to record growth

fields.headline: Tiger Woods helps drive Clubhaus to record growth
fields.trailText: Record-breaking performances from golfing stars Tiger Woods and Sergio Garcia are encouraging people to play the sport and have helped fuel the growth of Europe's largest leisure group, Clubhaus.
fields.body:
Record-breaking performances from golfing stars Tiger Woods and Sergio Garcia are encouraging people to play the sport and have helped fuel the growth of Europe's largest leisure group, Clubhaus.

The firm reported better than expected interim results yesterday, with turnover up 42% on the same period last year. Managing director Charlie Parker said the group's rising turnover was evidence of the "cross-demographic" appeal of golf and in particular, its burgeoning appeal to people under 25.

However, analysts believe the group's growth and undervalued equity could make it a target for takeover. Nick Batram from Granville Baird Equities said consolidation in the health and fitness sector was "inevitable", and he warned that Clubhaus could be vulnerable.

Mr Parker said he, too, expected consolidation in the sector but suggested that Clubhaus could be a player. "We've certainly talked to people," he said. "We've not really been able to find the right fit. But if there was one we'd look at it."

The results were also helped, Mr Parker said, by the company's "Country Club concept". Clubhaus has 21 clubs across Europe, 12 focused on golf. It has invested since flotation in 1994 in developing its existing assets to include luxury health and fitness centres as well as acquiring an average of four new health clubs a year. As a result the company's interest pay ments on debt has risen to £2.8m against £0.7m for the same period in 1999.

Profit was up 24% to £5.1m for the six months to June 30, with pre-tax profit before exceptional items down to £2.3m from £3.4m for the same period last year. A 21% rise in membership in six months had pushed profits up. Shares were yesterday up 1.25p at £61.25.

webTitle: Loss of duty-free sinks P&O ferry profits

fields.headline: Loss of duty-free sinks P&O ferry profits
fields.trailText: Profits from P&O's ferries sunk dramatically in the first half of the year, as the abolition of duty-free shopping deterred bargain-hunting day-trippers.
fields.body:
Profits from P&O's ferries sunk dramatically in the first half of the year, as the abolition of duty-free shopping deterred bargain-hunting day-trippers.

A surge in the price of oil aggravated P&O's woes, as the company was forced to pay more to refuel its vessels.

Half-year profits from the group's cross-Channel Stena Line dived 63% to £10m. The number of passengers making the crossing slipped 9% to 5.4m.

Graeme Dunlop, chairman of the ferries operation, said: "It has been tough in comparison to last year but we've demonstrated our resilience - the second quarter was much better than the first quarter."

Mr Dunlop said that without duty-free shoppers, the business was more seasonal: holidaymakers still flocked across the Channel during the summer. The worst of the effect was behind P&O. Figures for the third quarter would be up against a period without duty-free last year.

Revenue from shops and restaurants on ferries has edged up in recent months and is now almost as high as it was before the end of duty-free. The figures failed to move UMAST, the trade union representing P&O's ships' officers, which insisted a fall in profits was no reason to offer "stingy" pay rises. Apay dispute is in the hands of ACAS, the arbitration service. P&O's shares fell 12.5p to 621.5p. A year ago, the price was above £10.

The figures failed to move UMAST, the trade union representing P&O's ships' officers, which insisted a fall in profits was no reason to offer "stingy" pay rises. Apay dispute is in the hands of ACAS, the arbitration service. P&O's shares fell 12.5p to 621.5p. A year ago, the price was above £10.

fields.headline: Pram maker pushes on
fields.trailText: The bumpy ride for Britain's Royal pram maker, Silver Cross, should ease after a takeover by the nursery equipment conglomerate Design Company Holdings.
fields.body:
The bumpy ride for Britain's Royal pram maker, Silver Cross, should ease after a takeover by the nursery equipment conglomerate Design Company Holdings.

The Manchester-based firm will announce today that it has bought the Rolls-Royce brand of the baby transport market, which was saved from bankruptcy last year by private in vestors and pram enthusiasts. Design Company is expected to safeguard the 70 staff at the Silver Cross works in Guiseley, near Leeds, whose products have been wheeled by Madonna and Scary Spice as well as the Queen. Director Joan Spours said staff at the plant, which sells 35,000 of the 700,000 prams bought annually in Britain, had been told that it would be "business as usual" under the new owners.

webTitle: Nursing homes chief leaves with 'amicable' payoff

fields.headline: Nursing homes chief leaves with 'amicable' payoff
fields.trailText: Britain's largest owner of nursing homes, NHP, is to part company with its chief executive, Richard Ellert, after a tough year for the industry in which the group's market value has collapsed by 75%.
fields.body:
Britain's largest owner of nursing homes, NHP, is to part company with its chief executive, Richard Ellert, after a tough year for the industry in which the group's market value has collapsed by 75%.

NHP announced it had reached an "amicable agreement" under which Mr Ellert was resigning with effect from the end of the month.

It is understood that Mr Ellert will receive a substantial pay-off - he is on a one-year rolling contract with a salary of close to £300,000.

Insiders said Mr Ellert's departure was partly due to a proposed tie-up with Southern Cross Healthcare, which for the first time would take NHP into operating, rather than leasing out, care homes.

However, he has come under growing pressure from institutional investors about NHP's difficulties in recent months. Several of the company's biggest tenants, which manage its nursing homes, have gone out of business, leaving the group significantly short of rental income.

Since going public five years ago, NHP has spent close to £700m on nursing homes. Three securitisations have raised more than £550m and the company has an estate of more than 300 properties. These debts have caused concern as nursing homes have become less profitable due to a shortage of trained staff and complicated health and safety regulations. NHP made a first-half loss of £7m.

The collapse in NHP's shares has been accelerated by several high-profile disagreements. NHP's property consultant, DTZ Debenham Thorpe, criticised the way its valuation of the company's estate had been presented in a £194m fundraising last year.

Executives from the company met the serious fraud office in March to look into allegations that a "dirty tricks" conspiracy by outsiders had worsened the decline in its share price.

NHP yesterday denied reports that its bankers and institutional shareholders had asked for Mr Ellert's departure. The company's finance director, Bill Colvin, will run the company until the end of the year, when he is due to leave for a position at the construction firm Jarvis.

It was unclear last night whether Mr Ellert's Spanish girlfriend, Marisa Hontoria, was still employed by NHP as a consultant.

The company's shares were unchanged at 37.5p, against 200p a year ago.

fields.headline: Kill your speed
fields.standfirst: Gloucestershire
fields.trailText: What you see from a moving vehicle, either as roadkill squashed into the tarmac or rapidly disappearing through the roadside hedging, is a surprisingly accurate record of the surviving wildlife in the area and therefore of the existing biodiversity. Apply this to your own experience and you can make estimates for the area you know best.
fields.body:
What you see from a moving vehicle, either as roadkill squashed into the tarmac or rapidly disappearing through the roadside hedging, is a surprisingly accurate record of the surviving wildlife in the area and therefore of the existing biodiversity. Apply this to your own experience and you can make estimates for the area you know best.

In the congested and heavily trafficked south-east of these isles, and around its major conurbations, the answer is likely to be limited to unfortunate domestic pets, hedgehogs, and the urban fox. As you widen the survey area to the rural hinterland then rabbits, slow moving badgers, the country fox, and springtime frogs begin to appear in the account ledger. On motorways, the thriving kestrel population has learnt that free dinners are readily available for a fast mover with sharp beak and talons, and the range of roadkill depends very much on the landscape the motorway is cut through.

I was reflecting on this after a small deer, probably fallow, leapt clear across my bonnet as I was driving slowly along a heavily wooded lane just above the long scarp of Cotswold Edge above North Nibley. And I was saddened, given their population collapse, to kill a barn owl as we left a National Trust cottage in the Cornish Roseland shortly after dawn one day last winter. But the low-flying style of the barn owl makes them particularly vulnerable to traffic. At least, as someone observed, the accident confirmed that a surviving population of barn owls remained in that quiet corner of Cornwall.

On our last visit to Brittany in July, I was conducting the same exercise. With a lighter human population, my census included red squirrels crossing a minor road during the day, a large adder rapidly sidewinding across the baking surface of a coastal road in hot sunshine, which made a memorable mental snapshot, and a lively stoat or weasel (size would determine this and its speed defied any measure) streaking across a country lane. These were nice sightings, as were the badger cubs caught in the headlights late one evening as we returned to the Lieutenant's Quarter at St Anthony's Head last year.

webTitle: Glasgow tops list for the highest death rate in Britain

fields.headline: Glasgow tops list for the highest death rate in Britain
fields.standfirst: Special report: north-south divide
fields.trailText: The death rate for people of all ages living in Glasgow is more than twice as high compared to that for their contemporaries in east Dorset, the government said yesterday in the most comprehensive analysis so far of UK mortality trends.
fields.body:
The death rate for people of all ages living in Glasgow is more than twice as high compared to that for their contemporaries in east Dorset, the government said yesterday in the most comprehensive analysis so far of UK mortality trends.

The male death rate in Glasgow was the highest in Britain at 1,420 per 100,000.

The area of Dorset around Wimborne had the lowest death rate, at 700 per 100,000, according to a survey in Health Statistics Quarterly.

The two places also achieved the highest and lowest scores for deaths among women over the period from 1991 to 1997. In Glasgow the female death rate was 860 and in east Dorset 440 per 100,000.

The figures - adjusted to eliminate differences in the age profile of people in each local authority - showed a clear north-south divide.

Wales, Scotland and North ern Ireland have higher mortality rates than England and the northern English regions have higher rates than the south outside London.

Most of the high mortality districts are classified as manufacturing centres, coalfields or ports.

But the highest death rate for men aged between 15 and 44 was the London borough of Hammersmith and Fulham with 220 per 100,000.

This compared with 70 in Hertsmere, Hertfordshire; Melton, Leicestershire; and Wokingham, Berkshire. A spokeswoman for the Department of Health said action to tackle health inequalities across England was set out last month in the NHS national plan.

To ensure more equal distribution of GPs around the country, there would be 200 new personal medical schemes, mainly in disadvantaged communities, by 2004. And health centres in the most deprived communities would be modernised, among other measures.

In a separate study, the government said that sudden infant death was five times higher for babies born outside marriage where only the mother registered the birth, compared to babies born inside marriage.

In all age groups the rate was highest for children of mothers aged under 20. Peter Goldblatt, editor of the report, said a mother being the sole parent to register the birth did not necessarily mean she was a single parent.

"But often single mothers are also young mothers so those factors combine." A variety of social circumstances, including deprivation, led to the high rates for specific groups, he said.

Ron Robinson, of the Foundation for the Study of Infant Deaths, said it was important that the figures should not be seen as an attack on the parenting skills of either single or younger mothers.

fields.headline: Summer of blood terrorises Spain
fields.standfirst:
Government stance hardens as Eta explodes more bombs

Special report: violence in Spain
Basque government
Association for Peace in Basque Country
Terrorism Research Centre
fields.trailText: Away from the joyful chaos of Bilbao's annual street festival, opponents in Spain's terrorist agony are quietly deciding if the summer of blood will become a long war.
fields.body:
Away from the joyful chaos of Bilbao's annual street festival, opponents in Spain's terrorist agony are quietly deciding if the summer of blood will become a long war.

Four bomb blasts before dawn yesterday in the neighbouring towns of San Sebastian and Irun damaged shops, offices and trucks. It was further proof that the Basque separatist group Eta has found a rhythm which appears to be speeding up.

Stalked by assassins, members of the government in Madrid want moderate Basque nationalists to stop talking to Eta and settle for a military solution. Negotiation is no longer an option, they says.

Widely vilified for hesitating, the moderates are on the verge of abandoning Eta, and with it the likelihood of another ceasefire.

The Basque region encompasses 100 miles of mountain scenery and industrial affluence between the Pyrenees and the northern coast of Spain. It has considerable autonomy from Madrid, more than any other region in Europe, but not enough for Eta, which has killed 11 people since ending its 14-month truce in December after stillborn peace talks.

Optimists think a golden opportunity can be clawed back through all-party talks; others think this is the start of another 30 years of exploding cars and bullets.

More than 800 people have already died. In silent vigils throughout the country, Spaniards have rallied to the government's vow to resist terrorist pressure.

"Not a centimetre,"the prime minister, Jose Maria Aznar, said - meaning the political ground he is willing to cede to Eta for a lasting peace.

In a Bilbao park two Eta men, Efren and Garikoitz, smiled and shook their heads. Speaking Basque through a translator, they said "the organisation" was waging a legitimate struggle for a homeland, called Euskadi, for a people with its own language, culture and history. Madrid was centralist and anti-democratic, they said.

"I don't feel Spanish at all. The only thing I am is Basque," Efren said. "I don't have any quarrel with Spanish people, only the Spanish state."

"Madrid is not interested in peace. Its only objective is to keep control. Every time Aznar appears on TV talking about crushing us, he thinks that'll get him some votes."

Efren's journalism degree course was interrupted by five years in prison for being a member of Eta, which stands for Euskadi and freedom. "They tortured me - beatings, electrodes, a plastic bag over my head. Some friends got sick and died, no one helped them."

Like many comrades, he was sent far away, to Seville to serve his sentence. "It's unconstitutional, but they do it to punish the families," he said.

Efren is a second-generation Basque from Portugalete, a town 10 miles outside Bilbao which attracts migrants from the rest of Spain.

Garikoitz, 32, said the four Eta men who blew themselves up this month in Bilbao were freedom fighters. An architect's assistant, he said there was no shortage of recruits - a view confirmed by an interior ministry official. Garikoitz's sister is serving time in Paris for Eta membership.

"We do not feel free," he said. "It's not just a state of mind, it's a reality."

Security sources suggest that one reason the group ended the truce was to prevent a slide into political atrophy. Its motto is "Actions unite, words divide."

Another explanation is strategic. "It may be that Eta is paving the way for a second truce in more advantageous conditions than the first," said Ramon Cotarelo, a political scientist.

The police estimate that Eta's gunmen and bombers number less than 300,and that they rely on a network of passive and active support. In the region's last election, one in six voted for Eta's political wing, Euskal Herritarrok, formerly known as Herri Batasuna.

Pedestrians in the prosperous Bilbao suburb of Getxo condemn the violence but blame Madrid for the ceasefire's collapse.

The conflict was war, not a terror campaign, they said.

"Spanish people accuse us of not doing enough against Eta but Basques didn't start this. We shouldn't be policemen for the state," said a tattooed 22-year-old. "I'm not going to vote against Euskal Herritarrok because I'm not going to vote at all."

Eta banners flap freely on the main street in Balboa. Banks and mansions wear the scars of past firebombs, hurled to fulfil the group's anti-capitalist ideology.

"Kids here are well educated and well off but they join for emotional reasons, to be anti-establishment, to belong," said a pensioner, Juan Albeniz.

While few in this region are willing to openly side with Madrid, Eta has its enemies. "They are spoilt, murderous fascists," said Consuela Ordonez, 40, whose brother Gregorio, a councillor in San Sebastian, was shot dead.

She said Madrid's refusal to negotiate had not sunk the ceasefire. "The sole responsibility for the violence resuming is Eta's. They're a gang of fanatics. They hate society, they don't listen to people."

Pessimistic about a resolution, she condemned the ambivalence of moderate Basque nationalists. "Why don't they do more to stop the attacks? I don't understand."

In addition to soldiers, police officers, businessmen and politicians, Eta's renewed campaign has been aimed at artists, intellectuals and journalists, including the columnist Jose Luis de la Calle, shot dead in May.

Some writers may be intimidated into censoring their criticism, said Jose Manuel Alonso, a director of the newspaper El Mundo. Others may not. "We don't want to be heroes, but we have a responsibility to do our jobs," he said.

Eta called a ceasefire after the moderate Basque Nationalist party (PNV), which governs the region, moved closer to self-determination. The return to murder has strained that alliance, but Madrid wants it completely ruptured to isolate the militants.

Critics accuse the mainstream media of slavishly backing Madrid's wishes, rather than encouraging the PNV to repair the alliance in the hope of wooing Eta back from the gun.

"This is a crucial phase. The PNV is coming under massive pressure to renounce the militants. If it does, it's a disaster, we're back to square one," said Gorka Espiau, of Elkarri, a non-partisan peace group.

This morning, hundreds of youths in balaclavas will assemble at the town hall to cheer the raising of the Basque flag as part of the city's annual festival.

When the Spanish flag is also raised stones and petrol bombs will fly through the air and a riot will ensue. While Efren and Garikoitz have outgrown such frivolity, they thought they might go along to watch their successors warming up.

fields.headline: Fears grow at Belfast yard
fields.trailText: The future of the politically sensitive Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast is to be decided next week by its Norwegian owners who admitted yesterday that it faced "a very serious situation".
fields.body:
The future of the politically sensitive Harland and Wolff shipyard in Belfast is to be decided next week by its Norwegian owners who admitted yesterday that it faced "a very serious situation".

The yard, which built the Titanic, has been hit by a £23m setback from an American client refusing to pay its bill. Its 1,000 employees have already run out of work.

There is speculation that the yard might be temporarily closed to save money while the company attempts to firm up potential orders for four ferries and two cruise ships.

The owner, Fred Olsen Energy, said it was desperately trying to solve the problem and expected to make a final decision after the weekend.

Ole Jortz, finance director at the Oslo-stock-listed group, said: "This is obviously a very serious situation and it is being discussed every day. We are doing our utmost to find a solution but we are not magicians."

He was speaking after a board meeting yesterday in Oslo which was inconclusive. The company later released a statement to the stock exchange which blamed the US rig operator Global Marine for the crisis.

The yard lost a high court action two weeks ago which allowed Global Marine to remove a drillship completed by the yard but without a final instalment being paid.

Global Marine is blaming cost overruns on Harland and Wolff while the Belfast company accuses the rig owner of making changes to the design which increased the price.

The dispute has gone to arbitration but this could take many years to resolve. A judge disappointed Harland and Wolff management by agreeing that, pending a final outcome, Global Marine could remove the vessel from the yard.

Fred Olsen Energy, owned partly by the Fred Olsen family which also controls Timex, is forking out £2.5m a month to keep the yard running without work.

The company won a potential £300m contract from a ferry company and signed a £200m agreement with a cruise shipowner but these two potential lifesavers have yet to be turned into firm deals.

This could be hard to do as some shipping experts are sceptical about the seriousness of the companies behind these potential deals.

The company planning the ferry contracts, for instance, was only formed in May and so far has been unwilling to reveal who its financial backers are.

Harland and Wolff itself has also talked about its prospects bidding for Ministry of Defence contracts but these also remain highly competitive affairs. And its history with MoD ships has been chequered.

Union officials in Belfast are steeled for the worst, anticipating another round of job losses at the least.

Fred Olsen Energy, owned partly by the Fred Olsen family which also controls Timex, is forking out £2.5m a month to keep the yard running without work. The company won a potential £300m contract from a ferry company and signed a £200m agreement with a cruise shipowner but these two potential lifesavers have yet to be turned into firm deals. This could be hard to do as some shipping experts are sceptical about the seriousness of the companies behind these potential deals. The company planning the ferry contracts, for instance, was only formed in May and so far has been unwilling to reveal who its financial backers are. Harland and Wolff itself has also talked about its prospects bidding for Ministry of Defence contracts but these also remain highly competitive affairs. And its history with MoD ships has been chequered. Union officials in Belfast are steeled for the worst, anticipating another round of job losses at the least.

fields.headline: Rolls results frighten City
fields.standfirst: 'I stay' insists chairman as investors dump shares
fields.trailText: Rolls-Royce yesterday frightened investors with a prediction of flat earnings next year and the disclosure that interim profits have fallen by some 76% due to problems with its key Industrial Trent engine, which cost it £120m.
fields.body:
Rolls-Royce yesterday frightened investors with a prediction of flat earnings next year and the disclosure that interim profits have fallen by some 76% due to problems with its key Industrial Trent engine, which cost it £120m.

The shares fell 22% to 169.75p - leaving a symbol of British engineering excellence vulnerable to losing its place in the FTSE 100 and even to becoming a takeover target.

Rolls-Royce admitted that its business had become over-complex due to acquisitions including Vickers and strong volume growth.

The company announced plans to spend £50m a year until 2003 on restructuring its operations - with 3,000 job losses this year and 2,000 next around the world. No comment was made regarding possible plant closures.

Sir Ralph Robins, the chairman, attacked the City for its "extraordinary reaction" but admitted investor confidence had been dented and would be only be won back by a strong financial performance, which "should" resume in 2002.

Finding himself under pressure as leading investment institutions dumped the stock, 68-year-old Sir Ralph said he had no intention of standing down before his company's retirement ceiling of 70 and insisted that he had full confidence in his management team.

Rolls-Royce blamed anticipated problems for 2001 partly on the unexpectedly rapid withdrawal from service of airliners such as the Tristar and early Boeing 747s - which meant that sales of spare parts would fall over a period.

The company admitted that margins on new engines were not so lucrative and hinted that some sales of newly-developed designs would not even make a profit.

Profits will further be dented by the problems with the In dustrial Trent engines, derived from the aircraft engine range for use in power generation.

Sir Ralph said regulatory demands on emissions meant the company had been forced to "go back to basic physics" and a solution had only just been found.

A breakthrough which had been confirmed only in the last couple of weeks offered tremendous opportunities to upgrade many of its existing engines. Part of the £120m - which was to be taken as an exceptional charge - will be spent on compensating customers for late deliveries.

The news of Rolls' poor performance came after the announcement of strong underlying interim pre-tax profits, up 26% to £195m, as sales rose 33% to £2.8bn.

The future was bright, Sir Ralph insisted, with strong demand for aero-engines, marine propulsion and from the oil and gas market.

"A combination of factors has affected the outlook for 2001, when we expect earnings to be flat, but the strength of our business and the actions taken in 2000 and 2001 will enable earnings growth to resume in 2002," he explained.

He refused to reiterate the company's past pledges to provide double-digit growth, however, and analysts said they remained sceptical after the shocks delivered yesterday.

One sector analyst said: "There are a lot of hidden surprises in there [the accounts]. There is a £100m provision, they have stepped away from their double-digit earnings growth...the market will find it difficult to take comfort."

fields.headline: Verizon Wireless plans $5bn listing
fields.trailText: Verizon Wireless, the joint venture between the US telecommunications company of the same name and Vodafone of the UK, plans to raise $5bn (£3.3bn) by listing its shares on the US stock market in the next few months.
fields.body:
Verizon Wireless, the joint venture between the US telecommunications company of the same name and Vodafone of the UK, plans to raise $5bn (£3.3bn) by listing its shares on the US stock market in the next few months.

The largest mobile phone operator in the United States said in a filing to the securities and exchange commission yesterday that it intended to use the money raised to expand its network and buy additional licenses and assets.

Shares in Verizon, which owns 55% of the joint venture, rose $1.25, or 3%, to $41.75 following the announcement before falling back by midday. Shares in Vodafone, which owns 45% of the wireless business, also rose in London yesterday.

The beleaguered New York-based Verizon also settled the last of problems with workers' unions after a damaging strike.

In the past few days, it has signed a tentative three-year agreement with some 86,000 workers represented by the Communications Workers of America and the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers.

Although the reaction on Wall Street was generally positive to the share offering, analysts raised concerns because of the stock market performance of AT&T Wireless, the second largest operator in the US.

The Verizon rival was spun off from AT&T, America's largest telecoms group, at the end of April in a record-breaking initial public offering which raised $10.6bn.

The shares were priced at more than $30 and subsequently sank. Yesterday they were trading at just over $24.

AT&T sold 20% of its wireless division, prompting analysts to expect a similar percentage to be spun off from Verizon.

Financial details of Verizon's offering were not released yesterday. The number and price of the shares being sold will be announced closer to the IPO, expected some time in the autumn.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: B&Q man joins Homebase pitch
fields.body:
B&Q man joins Homebase pitch

Private equity firm Charterhouse Development Capital confirmed yesterday that it had teamed up with former B&Q man Jim Hodkinson to consider a pitch for Sainsbury's rival Homebase chain.

"We can confirm that we are working with Jim Hodkinson, taking a look at Homebase," said a spokeswoman for the company.

On Wednesday, Sainsbury's announced it was in the early stages of examining a number of strategic options for the DIY chain, which include a disposal, joint venture or alliance.

The chain is expected to be worth around £1bn.

Mr Hodkinson has been looking for a job since he left fashion chain New Look Group following criticism of his conduct at a social event.

Peugeot takes time out for tea

Car company Peugeot has offered to keep tea breaks at 10 minutes long as part of a new offer which will cut hours for its 3,000 workers.

Union leaders are recommending acceptance of the proposed deal, which includes pay rises of 17% for weekend workers.

All employees at the Coventry-based firm will also receive £100 if they vote to accept the deal in a ballot which will end next month.

The firm, which was hit by a strike last month, has reduced the number of Friday evening shifts staff will have to work.

Proposed cuts in tea breaks have been reversed, leaving the 10-minute period unchanged.

Hours will be cut from 39 to 36 and three-quarters a week if the deal is accepted.

Pikachu virus wreaks havoc

Children everywhere beware - Pikachu is not as cuddly as he seems. The Pokémon cartoon character has mutated on the web into a nasty little computer bug, spreading himself via emails like the devastating "love bug" did.

Virus experts said yesterday the cute yellow rabbit-like creature, a darling of the Pokémon video-game family, had popped up in the US, wrecking PCs that it gets into by wiping out their system files.

It has so far sown only a fraction of the havoc its famous predecessor did, but for a worrying reason. Kids, not corporations, are this time the target of the cyber-vandals.

Julius warns of slowdown

Britain's economy is showing signs of a slowdown in private spending although the picture has been muddied by erratic growth out-turns reflecting millenium effects, according to Bank of England's monetary policy committee member DeAnne Julius.

Speaking to the Scottish engineering senior executive dinner in Glasgow, Ms Julius said "we think that private spending growth may be slowing from high levels", partly thanks to the Bank's tighter policy and sterling strength.

webTitle: Rich pickings for America's Nasty Nick

fields.headline: Rich pickings for America's Nasty Nick
fields.standfirst: Special report: Big Brother
fields.trailText: The Olympics may be just around the corner, and it may be a presidential election year, but the only contest ordinary Americans were talking about yesterday was the one that was won on Wednesday night by the naked gay guy.
fields.body:
The Olympics may be just around the corner, and it may be a presidential election year, but the only contest ordinary Americans were talking about yesterday was the one that was won on Wednesday night by the naked gay guy.

In the summer of 2000, Survivor has been to America what Big Brother has been to Britain - the cult voyeur television show of the year, a compulsive national talking-point, and a heaven-sent media opportunity to fill up the silly season.

But while Nasty Nick got his comeuppance in mid-series on Big Brother last week, when the massively hyped final episode of Survivor was broadcast it was The Man America Loved to Hate who emerged from a desert island in the South China Sea as the last contestant standing and the winner of the show's $1m (£673,000) first prize.

Right from the opening episode in May, when the 16 hopefuls landed on Pulau Tiga island off the coast of Borneo, Richard Hatch was Survivor's demon king.

Each week, as the remaining contestants voted to banish one of their number from the island, it was Rich - as he has become universally known - who pulled the strings, schemed the alliances, and plotted his way towards this week's final triumph.

Rich grabbed the headlines with his penchant for on-screen nudity, for his openly gay sexual identity, and above all for his masterly manipulative performance on the island, always seemingly two steps ahead of his rivals.

At the final "tribal council" of the series, seen by more than 40m Americans, 39-year-old Rich turned the tables on his final opponent, Kelly Wigglesworth, to carry off the jackpot.

The final three-hour show generated enormous hype and the result topped the evening news headlines on all channels. Fans of the programme gathered to watch at Survivor parties all across America, many of them dressing - or undressing - as their favourite castaways.

Survivor has eclipsed even the US version of Big Brother. Rich, Kelly and the other contestants have become household names and cult characters in the weekly national soap opera.

Mr Hatch has invested some of his winnings in a trust fund for disturbed teenagers, but he is also expected to cash in on his recognition in a series of lucrative advertising deals.

At least 25m people are reckoned to have watched each episode, a record summer audience, transforming the fortunes of CBS television, which had acquired the reputation of the dullest of the big networks.

Wednesday's audience was expected to rival that for the Oscars and to get close to the number who watch American football's Super Bowl, traditionally the biggest audience-grabber of the year.

The show's catch-phrase, "The tribe has spoken", has replaced Who Wants to be a Millionaire's "Is that your final answer?" as the television trope of the moment.

fields.headline: McChicken friendly burger
fields.trailText: McDonald's, the fast-food group which has spent years in court fighting animal rights activists, has told US farmers to start being nicer to chickens.
fields.body:
McDonald's, the fast-food group which has spent years in court fighting animal rights activists, has told US farmers to start being nicer to chickens.

In a move hailed as a victory for consumer activism by animal rights campaigners, McDonald's has announced that it will no longer buy eggs from farmers who starve their chickens to increase production or who trim their beaks - a practice which agribusiness claims stops the birds killing each other.

The Illinois-based company, which buys 2bn eggs a year to provide the world with Egg McMuffins, is the first large US restaurant chain to publish such guidelines to suppliers.

The company - which took opponents to court for calling it "McMurder" and "McTorture" - is undergoing a $500m corporate makeover with the new slogan of "We Love to See You Smile".

Public concern over the effect of the treatment of animals used for food has grown in Europe and this concern has been taken up in the US. The White House is establish ing a task force to investigate animal welfare.

McDonald's guidelines will require its suppliers to almost double the living space for each hen to a minimum of 72sq in, which would allow them to lie down, although some campaigners said yesterday that the average hen would still not be able to stretch her wings.

The recommendations follow those issued by the scientific advisory committee of the United Egg Producers, the US farming cooperative. Ken Klippen, the executive director of government relations for UEP, told Reuters news agency: "Science shows it is healthier for the bird to be in a cage as opposed to running and stepping on its own droppings."

Some activists said that McDonald's, which operates almost 27,000 restaurants in about 120 countries, still had some way to go yesterday.

Others, like Steven Gross, who is a negotiator for People for the Ethical Treatment of Animals, said: "Other companies have been dragging their feet. This decision will have the salutary effect of waking them up."

fields.headline: CBI doubts Brown can deliver
fields.standfirst: Bureaucracy 'a blessing' if it stops chancellor putting £43bn into key services
fields.trailText: Business leaders yesterday cast doubt on the chancellor's ability to deliver the scale of public spending increases promised last month but suggested his failure to do so might be a blessing in disguise.
fields.body:
Business leaders yesterday cast doubt on the chancellor's ability to deliver the scale of public spending increases promised last month but suggested his failure to do so might be a blessing in disguise.

The Confederation of British Industry said bureaucratic delays and a lack of spare capacity in the building industry could thwart Gordon Brown's efforts to inject an additional £43bn into key services over the next three years.

However, it said this would help to keep the lid on infla tion and rates at a time when there was still a danger of excess demand leading to overheating in the economy.

Publishing its latest quarterly economic forecast, the CBI said its best guess was that inflation would be on target this year and next - despite growth being above the UK's historic trend.

Sudhir Junankar, the CBI's associate director of economics, said: "Next year the main uncertainties for growth and inflation will be whether the chancellor's spending plans will be fully achieved, whether wages remain under control in a tight labour market and what happens to sterling. Although the risks to growth are fairly even these uncertainties could push underlying inflation above our 2.4% forecast by the end of 2001."

Like the City, the CBI is concerned that unless consumer spending slows soon to make room for the extra demand created by higher public spending, the Bank of England could be forced to raise rates again from 6% to damp down inflationary pressure.

But Kate Barker, the CBI's chief economic adviser, said the "leads and lags" in getting the spending plans through Whitehall could delay imple mentation. "There's a lot of uncertainty in this new planning environment. It's not clear how departments will react to it," she said.

Under the new system government departments plan their spending over three years rather than one, tying the cash to the achievement of targets for service delivery.

Labour's second spending review, published in July, included a sharp rise in capital expenditure from 0.3% of gross domestic product in 1999-2000 to 1.8% by 2003-04.

However, ministers are still sitting on unspent cash from previous Treasury allocations. In June it emerged that capital expenditure by the state was down 50% compared with figures during the Conservatives last year in power.

A Treasury spokesman yesterday said departments would publish clear investment strategies in the autumn showing how they would meet their public service targets.

The CBI forecast that output would grow 3.1% this year and 2.7% next and that, based on rates being held at 6%, underlying inflation would average 2.3% and 2.4% respectively. Meanwhile, unemployment is predicted to fall to 1.41m by the end of next year.

webTitle: Putin aims Kursk fury at media

fields.headline: Putin aims Kursk fury at media
fields.standfirst:
Television moguls blamed for disinformation as public anger over tragedy fails to abate

Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: President Vladimir Putin has made his most scathing attack on the Russian media, accusing the two top television moguls of seeking to exploit the Kursk submarine disaster to make millions and damage the armed forces.
fields.body:
President Vladimir Putin has made his most scathing attack on the Russian media, accusing the two top television moguls of seeking to exploit the Kursk submarine disaster to make millions and damage the armed forces.

Under unprecedented criticism from the Russian press for his perceived failure of leadership at a time of national tragedy, Mr Putin lashed out, threatening to punish the proprietors and fight their influence through alternative "honest and objective" media.

His outburst came late on Tuesday at a closed and tightly controlled meeting in the northern navy port of Vidyayevo, where he spent almost three hours with the families of the 118 dead seamen of the Kursk. No outsiders are allowed near Vidyayevo and security in the two weeks since the disaster has been especially tight.

Posing as relatives of the dead, two Moscow journalists from leading national newspapers, Grigori Nekhoroshev of Nezavisimaya Gazeta and Andrei Kolesnikov of Kommersant, spent several days in Vidyayevo and saw the emotional encounter between Mr Putin and 500 Kursk relatives.

Howling at Mr Putin, widows and mothers who, along with the rest of Russia, had been glued to their television screens throughout the Kursk drama, demanded to know why they had received so much contradictory information. Mr Putin blamed television reporting, the journalists said, and then launched the strongest attack on the Russian media he has made since becoming president.

"They are liars. The television has people who have been destroying the state for 10 years. They have been thieving money and buying up absolutely everything," he said, according to Mr Nekhoroshev, a former BBC employee.

"Now they're trying to discredit the country so that the army gets even worse."

Mr Kolesnikov believes that the Kremlin was sending a strong political signal of further pressure to come.

In an interview on state television on Wednesday evening, Mr Putin made barely veiled threats against the two top television moguls, Boris Berezovsky, who controls the main state channel, ORT, and Vladimir Gusinsky, who owns the biggest private channel, NTV.

Blaming the messengers while provisionally exonerating the military and political leaders for their botched handling of the Kursk disaster, Mr Putin said the media were "unscrupulously trying to exploit this misfortune...to gain political capital".

In a clear reference to Mr Berezovsky and Mr Gusinsky, he said: "They'd better sell their villas on the Mediterranean coast of France or Spain. Then they might have to explain why all this property is registered in false names under front law-firms. Perhaps we would ask them where they got the money."

The Russian media have been energetically exploring the Kursk tragedy, exposing navy humbug and Kremlin cover-ups, providing the names of the dead when the authorities refused to do so, and frustrating Kremlin attempts to control the coverage.

The second state channel, RTR, has been favoured with exclusive access to a navy cruiser at the site of the sinking. It was also given the interview with the president, and it provided the only sanctioned, and extremely restricted, pictures of Mr Putin's meeting in Vidyayevo.

The head of RTR is Oleg Dobrodeyev, a founder of NTV in the early 90s, who broke with Mr Gusinsky earlier this year over the channel's critical coverage of the Chechen war and last year's pro-western coverage of the conflict in Kosovo.

Under unprecedented criticism from the Russian press for his perceived failure of leadership at a time of national tragedy, Mr Putin lashed out, threatening to punish the proprietors and fight their influence through alternative "honest and objective" media. His outburst came late on Tuesday at a closed and tightly controlled meeting in the northern navy port of Vidyayevo, where he spent almost three hours with the families of the 118 dead seamen of the Kursk. No outsiders are allowed near Vidyayevo and security in the two weeks since the disaster has been especially tight. Posing as relatives of the dead, two Moscow journalists from leading national newspapers, Grigori Nekhoroshev of Nezavisimaya Gazeta and Andrei Kolesnikov of Kommersant, spent several days in Vidyayevo and saw the emotional encounter between Mr Putin and 500 Kursk relatives. Howling at Mr Putin, widows and mothers who, along with the rest of Russia, had been glued to their television screens throughout the Kursk drama, demanded to know why they had received so much contradictory information. Mr Putin blamed television reporting, the journalists said, and then launched the strongest attack on the Russian media he has made since becoming president. "They are liars. The television has people who have been destroying the state for 10 years. They have been thieving money and buying up absolutely everything," he said, according to Mr Nekhoroshev, a former BBC employee. "Now they're trying to discredit the country so that the army gets even worse." Mr Kolesnikov believes that the Kremlin was sending a strong political signal of further pressure to come. In an interview on state television on Wednesday evening, Mr Putin made barely veiled threats against the two top television moguls, Boris Berezovsky, who controls the main state channel, ORT, and Vladimir Gusinsky, who owns the biggest private channel, NTV. Blaming the messengers while provisionally exonerating the military and political leaders for their botched handling of the Kursk disaster, Mr Putin said the media were "unscrupulously trying to exploit this misfortune...to gain political capital". In a clear reference to Mr Berezovsky and Mr Gusinsky, he said: "They'd better sell their villas on the Mediterranean coast of France or Spain. Then they might have to explain why all this property is registered in false names under front law-firms. Perhaps we would ask them where they got the money." webTitle: TUC calls for £5 per hour pay minimum

fields.headline: TUC calls for £5 per hour pay minimum
fields.standfirst: Chancellor steps into lion's den to justify brakes on statutory wage
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown, the chancellor, will face a demand for a 35% increase in the statutory minimum wage to take it to £5 an hour, and for the restoration of a link between pensions and earnings, when he addresses the TUC's annual conference in Glasgow next month.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown, the chancellor, will face a demand for a 35% increase in the statutory minimum wage to take it to £5 an hour, and for the restoration of a link between pensions and earnings, when he addresses the TUC's annual conference in Glasgow next month.

In a statement issued today, certain to be agreed by the full congress, the TUC General Council says it believes the legal minimum of £3.70 an hour has had less impact than had been expected, and should be uprated by October next year to reflect increasing earnings and to help "close the gap between the rich and poor".

Although the TUC has encouraged use of the £5 figure as a wage bargaining target with employers, the demand to make this figure into a legally enforceable minimum is a significant advance on its previous call for "somewhat more than £4", and was immediately criticised as "potentially very damaging" by the CBI, the main employers' organisation.

Susan Anderson, CBI human resources director, said now was "not the time to throw caution to the wind", following a successful introduction in April last year.

A £5 statutory minimum would increase the pay of at least 2.5m part or full time workers, she said, compared to the 1.7m covered by the existing rate. Other proposals by the TUC, to get rid of the lower rate for workers under 21 and to introduce a minimum for 16 and 17-year-olds, were, she said, "own goals" that would result in there being fewer jobs for young people.

The TUC general secretary, John Monks, described the minimum wage as being one of the government's greatest achievements, but qualified this praise by saying that the 10p per hour increase to £3.70 from this October was "welcome, but not enough".

"Now it is clear, despite employer warnings, that the minimum wage's impact on jobs is negligible, it should be uprated to a more realistic level," said Mr Monks. "Discredited employer scaremongering should not be permanently built into its level."

The government's advisory body, the low pay commission, is due to make a recommendation next summer on whether and by how much to increase the minimum.

The chancellor is blamed by union leaders for insisting on the creation of the lower youth minimum wage and for the delay in bringing in the £3.70 adult rate, and also for setting this year's increase in the state pension at 75p a week. He is consequenetly expected to try to use his speech to highlight his credentials as being in reality a friend of the labour movement.

The final agenda for the Glasgow congress shows the government will face pressure over its part-privatisation plans for air traffic control and the London Underground, as well as its enthusiasm for using the private finance initiative in public services.

And it will come under attack over its policies towards asylum seekers, described in a Transport and General Workers' Union motion as serving to "further alienate, stigmatise and segregate refugees".

 The Ford car company has been warned by the commission for racial equality to act on pledges it gave last year regarding treatment of its black and Asian workers, following years of allegations of racism at its Dagenham plant in Essex and a employment tribunal finding of discrimination, harassment and victimisation. The commission suspended a move for a formal investigation after Ford agreed to a tight timetable of action.

webTitle: Teachers to get bonuses in boost for fresh start scheme

fields.headline: Teachers to get bonuses in boost for fresh start scheme
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: The government is to shake up its flagship "fresh start" scheme for failing schools with a support package including cash injections worth up to £400,000 each over two years.
fields.body:
The government is to shake up its flagship "fresh start" scheme for failing schools with a support package including cash injections worth up to £400,000 each over two years.

One fresh start school, Fir Vale, in Sheffield, is to use an extra £200,000 a year over two years to give staff a 5% loyalty bonus. It will be the first time teachers have been given extra money for teaching in a challenging state school.

David Blunkett, the education secretary, plans a major restructuring of the scheme as four more primary and five more secondary schools join in September, bringing the total up to 25. He conceded there had been problems in the past and said some might still fail.

"We must make sure that what we do is genuinely a fresh start, not what we cobbled together in the past," he said.

In the "refreshment", head teachers of fresh start schools will establish a more direct relationship with the Department for Education as the role of local councils is prescribed and diminished.

Details emerged yesterday of a meeting at the department in June between the existing 16 fresh start head teachers and senior officials, including Michael Barber, head of the standards and effectiveness unit, and Peter Clark, the former acting head of the Ridings school in Halifax. In their first joint meeting, the head teachers called for extra funding and help with the recruitment and retention of staff. The heads are establishing a network to spread best practice.

Yesterday Mr Blunkett visited Fir Vale, which borders his constituency, as pupils received their GCSE results. Seventeen per cent of pupils there won at least five A-Cs at GCSE compared with 11% last year.

The bonus scheme has Mr Blunkett's blessing. In April he said he was prepared to consider giving fresh start staff guarantees of future employment. Yesterday he said Fir Vale, under the leadership of Hugh Howe, its fifth head in five years, could be a "model" fresh start school.

Details of the bonus package are still being worked out but it is likely teachers there will receive their bonus in two instalments, in December and May.

Mr Howe said the school's success meant that its teachers were able to win promotion elsewhere. "Those teachers have been in school two years and they met the challenging environment, contributing to the success we have had. They have been attracting other schools."

Under the fresh start scheme, launched two years ago, failing schools were relaunched with new names, new headteachers, new staff and a new action plan.

An extra £60m for city academies and fresh start schools was earmarked in this year's Budget. Mr Blunkett has been keep to ensure that some of the money gets directly to headteachers. The amount will vary depending on the size and type of school and will be linked to performance targets.

The fresh start initiative was rocked in March when three "superheads" quit fresh start schools in five days.

Mr Blunkett said: "I don't pretend it's the sole answer in every community for every school. If it fails, we should be big enough to put our hands up and say it has. But for many of the communities and the kids that attend those schools, its the last chance."

webTitle: Leeds fans face weeks in jail

fields.headline: Leeds fans face weeks in jail
fields.trailText: British soccer fans could spend weeks or even months in a German jail after being arrested this week in Munich for giving Nazi salutes and chanting "Sieg Heil", police and consular officials said yesterday.
fields.body:
British soccer fans could spend weeks or even months in a German jail after being arrested this week in Munich for giving Nazi salutes and chanting "Sieg Heil", police and consular officials said yesterday.

Three more Britons were detained yesterday and on Wednesday night, bringing to 16 the number in custody. Two of the men were snatched by police in the city's stadium as they were watching Leeds United's Champions' League qualifier with 1860 München.

A police spokeswoman said the men had been identified on the basis of a video shot in a beer hall, where the offences are alleged to have been committed on Tuesday evening. The fans have been charged with using slogans banned by the German constitution.

The offence carries a maximum sentence of up to three years in prison or a fine of up to 360 days' earnings, an official in the regional prosecutors' office said. A judge in Munich was last night considering whether to fine the men within the next few days, or hold them for trial. Police sources said they could spend at least a month in jail if they were bound over.

A spokeswoman for the British consulate in Munich said the first 13 men to be arrested had been questioned by a judge yesterday. "After their interview, the judge decides whether to put them on trial or issue a summary punishment order," she said.

The remaining three fans are expected to be questioned today. The police spokeswoman said all 16 had been transferred from police headquarters to a remand centre.

The consulate spokeswoman said British officials had visited the fans yesterday.

The arrests come at a sensitive moment for Germany, which is in the throes of a roaring controversy over the activities of its neo-Nazi fringe. The chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, called this week for the authorities to use an "iron hand" in dealing with far right offences.

His government fears that neo-Nazi violence, particularly in the east of the country, could deter investment and open divisions in a society where almost 10% of the population is now of foreign origin.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.body:
Euthanasia claim MP clear

Liberal Democrat MP and doctor, Peter Brand, who was investigated by police after telling the Commons during a debate on euthanasia in January that in 1973 he had allowed a two-year-old leukaemia victim to die after the child's parents asked him to withdraw treatment, will not face criminal charges, Hampshire police said.

Boy, 13, denies killing brother

A 13-year-old boy was yesterday remanded to secure local authority accommodation after pleading not guilty at Bristol crown court to murdering his six-month-old brother who died of stab wounds at the family home in Withywood, Bristol, in January. He cannot be named for legal reasons and the case was adjourned until a date yet to be fixed.

Soft drink threat to diabetics

Trading standards officers yesterday warned diabetics across Britain that imported cans of a soft drink Pepsi Max could be dangerous to them. The cans, from Canada, contain sugar, while those made in Britain are sugar-free.

10-year-old dies after overdose

Scott Brennan, 10, who had been grounded by his mother for playing truant from school died after taking an overdose of paracetamol at his mother's home in Birkenhead, Merseyside, in May this year.

The Wirral coroner, Christopher Johnson, recorded an open verdict yesterday. He said he was not convinced that Scott had taken his own life.

Jupiter moon may harbour life

Planetary physicists reported in Science yesterday that the Galileo spacecraft had sent back convincing evidence that Jupiter's fourth largest moon, Europa, has a salt water ocean beneath its icy surface where the right conditions for primitive life may exist.

Heat generated by the gravitational tug-of-war between Europa and its huge parent planet would keep the sub-surface ocean warm, it is argued.

Hit motorcylist drove off in car

A motorcyclist who was thrown from his machine in an accident on the A27, in Falmer, East Sussex, got up and drove off in the vehicle which had hit him moments before. The woman driver, 68, who stopped to check his injuries, was stunned when he hopped into her vehicle and drove off. The car was abandoned nearby.

Children's swings recalled

Toy manufacturer Fisher-Price was yesterday recalling thousands of children's swings after it emerged that they could cause serious injury. Parents have been told not to use Lift & Lock Swings until a defect that means children can wriggle out of the seat has been repaired. A toddler suffered a fractured skull in the US after falling out.

fields.headline: Wildlife protection plans unveiled
fields.standfirst: 81 extra English sites to be listed as areas of European importance
fields.trailText: Wildlife campaigners yesterday welcomed a big increase in the number of rare species and habitats that are to be given extra protection.
fields.body:
Wildlife campaigners yesterday welcomed a big increase in the number of rare species and habitats that are to be given extra protection.

The area of England deemed of European importance for its wildlife should grow by about half under government plans announced yesterday, while new codes for sites of special national scientific interest have been prepared in view of concerns that many sites have not been properly looked after.

Some of the finest natural areas, such as the North Yorks moors, Ashdown Forest in Sussex, Dawlish Warren in Devon and the Overstrand Cliffs in Norfolk, are among 81 proposed additions, covering 300,000 hectares, to England's special areas of conservation.

Beast Cliff in Robin Hood's Bay, Whitby, the Humber and Severn estuaries, the bogs of the Manchester Mosses near Warrington and Wigan, Wimbledon Common and Richmond Park in south-west London, Butser Hill in Hampshire, the Exmoor and Quantock oak woods on the Devon/Somerset border and the cliffs running from Hastings to Pett beach in East Sussex are among other sites proposed for the new list, which has gone out for public consultation.

If the EU agrees, there will be 576 such sites in the UK and 228 in England. The measures offer new protection for mammals such as horseshoe bats, otters, grey seals and bottlenose dolphins, as well as rare snails, fish, beetles and plants, and for habitats including salt meadows, estuaries, heaths, cliffs, bogs, scrub and grassland.

John Prescott, deputy prime minister, said the measures would be a big part of Britain's contribution to the EU's net work of nature conservation. The government and its quango English Nature will add the new areas to England's 4,000 sites of special scientific interest, which cover nearly 7% of its area. Measures in the countryside and rights of way bill are intended to improve protection for such sites.

Although English Nature has limited powers to force landowners to restore damaged sites, conservation campaigners have wanted far tougher penalties for failure to look after such areas and more encouragement for owners to repair damage. The draft guidelines on protection for SSSIs include establishing new management and conservation schemes and ways of considering applications for activities that might damage sites.

Mark Avery, conservation director of the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, said he remained concerned that the protection "creates a false sense of security". Craig Bennett, wildlife campaigner for Friends of the Earth, similarly urged the government "to stand firm and put the interests of people and wildlife before the plans of big business".

Lady Young of Old Scone, chairman of English Nature, said: "England now has over 900,000 hectares of protection for internationally threatened plants and animals and fragile habitats like sand dunes."

webTitle: Six-year-olds' success sets record for early achievement

fields.headline: Six-year-olds' success sets record for early achievement
fields.standfirst: Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: Two six-year-olds - a boy and a girl - yesterday set a GCSE record as the youngest children to pass exams designed for teenagers 10 years older.
fields.body:
Two six-year-olds - a boy and a girl - yesterday set a GCSE record as the youngest children to pass exams designed for teenagers 10 years older.

In results that saw an unprecedented number of passes by pupils of primary school age, Rajaei Sharma, born in November 1993, narrowly beat Elissa Patel, born in October the same year, to the record when both scored Cs in information technology. They had completed the course in nine months.

Elissa's 10-year-old sister Leah got an A in the same exam. All studied at the private tutorial college Ryde college near Watford, Hertfordshire. Other high-flying juniors at the college include nine-year-old Neha Panda, who got an A in maths, and Misbah Anwar, 13, who got As in maths and information technology.

Ten boys aged between eight and 13 were celebrating their success in their first GCSE. The pupils, from Clifton Lodge boys' preparatory school in Ealing, west London, all achieved grades A to C in mathematics.

Among the state school pupils to achieve exceptional results was Ben Nicholls, 12, who got the top grade of A* in GCSE music (which he sat aged 11) to add to the A grade in GCSE English he sat last year. The youngster, who took the exam while a pupil at Newcastle under Lyme school in north Staffordshire, has won a music scholarship to Winchester college, where he will start next month.

In Leicester, a primary school pupil who took a language GCSE at the age of eight was celebrating a top mark. Ashka Shah secured an A grade in the Asian language Gujarati after sitting the paper with other pupils twice her age at the city's Fullhurst community college.

In east London, Annemarie Osawemwenze Imafidon passed her GCSE in maths at grade C, which she took when aged 10. Annemarie, who is a student of St Saviour C of E primary school in Walthamstow, started solving maths problems on the internet at the age of eight but was told by her local education authority that she was too young to attempt a GCSE.

She continued unsupervised and kept up her interest in maths and IT via the web. She eventually enrolled for her exams at the private Lyceum tuition centre at the beginning of this year, and is awaiting the result of her GCSE in computing/IT.

The pupils, from Clifton Lodge boys' preparatory school in Ealing, west London, all achieved grades A to C in mathematics. Among the state school pupils to achieve exceptional results was Ben Nicholls, 12, who got the top grade of A* in GCSE music (which he sat aged 11) to add to the A grade in GCSE English he sat last year. The youngster, who took the exam while a pupil at Newcastle under Lyme school in north Staffordshire, has won a music scholarship to Winchester college, where he will start next month. In Leicester, a primary school pupil who took a language GCSE at the age of eight was celebrating a top mark. Ashka Shah secured an A grade in the Asian language Gujarati after sitting the paper with other pupils twice her age at the city's Fullhurst community college. In east London, Annemarie Osawemwenze Imafidon passed her GCSE in maths at grade C, which she took when aged 10. Annemarie, who is a student of St Saviour C of E primary school in Walthamstow, started solving maths problems on the internet at the age of eight but was told by her local education authority that she was too young to attempt a GCSE. She continued unsupervised and kept up her interest in maths and IT via the web. She eventually enrolled for her exams at the private Lyceum tuition centre at the beginning of this year, and is awaiting the result of her GCSE in computing/IT.

webTitle: Longer life may be bad for health

fields.headline: Longer life may be bad for health
fields.trailText: People born in Britain today will suffer more from long-term illness than any previous generation, according to government forecasts published yesterday that suggest unremitting growth in the pressure on public services.
fields.body:
People born in Britain today will suffer more from long-term illness than any previous generation, according to government forecasts published yesterday that suggest unremitting growth in the pressure on public services.

They show national improvements in health are not keeping pace with increases in life expectancy, leading to longer periods of sickness - particularly for women who tend to live longer than men.

A report by the office of national statistics said girls born in 1997 could expect on average to live to 79.6 years, nearly three years longer than those born in 1981. But there was no increase in the time they could expect to enjoy reasonably good health.

A girl born in 1981 could expect to suffer 16 years of "limiting long-standing illness". For girls born in 1997, this had increased to 19.2 years, the ONS said.

This suggests that girls born in 1997 will be ill for 24% of their lives, compared to 21% for those born in 1981.

Women aged 65 could expect to live 16.9 years longer in 1981, against 18.5 years in 1997. But the time they could expect to live free of long-term illness rose only from 8.5 to 9.3 years. So the average period of debilitation before death increased from 8.4 to 9.2 years.

This means that the average 65-year-old woman can expect nearly half the rest of her life to be affected by illness.

The ONS said the figures were calculated from the government's annual household survey that includes questions on whether people have a "long-standing illness, disability or infirmity" that has troubled them for some time and limits their activities.

The ONS said it produced the report to help policymakers wanting to know whether "the additional years of life are spent in good health or in a prolonged state of illness and dependency".

The prospects may not be quite as gloomy as the long-term illness statistics suggest. Many with long-standing debilities said their health was good or fairly good. A girl born in 1997 can expect 10.9 years of poor health throughout her life and a 65-year-old woman can expect 5.3 years.

"Both life expectancy and healthy life expectancy are higher for women than men. But women can expect to live a larger number of their remaining years, and a larger proportion of years, in poor health or with a limiting long-standing illness, than men," the ONS said.

A boy born in 1997 would have a life expectancy of 74.6 years and could expect 7.7 years of poor health and 15.7 years of "limiting long-standing illness".
