webTitle: Poor design of household goods 'human rights issue'

fields.headline: Poor design of household goods 'human rights issue'
fields.trailText: Millions of people are having to struggle with everyday tasks because of poor design of household goods, such as packaged food and ironing boards, Kim Howells, the consumer affairs minister, said yesterday.
fields.body:
Millions of people are having to struggle with everyday tasks because of poor design of household goods, such as packaged food and ironing boards, Kim Howells, the consumer affairs minister, said yesterday.

Manufacturers were increasing the risks of accidents in the home by producing low quality products that required excessive force or knives or scissors to open.

Mr Howells even suggested that many people were being deprived of their human rights, after a study for the Department of Trade and Industry found that more than a million of the UK's 6.5m disabled people had trouble opening jam jars and using ironing boards.

Hundreds of thousands of them could not easily open packaged foods or shoe polish tins, hold on to teapots, carry kettles or reach into their refrigerators, because many lacked the strength to twist, lift or balance things the way able-bodied people did.

The report called for changes, including bigger and better tear tabs, more textured grips on jar and bottle tops, improved handles and lighter ironing boards with kneeholes for wheelchair users.

Mr Howells said better design would help able-bodied people too. He had commissioned the study after struggling himself to open bottles.

In fitting some vacuum cleaner bags, a PhD in engineering would be useful, he said. "If we can put men on the moon, it seems crazy that you could not design something to work a bit better than that.

"It is a human rights issue: if you have millions of people who can't do these things they are being deprived of quite a few choices excluded from using household products because their needs are not being fully considered at the design stage."

Hospital figures suggested that more than 30,000 people a year needed treatment for accidents involving kitchen or table knives, nearly 10,000 were hurt using vacuum cleaners, more than 9,000 using kettles and 2,800 using ironing boards.

The study for the DTI included interviews with 218 people with disabilities.

Martin Waddingham, who has cerebral palsy and lives with his wife and young son in Shepshed, Leicestershire, said he had trouble lifting hot saucepans. "I use a wheelchair outside, but I get about inside on my knees. One of my troubles is balancing. I lack steadiness and strength, and my right side is weaker than my left.

"Ring pulls are particularly difficult, and if I iron there are more creases than when I started. I do a lot for myself, but most general tasks are pretty difficult."

webTitle: Norwegians add to President Putin's woes

fields.headline: Norwegians add to president's woes
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Norwegians and a Briton involved in the attempt to save the crew of the submarine Kursk went public for the first time yesterday in criticising senior Russian navy officials for hampering the rescue operation.
fields.body:
Norwegians and a Briton involved in the attempt to save the crew of the submarine Kursk went public for the first time yesterday in criticising senior Russian navy officials for hampering the rescue operation.

Norwegian military commanders lined up to complain about the lack of cooperation, while the head of the country's rescue team revealed that he had threatened to pull out because of frustration.

A British crew member of the rescue team also expressed bitter disappointment. But the Royal Navy, more coy than the Norwegians, distanced itself from his comments, saying he was not a member of the Royal Navy but just part of the support ship.

The Norwegians and British had hinted in private at their frustration with Russia's lack of urgency in allowing them to use their sophisticated submersible technology, but until now have avoided going public.

The criticism will add to the pressure from the Russian public on President Vladimir Putin, whose image was dented by his delay in seeking international help.

Paddy Heron, a British member of the crew of the Norman Pioneer, told BBC Scotland that the Russians had frustrated their efforts. "Any arrangement or proposed operation that they spoke about was rescinded, gone back on, altered or countermanded."

He said the British team had been "revolted" to hear the Russians say they had done everything they could.

"We had one of the most sophisticated vessels available in Europe sitting at the wreck site with a submersible specifically designed to rescue men from submarines," he said. "The Russians would not let us use that."

The Ministry of Defence said that Mr Heron was neither in the Royal Navy nor part of the submersible team, but a junior member of the crew of the Norman Pioneer, which was chartered by the Royal Navy from a private company.

Lieutenant Colonel John Espen Lien, spokesman for the Norwegian supreme defence command, said the early information from the Russians was so bad that the Norwegians were not sure that the conditions were safe for the diving team to continue.

"It would have been very difficult for us to continue if the information had not improved," he said.

"It took unnecessary time, to the point that we had to take it up at top levels."

The Russians said that an escape hatch on the Kursk was badly damaged. Norwegian officials and divers said it was not.

"That was one of the areas in which there was incorrect information," Col Lien said. "The Russians never explained what happened...I don't know where in the system that misinformation arose."

He said the problems lay not with the commanders of Russia's northern fleet, but with lower ranking officers unsure how much information they could give to Britain and Norway, both members of Nato.

The leader of Norway's rescue effort, Rear Admiral Einar Skorgen, said in comments to the Norwegian daily Nordlandsposten that he had threatened to call off the rescue effort out of frustration with the Russians.

"I was really angry," he said.

Admiral Skorgen, head of the armed forces in northern Norway, said he telephoned the Russian northern fleet to say that the mission would be in jeopardy unless Russia provided correct data.

"I think this was understood as a threat from my side, yes," he said.

"At times there were so many wrong details and disinformation from Russia that it was close to endangering the divers," he said. "We couldn't rely on the information we were getting."

webTitle: Grieving mother silenced with a syringe

fields.headline: Grieving mother silenced with a syringe
fields.standfirst: Special report: Russia's stricken submarine
fields.trailText: Criticism of Russia's handling of the Kursk tragedy increased yesterday when close examination of local television film showed that the distraught mother of one of the dead sailors was sedated involuntarily while haranguing a deputy prime minister.
fields.body:
Criticism of Russia's handling of the Kursk tragedy increased yesterday when close examination of local television film showed that the distraught mother of one of the dead sailors was sedated involuntarily while haranguing a deputy prime minister.

The incident, revealed in the French newspaper Le Figaro on Wednesday, occurred last Friday in the fleet's home port, Vidyayevo, when Ilya Klebanov, who heads the government inquiry into the disaster, was confronted by grieving and angry relatives.

Despite an almost total ban on the media in Vidyayevo and at the relatives' meetings with navy and government officials, a cameraman for a local television station in the nearby port of Murmansk filmed the woman telling Mr Klebanov what she thought of him, and ordering naval officers to tear off their epaulettes.

An officer sought to restrain the woman, who was beside herself with grief and anger and refusing to keep quiet.

A medic then approached from the rear with a syringe and injected a sedative. The woman collapsed and was taken away.

The incident was broadcast extensively yesterday, to the acute embarrassment of President Vladimir Putin's government. But if it reflected badly on Mr Klebanov, he endured worse on Tuesday when, according to a Moscow journalist, he was attacked by the Ukrainian widow of a Kursk sailor.

Relatives demanded to know when the bodies would be recovered from the submarine. "In a few months, maybe. Or maybe a year. I don't know exactly," he replied.

"He said this almost nonchalantly. The room erupted," Andrei Kolesnikov of the newspaper Kommersant reported.

"A little woman in a fleecy jacket and a skirt down to her ankles ran up to him, grabbed him by the chest and started shaking him. 'You swine, get out there and save them.' Several officers instantly rushed up and dragged her away. It wasn't easy. She clung to Klebanov and was shouting: 'You're nothing but scum, just scum'.

"Klebanov took a while to straighten his tie. His face was like stone," Mr Kolesnikov said. "He looked as though he was offended. He stopped answering questions, and then suddenly blurted out: 'You'll get your sons.'"

fields.headline: Drowned children recovered from pond
fields.trailText: Relatives of two young girls who drowned in a pond as they played with their brothers on a summer evening were today trying to come to terms with their loss.
fields.body:
Relatives of two young girls who drowned in a pond as they played with their brothers on a summer evening were today trying to come to terms with their loss.

Police divers recovered the bodies of Louise Wood, 12, and Hayleigh Hinton, eight, from Ashbyville pond, Scunthorpe, at around 1am yesterday after a four hour search.

The girls, who had gone to the pond on their bikes on Wednesday evening, got into difficulties along with Louise's brother, Josh, seven, as they played on a rope swing over the water.

Hayleigh's brother, Colin Laister, 12, managed to rescue Josh but lost sight of the girls and ran to a hotel to raise the alarm.

Police, fire crews and a helicopter with thermal imaging equipment scanned the pond, which has dense weed below the surface, but found no sign of the girls.

A Humberside police spokesman said the children's relatives were at the scene throughout the search.

A witness said the parents could be heard sobbing as the bodies were eventually recovered by police divers.

Flowers were left at the scene yesterday afternoon in memory of the two girls. One message on a wreath said: "Darling Hayleigh, we will always love and miss you, love mummy, daddy and sisters and brother."

The rope hanging over the water which attracted so many local children was removed by scenes of crime officers.

The two girls lived near to each other Scunthorpe.

A neighbour, who asked not to be named, said: "They were both lovely girls. Everyone around here is in a state of shock."

Another neighbour said: "It must be awful what the families are going through. That lake is dangerous and there should be more safety measures in place."

Ashbyville pond is situated between Scunthorpe's steel plants and an estate containing a hotel, a pub, a supermarket and several shops.

David Simpon, 17, who lives nearby, said there had been several youngsters injured in the water over the last few months.

He said: "We have been warned it's dangerous. We have seen children playing on the rope swing. The water starts shallow and then it suddenly goes down steeply to about 20-25ft."

A spokesman for North Lincolnshire council, which owns the land, said: "This is a terrible tragedy for the whole community and our hearts go out to the girls' families and friends.

"A police investigation is now under way on behalf of the coroner."

Louise's father, Phillip, said in a statement last night: "On behalf of my wife Dawn and myself I would like to thank the emergency services for their efforts and help during the tragic incident when my daughter Louise tragically died.

"I would also like to thank the emergency services for the way they looked after my son following his rescue."

Gillian Hinton also appealed for members of the public who tried to help to come forward so that she could personally thank them.

A massive search involving a helicopter, police and coastguards, was launched yesterday after a seven year old boy went missing in Rhyl, north Wales. Philip Jones, who was said to have learning difficulties, was last seen playing in a paddling pool at 3pm.

North Wales police said they were increasingly concerned for his safety.

Philip was wearing maroon and black checked shorts but was not wearing a top or shoes.

webTitle: Julian Borger: the last indignity for the people of Kosovo

fields.headline: The last indignity for these sufferers is to be disbelieved
fields.standfirst:
Those who are digging up Kosovo's corpses know what the truth is

Special report: Kosovo
fields.trailText: Fate has saved up one last indignity for the people of Kosovo. They lost relatives in last year's bloodletting, they saw loved ones executed before their eyes, and they were driven from their homes. Now - just as they are struggling to rebuild their lives - they are being called liars and accused of faking their grief for political gain.
fields.body:
Fate has saved up one last indignity for the people of Kosovo. They lost relatives in last year's bloodletting, they saw loved ones executed before their eyes, and they were driven from their homes. Now - just as they are struggling to rebuild their lives - they are being called liars and accused of faking their grief for political gain.

The Kosovo backlash is in full swing. The criticism of last year's Nato campaign against the Serbs - quite properly - opened a debate over "humanitarian intervention" and whether such intervention should involve dropping cluster bombs from high altitude.

But the backlash has gone further, casting doubt on the scale and nature of Serb atrocities and calling into question eyewitness accounts of the killing. The allegations are serious - hinting at a conspiracy between Nato, the press, the humanitarian agencies and the refugees themselves - yet they are based on no more than partial and misconstrued evidence.

The starting point for the wave of revisionism has been the exhumations carried out by the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague. As of mid-July, tribunal investigators confirmed they had recovered the remains of 2,808 bodies, believed to be victims of the Serb ethnic cleansing campaign. That routine announcement triggered reports that the total death toll had been less than 3,000 and that Nato (with the aid of its co-conspirators) had deliberately inflated the casualty figures, with estimates of 10,000 dead and more, to justify its intervention.

No one is more bemused by these claims than their supposed source - the Hague tribunal itself. Paul Risley, the chief prosecutor's spokesman, says he is unsure how his tally of exhumations to date came to be portrayed as a final toll.

The search for bodies is continuing. Seven forensic teams are currently probing Kosovo's tortured earth, and aim to investigate another 150 reported grave sites before winter sets in. That will leave 200 sites to go. And more are being reported all the time.

In October, the tribunal will make a decision as to whether to continue its forensic work. If the digging is called off, it will be because the prosecutors believe they have enough evidence to mount a war crimes case against the Serb leadership in Belgrade. It will not be because there are no more bodies to find.

According to Risley, there is a rule of thumb among those whose job it is to literally pick up the pieces after such bloody conflicts. You seldom find more than half the bodies. Kosovo is unlikely to be an exception. Returning refugees found the bodies of their friends and relatives lying in their houses or gardens, in roadside ditches, or scattered through the forests and mountains. The remains were quickly buried in individual graves, prayers spoken and word was passed about who had been found. There was no reason to seek out the Red Cross to add their names to the list of the missing. Their fate was known.

In nearby Bosnia, five years after the war, war crimes investigators are still stumbling across more graves, still finding bones on hillsides. The search will take years in Kosovo as well, and there is reason to believe that even fewer of the bodies will be found. If there was one lesson President Milosevic took from Bosnia, it was to make more of an effort to hide the evidence.

Several mass graves in Kosovo were systematically emptied last summer by the retreating Serb troops. In the village of Izbica, there was well-documented evidence, including videotape and satellite photographs, of the killing and burial of nearly 150 Kosovans in an open pasture. By the time Nato arrived, the field was a mass of churned earth scarred by the caterpillar tracks of heavy diggers. The same happened in Pusto Selo, near Orahovac, and the hamlet of Rezalla, north of Pristina. There is strong evidence that some of the bodies were incinerated in factories, or in some cases burnt on bonfires at the murder scene.

Sure enough, some wild figures did fly about for a few days. The US defence secretary, William Cohen, said in May that 100,000 military-aged men were missing and "may have been murdered". That was clearly an exaggeration, but not much of a conspiracy. The 100,000 figure never gained wide circulation and the estimate most often quoted by Nato officials was 10,000 dead, a guess shared by many humanitarian workers on the borders at the time. Today, it still looks like a reasonable assessment.

In the absence of complete forensic evidence, the only feasible scientific way of gauging the extent of the bloodshed is to take sample surveys of the population and extrapolate. One such epidemiological survey was published in the Lancet in July, estimating that 12,000 people had been killed by "war-related trauma" in Kosovo from February 1998 to June 1999.

The testimony provided by the traumatised refugees as they arrived at the Macedonian, Albanian and Montenegrin borders last year was eventually borne out by the facts. There is no evidence of any concerted effort to deceive or exaggerate. fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: The triumphant return to Leeds is on! In what hostage negotiators describe as "a minor miracle", Gerald Kaufman was released unharmed yesterday by splinter group Real GAF (Judy Garland Appreciation Society). He was found in a bin-liner in the doorway of the London Palladium, which is currently staging The King And I.
fields.body:
The triumphant return to Leeds is on! In what hostage negotiators describe as "a minor miracle", Gerald Kaufman was released unharmed yesterday by splinter group Real GAF (Judy Garland Appreciation Society). He was found in a bin-liner in the doorway of the London Palladium, which is currently staging The King And I. "He's been singing the same songs - Hello Young Lovers, Whistle A Happy Tune, etcetera, etcetera, etcetera - without pause" said the attached note, "and we can't take any more." Gerald returns just in time to travel with my colleague Richard Adams and myself to Crewe this morning. A chauffeur will pick us up off the 11.04 train, and after a quick tour of the Rolls-Royce factory we will collect the £250,000 Corniche convertible RR1 and drive to Leeds. This is the itinerary: 5pm, outside the town hall; 5.40 outside Opera North; 6.20 outside the West Yorkshire Playhouse. Come and say hello. A full report will appear next Wednesday.

 We're only five months late on this, but when Al Gore was making a keynote address at the New Hampshire primary, a woman bustled on to the stage to hand him a slip of paper. "This is a first for me," droned the VP, "but I have a public service announcement. Would the owner of car registration number ABC 1234 please move it. It is causing an obstruction." Everyone was amused at this stunt to show Mr Gore's human side, and no one laughed louder than the BBC Newsnight team. Not that they were laughing when they left the building to find their car gone, but there we are.

 Shadow chancellor Polly Portillo appears to be taking his constituency role extremely seriously. This weekend, the local MP will eschew the Notting Hill carnival for a jaunt to the west country. Poor show.

 A certain Catherine Bailey has been spotted collecting her pictures from the Tavistock branch of Snappy Snaps. Nothing wrong with that in itself, but it does seem a bit of a shame when you've gone to all the trouble of marrying David Bailey.

 While debate continues over the Pencil Museum of Keswick, a reader calls to report that, on a recent trip to Iceland, his eye was caught by an advert in What's On In Reykjavik. The Icelandic Phallological Museum, this claimed, is "a unique collection, the only one of its kind in the world, of over 60 penises and penal (sic) parts belonging to almost all the land and sea mammals that can be found in Iceland." The museum (tel: Reykjavik 588 8705) is open on Mondays, Thursdays and weekends. For parties of 25, booking is by prior arrangement.

 Many people have been in touch (none, actually) to ask how the Mr Tony Blair farce Ronan Bennett and myself are writing is coming on. Very well, thank you. Indeed, I think we have persuaded O'Mandy Mandelson to come to the first night, and the only thing left to do now is write it. There is something else. The play's producer Matthew Byam Shaw is being extremely difficult over the writers' percentages. I am therefore obliged to plug his new production, opening at the New Ambassadors (sooooo handy for the Ivy) on August 30. I saw In Flame by Charlotte Jones at the Bush Theatre in west London a while ago and oddly enough it was excellent. But that's not really the issue, is it? Go for us.

 As a new month approaches, thoughts turn to the Diary's Book of the Month for September. One title contender has to be Dr Alan O'Reilly's Britain Under Siege (Christian Concern, £3.75). After describing a bloody massacre by militants in Algeria, Dr O'Reilly writes: "Will the scenes of carnage be even worse in Britain? They will if Rome and Islam run true to form." So no wonder the English Churchman magazine describes it as "a useful and well-researched book".

fields.headline: The wild bunch
fields.standfirst: Ozzy Osbourne, Keith Moon, the Stone Roses... Britain once had the greatest rock 'n' roll hellraisers on earth. These days we get Robbie Williams showing us his underpants. What happened to music's bad boys? By  Bob Stanley
fields.trailText: It's corporate, phoney and embarrassing. But, no question, Robbie Williams believes he's holding up a grand tradition by waggling his ample butt on billboards nationwide. The notion of rock'n'roll bad boys goes back to Jerry Lee Lewis and his underage bride, or (as purists will ceaselessly remind you) Robert Johnson and Hank Williams's many misdemeanours.
fields.body:
It's corporate, phoney and embarrassing. But, no question, Robbie Williams believes he's holding up a grand tradition by waggling his ample butt on billboards nationwide. The notion of rock'n'roll bad boys goes back to Jerry Lee Lewis and his underage bride, or (as purists will ceaselessly remind you) Robert Johnson and Hank Williams's many misdemeanours.

Hellraisers of great wit and great style have always been in short supply. Eccentricity and borderline madness underscore the lives of Little Richard, PJ Proby and Keith Moon. Moon traded his working-class Wembley persona for one of a rock aristocrat after the release of Tommy in 1969 made him a wealthy man. He took to calling everyone "dear boy", influenced by the band's well-spoken manager Kit Lambert, and his fondness for the odd "drinkipoos". The drummer flew his helicopter into the grounds of Oliver Reed's house by way of introduction before they began filming Tommy together - he had a shotgun fired at him for his troubles but the two were soon inseparable.

When Keith Moon threw a television set out of the window he made sure it had a long flex so that he could see the picture just as it hit the ground. Compare this to the joyless ritual in the Rolling Stones's Cocksucker Blues film, where they wearily lug a set across the room. Raising hell to keep up appearances has become pretty much the norm. Since the Stone Roses arrogantly (but correctly) called themselves the world's greatest band in 1989, all manner of indie pretenders have misguidedly mimicked their stance. The end result was Oasis who, likewise, were gleefully lapped up as loveable scallies - as long as they were making great records. But 5.30 were among the lesser lights. Managed by New Labour pop tsar Alan McGee, they carted "Aleister Crowley's door" with them on tour and miked it up on stage for the creepy vibes. Customs officers in New York were less impressed and reduced it to matchwood in their search for "bad boy" substances.

While a professional hellraiser like Alice Cooper would lark around with dead animals on stage but secretly play golf with David Cassidy, there are genuine naïfs like Liam Gallagher and Ozzy Osbourne who live the life because that's what they'd have done whether they'd been a rocker or a brickie.

Ozzy has great pathos - on waking up in jail after unconsciously trying to kill his wife, he quizically exclaimed, "But I was in a Chinese restaurant five minutes ago." After biting the head off a live bat he needed a rabies jab - "like having a golf ball injected into your arse", he warned copycat fans.

The boorishness of Led Zeppelin or the pious behaviour of Iggy Pop (who now turns his nose up at coffee, he's so squeaky clean) is seen as acceptable, while The Fall's cantankerous Mark E Smith (beat girlfriend on stage) or Morrissey (sang about the National Front) aren't. The media loves a rock'n'roll bad guy but there are limits. Thus the end results of Keith Moon's odd genius are prefabricated naughties like East 17 and 5ive to counter Take That and Boyzone.

And of course the music industry wouldn't go anywhere near a genuine hellraiser. GG Allin began his career in a mediocre US punk group called The Jabbers. One night he was given some acid in a Dunkin' Donuts and he was transformed. As a solo act he used to crap on stage and then eat the evidence. Song titles included Bite It You Scum and Antisocial Masturbator. He never paid taxes, kept all of his belongings in a brown paper bag, smashed his teeth out with a microphone, was arrested 56 times (and frequently jailed), and appeared on Jerry Springer telling the nation that the GG Allin Army was going to bring down the government. At his last concert he played naked while the audience fed him pills - he OD'd that night. And if no US record labels will touch his back catalogue, at least his brother makes money from GG Allin dolls and umpteen bootlegs.

Scandinavian pop - The Cardigans et al - hardly prepares you for the world's most extreme hard rockers. Take Norway's Emperor. Their guitarist Samoth burnt down several 1,000-year-old wooden churches - there were only about 20 left before he started. Then there's Mayhem - the singer shot himself, the drummer wore a necklace made of skull fragments, and the guitarist Euronymous claimed to have cooked and eaten human brain. This is hard to verify as Euronymous was stabbed 23 times by Emperor's guitarist Count Grishnakh - apparently he was jealous because followers thought Euronymous was the more evil of the two.

And all we can come up with is a podgy kid on Top of the Pops in tiger Y-fronts.

 Hellraisers, tomorrow, 9pm, C4; The Real Keith Moon, tomorrow,10.15pm, C4

webTitle: Faulty landing gear blamed for crash

fields.headline: Faulty landing gear blamed for crash
fields.trailText: The Gulf Air plane which crashed off Bahrain on Wednesday was unable to lower its nose wheel for landing, sources quoted by a Bahraini newspaper claimed yesterday.
fields.byline: Brian Whitaker and  Khaled Dawoud  in Cairo
fields.body:
The Gulf Air plane which crashed off Bahrain on Wednesday was unable to lower its nose wheel for landing, sources quoted by a Bahraini newspaper claimed yesterday.

All 143 people on board - including two Britons - died as the Airbus A320 plunged into the sea after two attempts to land.

According to the sources, Captain Ihsan Shakeeb told the control tower that he could not release the front wheel, and was told to circle the airport and try again. But two further attempts failed.

Earlier, a statement by Gulf Air said: "Approximately one nautical mile from touchdown and at about 600ft [185 metres] above sea level the aircraft commenced a go-around."

It gave no reason for the decision to make a circuit.

David Learmount, a safety expert at Flight International magazine, said the statement indicated that the plane was flying too high and probably too fast for a normal landing; one mile from touchdown it should have been at 300 feet.

He said: "If the pilot was flying on purpose at 600ft, a problem with the landing gear would fit the scenario."

But he said this would not lead to an attempt to ditch the plane in the sea.

"They would lay a carpet of foam on the runway. Landing without wheels causes surprisingly little damage - planes very often fly again within six months."

Another reason for making a circuit would be that the pilot had found himself too high by accident, possibly as a result of problems with air traffic control.

A circuit involves a lot of work for the pilot, Mr Learmount said.

"You have to pull the nose up, put power on, bring the gear up and adjust the flaps. It shouldn't be a problem, but there have been quite a few examples in the last 10 years of pilots getting it wrong."

But he added: "I have no reason to conclude this was pilot error from the information available."

The names of people killed in accidents are not normally released until their families have been informed, but the Bahrain Tribune published a full list on its website yesterday while Foreign Office officials were still trying to contact relatives of one of the two Britons who died.

The two were later named as Aileen Woods, 28, a resident of Bahrain, and Christopher Keenan, who lived in Abu Dhabi.

Relatives of the 65 Egyptians killed in the crash left Cairo for Bahrain in a chartered plane yesterday to identify the bodies and bring them home for burial. Dozens of doctors and nurses and five ambulances were on hand to deal with grieving relatives, many of whom fainted or became hysterical

The bereaved women among the 135 relatives were all dressed in black. A few who were unable to walk the short distance to the aircraft were pushed in a wheelchair.

An official said there were 38 children under 12 on the ill-fated airliner.

webTitle: Third world aims a spearhead at rich club

fields.headline: Third world aims a spearhead at rich club
fields.standfirst: Caucus of key figures will look for a seat at developed world's table
fields.trailText: Key figures from the developing world gave their agreement yesterday to proposals for securing a voice in international economic forums.
fields.body:
Key figures from the developing world gave their agreement yesterday to proposals for securing a voice in international economic forums.

The meeting, in London, was the first for the coordinating group of the G77, which represents 80% of the world's population.

The group is angry at the way the developing world has been excluded from decisions taken by such organisations as the Group of Seven, which represents the wealthiest countries.

The two-day meeting was the most serious attempt by the developing world to acquire political muscle since the Non-Aligned Movement lost influence.

The main people involve were the president of Nigeria, Olusegun Obasanjo; the president of Malaysia, Mahathir Mohamad; the president of Algeria, Abdelaziz Bouteflika; the prime minister of Jamaica, James Patterson; and Cheryl Carolus, the South African high commissioner in London, representing President Thabo Mbeki.

They issued a statement expressing concern about globalisation, trade barriers biased against developing countries, the environment, and debt. The statement reinforced the necessity of becoming effectively organised.

A source close to the discussions said: "They are concerned about decisions taken by the rich club and then they have to pick up the tab."

The group of 77, which was originally 77 countries but was expanded to 133, has been largely moribund through lack of organisation. I

It carries little weight with the G7, the World Trade Organisation and the International Monetary Fund.

fields.headline: Branson the victor attacks Camelot
fields.standfirst: Special report: the lottery
fields.trailText: Sir Richard Branson yesterday took a swipe at the lack of "integrity" at national lottery operator Camelot, as he arrived back in Britain to nail down his own bid to run the lottery for the next seven years.
fields.body:
Sir Richard Branson yesterday took a swipe at the lack of "integrity" at national lottery operator Camelot, as he arrived back in Britain to nail down his own bid to run the lottery for the next seven years.

The founder of the Virgin group also extended an offer to many of Camelot's 800 staff to join his People's Lottery if, as expected, it overcomes lingering concerns of the regulator. The lottery commission has given the People's Lottery a month to allay fears over the financial stability of the company before awarding it the licence from October next year.

Sir Richard, who had been delayed from returning from a holiday on his private Caribbean island by a hurricane, said he had been confident of winning the contest because of continuing questions over the probity of GTech, the US firm which is a principal supplier to Camelot.

"There was a lack of integrity in [Camelot's] principal supplier but indirectly that reflects on Camelot and was seen by the lottery commission as one and the same thing and I think that is the right view," he said.

In its role as regulator, the commission has an continuing investigation into GTech for trying to cover up a software glitch which meant that some winners were being shortchanged over a four year period to 1998.

Sir Richard said he was certain the concerns still held by the commission could be overcome. He will meet with lottery commission chairwoman, Helena Shovelton, this afternoon to discuss the outstanding problems including the provision of an extra £50m banking facility.

The commission also wants clarification on legal issues related to payments of prize money owed should the People's Lottery go bust.

"These are relatively small issues and we feel that as long as there is nothing else ... we should be able to sort them out.

"We have spoken to our principal suppliers and they have indicated that they would be willing to deal with the issue. If there were any shortfall then yes I would cover it." The People's Lottery, he added, was fortunate in having some of the most powerful companies in the world on board as suppliers, including Microsoft and Cisco.

He said that given the short space of time between the award of the licence and the handover in October next year, the People's Lottery would set about seeking temporary offices in London and begin recruiting immediately.

"There will be staff at Camelot in need of a job and if we can help without putting our costs up then we will certainly want to look at that. Obviously the people running Camelot are in a horribly uncomfortable position. But there was always the risk that the licence wouldn't be renewed and they would have planned for that as a possibility. We are happy to have conversations with them to see if there are ways of an orderly handover and of helping people."

The Conservative party chairman, Michael Ancram, meanwhile demanded clarification from the culture secretary, Chris Smith, that he had played no part in influencing the decision to put the People's Lottery forward as the preferred bidder. The Department of Culture, Media and Sport responded with a statement saying the decision had been made "entirely and solely" by the commission.

webTitle: Analysis: being a graduate may not secure a job

fields.headline: Inflation by degrees
fields.standfirst:
Once you could expect a good job if you got some A-levels. Now, as university numbers rise, even being a graduate may not be enough
Education Unlimited
fields.trailText: As students digest their A-level and GCSE results and plan their futures, many will be left pondering what rewards their new-found qualifications will deliver. There will certainly be more jobs for highly qualified people in the future - an extra 2m over the next 10 years according to new projections by the Institute for Employment Research. The trouble is, there are expected to be at least 2.2m more graduates.
fields.body:
As students digest their A-level and GCSE results and plan their futures, many will be left pondering what rewards their new-found qualifications will deliver. There will certainly be more jobs for highly qualified people in the future - an extra 2m over the next 10 years according to new projections by the Institute for Employment Research. The trouble is, there are expected to be at least 2.2m more graduates.

Thirty or 40 years ago, gaining some A-levels gave you a good chance of a decent job; a degree gave you hope of an even better one. Things have changed. With participation in higher education double what it was only 10 years ago, having a degree is increasingly becoming a necessity rather than a bonus.

Gaining an A-level qualification still increases your chances of commanding a higher salary - around 18% higher than someone with GCSEs only. For women, the pay bonus attached to having A-levels is even greater (although pay levels for women still lag behind men's). But A-levels are no longer sufficient to gain a professional, managerial or even administrative job; a degree is rapidly becoming a standard requirement.

The pace of change is accelerating. Twenty years ago, just one in eight corporate administrators were graduates. Today, it is around a third, and by 2009 it is projected to be more than two-fifths. Just one in 20 buyers, brokers and sales reps were graduates in 1981, but by 2009 it will be one in seven. A third of managers are expected to be graduates by the end of the decade.

Having a degree matters more than the type of degree you have. Qualifications are still primarily a way for employers to see who the brightest people are, rather than evidence of specific skills. Employers are increasingly demanding more generalised skills in the workplace, with greater emphasis being put on communication, IT and problem-solving skills, but there is still little evidence of the new vocational degree courses - such as business and management studies - being seen as reflecting these new skills.

Holding a traditional degree is still seen by employers as a proxy for generic skills: the ability to learn, to lead a team and negotiate. If anything, it is science and engi neering graduates who are in shortest supply and have been seeing the biggest pay rises in recent years, but this is more to do with the demand for high-level numeracy skills than a shortage of scientists and engineers. Arts and humanities graduates tend to earn less than people from courses such as law, medicine, maths and computing, at least in their first job, but these differences are dwarfed by the gap between the lifetime earnings of graduates and non-graduates.

The projections for the oversupply of graduates could turn out to be an underestimate. The government's public-service agreement targets, released with last month's spending review, include increasing participation in higher education "towards 50% of those aged 18-30 by the end of the decade". The 2.2m figure assumes the current level of one-third, so the true figure could end up significantly higher. Even without allowing for this extra increase, by 2009 30% of the entire workforce will have qualifications to at least "level 4" - which includes higher education diplomas and vocational courses like HNDs and BTEC. A-levels count as level 3; a degree, teaching or nursing qualification as level 5.

More and more graduates may have to settle for jobs outside the traditional graduate sector. And it is outside the graduate sector that job growth will be much slower. The number of skilled trade jobs is expected to fall by 270,000 over the next decade. The number of administrative and clerical jobs will shrink too. However, there will be strong growth in job opportunities on the fringes of the professions.

More than 800,000 new jobs will be in what are called "associate professional and technical" occupations. This means people like physiotherapists and radiographers instead of doctors; financial analysts and tax advisers instead of accountants; welfare officers instead of qualified social workers. It also includes technicians and specialists in areas like IT and engineering.

If all else fails, graduates might consider sticking to their holiday jobs. There is predicted to be significant growth in part-time jobs during the next 10 years. And the personal service sector is booming: there will be nearly half a million more jobs in this area by the end of the decade. Students might increasingly find themselves having to rely on their temporary catering and bar jobs for longer than they expected.

Access to higher education will become increasingly important in the future. With wage differentials between the top and bottom rising, and with most of the training at work going to people who already have qualifications, the price of missing out will become ever higher.

For those who do get in, a degree is no longer a passport to a top job, but it will at least be a way into a much-expanded range of white-collar jobs, including many that were not around when their parents left school.

Nick Burkitt is researcher on the future of work at the Institute for Public Policy Research.

webTitle: Where horse is harnessed à la carte

fields.headline: Where horse is harnessed à la carte
fields.trailText: Without a smattering of French you might miss the significance of one of the  specialités de maison listed on the blackboard outside Le Tigre et la Grenouille, the only French restaurant on Bethnal Green Road in east London:  Steak de Cheval po le Marchand de Vins .
fields.body:
Without a smattering of French you might miss the significance of one of the specialités de maison listed on the blackboard outside Le Tigre et la Grenouille, the only French restaurant on Bethnal Green Road in east London: Steak de Cheval po le Marchand de Vins .

Xavier Claustres, proud patron of Le Tigre et la Grenouille (the Tiger and the Frog), which claims to be the only restaurant in Britain with horse on the menu, explained the absence of a translation: "Those with the rudiments of a second language tend to be a little more open minded than the mob."

With such free-thinking gastronomes in mind, the restaurant began serving horse in May to those customers willing to sample a meat that has been taboo in Britain since before the second world war.

Mr Claustres and his chef, Konor Miah, whose Bangladeshi heritage accounts for the tiger, are convinced that the quality of the meat will overcome British squeamishness when it comes to eating pets.

"It is a terrifically lean meat, very rich in glucose and iron which gives it flavour, and very tender," said Mr Claustres. "It has been most popular. People who are a little adventurous, who want to try something new, try it and they never complain."

A fillet, pan-fried in a shallot and red wine sauce, served very rare and accompanied by roast potatoes and courgettes was tender, tasty and similar in texture and flavour to beef, if a little less rich.

The meat, said Mr Claustres, was of the highest quality. "I get my horse from a butcher in Brittany - the last horse butcher in Britain closed in 1938 so I have no choice. My butcher breeds, rears and slaughters his own horses so they are free range. They have not travelled halfway across the continent in a crate as some other meat does."

The British attitude to horse meat is at odds with much of continental Europe. In Belgium, Germany, Russia and France, horse is eaten.

"I was brought up eating horse sausages and mince by my mother but many French people have never tried it," Mr Claustres said. "The market has become a niche because, since Napoleonic times, the horse butcher has been completely separate from other butchers."

Pet food aside, there is a thriving horse meat export market in Britain, with a dozen horse abattoirs, and British horses find their way to dinner tables across Europe.

There are no specific restrictions on the sale of horse meat and, according to the Ministry of Agriculture, Food and Fisheries, there never have been. Despite this Mr Claustres does not expect the meat to appear on supermarket shelves.

He said: "I doubt it will catch on hugely _ Even if one of the big guys, an Antony Worrall Thompson or such like, put horse on the menu it might become popular briefly, but it would have to overcome a cultural taboo to make it a great success."

Mark Askew, head chef at Gordon Ramsay, in Chelsea, west London, cannot see that happening: "We've never used it and I don't think we would - bit of a touchy subject isn't it? I don't even think it's that popular in France."

 One of Scotland's most infamous delicacies has made its way on to the dessert menu at an upmarket restaurant in Edinburgh. To gourmets dining at the Channings restaurant it has become part of the "assiette of chocolate" array of delicacies. But it tastes suspiciously like a deep-fried Mars bar.

The restaurant's head chief, Richard Glennie, said: "It started out as a bit of fun when I made the dessert for a Burns supper we held earlier this year. We served the Mars bar with a sorbet of Irn-Bru and to our surprise the dish was a huge success."

Chew over these

Ostrich
Hailed as a low-cholesterol alternative to beef after the BSE crisis in 1996, investors plunged into ostrich farming, supermarkets stocked up, and British Airways put the ostrich on in-flight menus. In three years the public had deserted the fad, and Waitrose, Asda and Sainsbury's withdrew the bird last year.

Crocodile
A meat with a similar short-lived popularity - Sainsbury's withdrew it in 1998. Imports of kangaroo meat met with opposition from vegetarian campaigners but it remained on Sainsbury's shelves until January1999.

Wild boar
British game is enjoying a revival. The wild boar industry, traditionally associated with Belgian cuisine, is now worth £1m a year, with boar farmers claiming the demand comes from supermarkets.

Rodents
The capybara, the world's largest rodent, is considered a low fat alternative to beef in Venezuela - where, in order to avoid a ban on meat at Lent, it was declared a fish by the Catholic Church.

Scorpions
The Birdcage, a London restaurant, has chocolate-coated scorpions, worms and crickets on the menu.

fields.headline: The Guzzler
fields.trailText: Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15
fields.body:
Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Pierre Victoire, 90-92 Regent Street, Cambridge. Tel: 01223 570170

A phoenix from the ashes of receivership. Pierre Victoire was the cheaper-than-cheap chain of franchises, but didn't quite manage the bottom line as well as it did the food. Now back in Cambridge (and elsewhere, including St Albans, Bath and York). The formula remains the same: decent French grub - steak, saucisses, mussels, roast chicken, salmon and dill beignets, and frites with everything - £4.95 for a two-course lunch and the rest. But there are changes. It's much smarter, no longer folksy. Worth going the extra yard along Regent Street to eat there.

Quick bites... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Bar Moosh, 1-3 Station Road, Cambridge. Tel: 01223 360268

Moosh is in a little run of eateries near the station. Large and cheerfully ramshackle, it throbs with world music. A long list of cocktails (£4 to £5). Fashionable mass market beers on tap, Courage Directors on the hand pump and a wine list that is more than a gesture. Serious cheeses signal gastro-intent. There's substantial grub too: brioches stuffed with cheese or wild mushrooms; fresh mussels with parsley, garlic and chilli or ginger coriander and saffron; big salads. And spotted dick and treacle roly poly with custard among the puds. Probably take you past the 15 minute mark, though.

On the menu: halloumi

Or haloumi or halloumy.

Get on with it. What is it?
A cheese.

Made with sheep's, goats' or cows' milk?
It was originally produced using sheep's or goats', but now it is usually cows'. From Cyprus, Romania or the Lebanon.

Taste?
Not much. Fresh, let's say.

Texture?
Fibrous and rubbery.

Doesn't sound very appealing. What do we do with it?
Fry, grill or barbecue.

And that's why it's creeping up the menu stakes?
Halloumi is cheap, easy and forgiving - the chef's choice for the vegetarian option.

Just out

Knorr New World Sauces

Form: Coloured gloops in pouches. The New World turns out to be South Africa. Four cook-in variations on a curry theme and one non-curry - Kwazulu Pineapple and Red Pepper, Spicy Durban, Cape Malay, Franschoek Fruity and Karoo Tomato Bredie.

Flavour: Most of the spicy subtlety is lost among the stabilisers, flavour enhancers and general goo.

Verdict: There are far better curry pouches (eg Tamarind). Best: Cape Malay. Worst: Karoo Tomato Bredie.

Price: About £1.49 per 500g pouch.

fields.headline: Wedding seen abroad on internet
fields.standfirst: Net news
fields.trailText: A couple yesterday shared their London register office wedding ceremony with relatives and friends around the world, by means of the internet.
fields.body:
A couple yesterday shared their London register office wedding ceremony with relatives and friends around the world, by means of the internet.

In a first for the registry at Brent town hall in north London, Ravi Ram, 38, and Mamta Patel, 24, paid £37.50 for a 15-minute ceremony that was viewed via the internet by Mr Ram's sister, Doorga, a student in Mauritius. And Miss Patel said friends in the US were also watching online. "It was nice for people who could not get here," she said.

The couple, who had 30 conventional guests, will also have a Hindu wedding in Wembley at the weekend. They are both from Harrow, and met while working at a private residential home.

Brent's chief registrar, Mark Rimmer, who conducted the ceremony, said: "I expect this will be extremely popular, particularly as it will be at no cost to the couple."

Whenever a couple ask, the register office's webcam will be switched on; anyone can log on to future weddings at The brent council website

webTitle: Soldier of fortune digs back to 1800

fields.headline: Soldier of fortune digs back to 1800
fields.trailText: An antiques dealer from Arizona is to dig in a Swansea park for treasure he knows he buried in a previous life 200 years ago but cannot remember where.
fields.body:
An antiques dealer from Arizona is to dig in a Swansea park for treasure he knows he buried in a previous life 200 years ago but cannot remember where.

Jim Bethe, 58, says he has discovered through regression therapy that he had been there before as a Welsh soldier who had an active military career before dying on the battlefield at Waterloo in 1815.

He is now in Scotland having scenes from his previous existence recreated on film. But he will soon be heading for Singleton Park in Swansea, armed with a shovel and the conviction that his case is one of the best potential proofs of the possibility of reincarnation.

"We have been approached on the possibility of some previously buried artefacts being recovered," said a city council spokeswoman as if this sort of thing happened every day.

"The dig will cover approximately four square metres in a park of 131 acres and the site will be reinstated once the dig has concluded."

Mr Bethe believes he was previously John Seaman, born somewhere in Britain in 1779. Twenty years later, he was involved in a fierce battle in India during which he raided the palace of the Sultan of Tippoo.

He stole a casket packed with jewels. He killed two guards but was stabbed in the back. (Mr Bethe bears on his back a birthmark which conforms to a scar made by a sword.)

Mr Seaman came home to Swansea, hid his loot, and married Mary Merton in 1804 or 1805. Mary died in childbirth and their only child was killed by lightning at the age of five.

Seaman went back to India, was recognised in Poonah as a thief, set upon and left for dead. But he survived, went back to Europe and died in Wellington's army, says Mr Bethe.

"Mr Bethe first made contact with us in 1989," said Malcolm Ridge, chairman of the Gower Society, a local conservation and history group. "He said someone from his family had lived in the area 200 years ago and asked whether we could help.

"We corresponded and then he said he had something to confess. 'This relative is me in a former life,' he said. Which was something of a surprise."

With the help of a Welsh diviner, Mr Bethe located a site in Clyne Park in Swansea, began digging and found the remains of a building. It turned out to be the cesspit of a Victorian castle built some years after Seaman died.

Undaunted, he tried to persuade Steven Spielberg to film his story, which has now been taken up by the Manchester-based production company Activmedia.

"I approach this from a cynical standpoint," said the director, Simon Westland. "It's easy not to believe but there is some very compelling evidence to show that Jim is genuine. We are trying to pin down the historical facts to give the story more credibility."

Mr Seaman was unavailable for comment last night.

fields.headline: No: 1707 Kelly Brook
fields.body:
Age: 20

Status: Glamour model turned TV host turned occasional actress.

Ah, yes. The erstwhile presenter of Channel 4's Big Breakfast. Haven't seen her around for a while. What's she up to these days? Kelly was spotted in all her glory this week at the British premier of Snatch, the new gangster film directed by Guy Ritchie.

Friends in high places has she? Her boyfriend, Jason Statham, appears in the film but could not make the premiere because he was working in Mexico.

Bummer. Funny you should say that. That's exactly what drew attention to young Kel at the Leicester Square do.

How so? She turned up in a dress designed by Julien Macdonald that was backless, sideless and almost frontless.

Gosh! So short was the little pink sequinned number that at the back she displayed a large proportion of her posterior, and at the front she showed off her matching micro-knickers. "Jason was really hoping to come," she said, "So I said I would make it up to him and wear next to nothing. My friends said they didn't think I had the guts to wear this dress - but I have."

How did she look? A little shaky actually.

Cold, was she? No

Nervous, perhaps? Apparently not. "It's fantastic to be here," she gasped, "I'm shaking because I am so excited."

How did the onlookers react? Well, there were signs of rioting but that was probably more to do with the appearance of lead star Brad Pitt who almost got arrested for inciting the crowds.

And the media? Let's just say that in the midst of all the publicity hungry stars, she would definitely be the one holding the trump card up her sleeve.

If she had any. Precisely.

Do say: "Less is More."

Don't say: "It's a bum deal."

Not to be confused with: Elizabeth Hurley.

fields.headline: Lord Vernon
fields.standfirst: An ancient peer embracing modern causes
fields.trailText: The 10th Baron Vernon, who has died aged 77, was a very deviant hereditary peer. He was a liberal pro- European, supported abortion and opposed apartheid. Of his 22 votes in the Lords in 1984-85, 21 were against the Thatcher government. He was also one of the first ex-Tory peers to join the Social Democratic Party.
fields.body:
The 10th Baron Vernon, who has died aged 77, was a very deviant hereditary peer. He was a liberal pro- European, supported abortion and opposed apartheid. Of his 22 votes in the Lords in 1984-85, 21 were against the Thatcher government. He was also one of the first ex-Tory peers to join the Social Democratic Party.

Given his background, his views were all the more striking. He was born in a stately home - Sudbury Hall, in Derbyshire - to an aristocratic family that stretched back to the Norman conquest. He had the education (Eton and Magdalen College, Oxford), war experience (captain in the Scots Guards) and occupations (M15 and Colonial Office) that should have guaranteed his status.

But from his maiden speech in the House of Lords - on Africa in 1965 - Vernon showed a combination of liberalism and hard-headed realism. He hated apartheid, but feared economic sanctions would not work. His solution was to divide South Africa between whites and blacks with a fair distribution of its wealth. He was similarly realistic about dealing with Rhodesia, ridiculing nominal sanctions against a regime backed by South Africa, while accepting that military action by Britain was unrealistic.

In 1967, his strong support for David Steel's abortion bill again set him aside from his Conservative colleagues. He showed particular concern that rich people could readily have safe, if illegal, abortions, while poor women had to take the risk of backstreet ones.

Vernon was also concerned about over-population, particularly in Africa, which he had come to know during his time with the Colonial Office. In 1980, he proposed that development aid should be coupled to population control. In 1985, he urged that £1m of the £50m raised by Live Aid be devoted to birth control. He followed this up by becoming chairman of Population Concern, from 1984 to 1989, supporting birth control overseas.

The only area in which Vernon remained traditionally conservative was in his hostility to the National Trust experts who insisted on restoring Sudbury Hall to its original, mid-17th century colouring, ignoring its evolution as his family home. In 1971, he accused the trust of being "too ready to destroy the character of houses built up over the centuries".

Vernon could have been excused for having special memories of the place. He was looked after there for his first eight years by his nanny, rather than by his father, the 9th baron, or his mother, Violet. At eight, he was sent off to prep school and Eton. When he inherited in 1963, he found that the farming estate could not pay the hall's upkeep, so he offered it to the National Trust, and moved into a smaller house nearby.

Although he continued to manage the estate with sensitivity, this was not what he had trained for, nor was it his main interest. After war service, he had studied for the bar at Lincoln's Inn, but went into M15 (1950-55) before being seconded to the Cabinet Office and then the Colonial Office until 1961, serving first in Kenya, probably as an intelligence officer. For British intelligence operatives, the key question was whether Britain could keep African nationalists on side sufficiently to keep them out of Soviet hands.

Vernon's appreciation of the African scene was such that he saw decolonisation as inevitable. He co-founded the insightful African Newsletter, and also Soviet Analysis.

He is survived by his second wife, Sally, and by a daughter from his first marriage to Sheila. Their other daughter, the novelist Frances Vernon, died in 1991.

 John Lawrance Vernon, 10th Baron Vernon, born February 1 1923; died August 19 2000

webTitle: Jakarta-backed militias continue to terrorise East Timorese

fields.headline: 'We are simple people who want to go home'
fields.standfirst:
Jakarta-backed militias continue to terrorise East Timorese, holding refugees hostage
Special report: Indonesia and East Timor
fields.trailText: Marietta Soares did not have to speak to show that she was afraid of being caught talking to a white man. Continually glancing around, she was shaking as she described her family's plight, effectively held hostage for the past 11 months in a squalid refugee camp just inside Indonesian West Timor.
fields.body:
Marietta Soares did not have to speak to show that she was afraid of being caught talking to a white man. Continually glancing around, she was shaking as she described her family's plight, effectively held hostage for the past 11 months in a squalid refugee camp just inside Indonesian West Timor.

"My three children and I get enough food for three helpings of rice each a day," she said. "Occasionally we get a few vegetables or some dried fish, but they don't allow us go out to find our own food. We can only do what they let us and we rarely get any news except what they tell us.

"We really want to go home to East Timor, but it is impossible. They will beat us or maybe even kill us if we try. Even talking to you risks punishment."

"They" are the militia, a mixture of East Timorese paramilitaries who support the Indonesian government in Jakarta, West Timorese thugs, and current and former members of the Indonesian armed forces. Feeling angry and betrayed by East Timor's overwhelming vote for independence last August after 25 years of Indonesian occupation, they are fighting a desperate campaign to try to reverse their defeat.

Their aim is to win the right to create an Indonesian region in western East Timor. There is a political wing, the Heroes of Timorese Unity, which denies the militia existence and stresses that its campaign is a purely peaceful one.

Their strategy is two pronged. The first is to use the remaining 130,000 of the refugees who fled militia violence in East Timor last year as a bargaining chip by preventing them returning to East Timor or - as tens of thousands wish to, building a new life in Indonesia.

This is done by brute force and a skillful disinformation campaign, telling them that East Timor is so unsafe that people are flooding back to West Timor. While the forces of law and order in East Timor are far from complete, the territory is calm.

The second part of the strategy involves fighting a guerrilla war in western East Timor against the international peacekeeping force.

UN officials attacked

"It took about six months for the militia and their army backers to regroup and plan a new strategy," said one of the few international aid workers still in Atambua, the town about five miles from the border where most of the refugee camps are located.

"During this time about 150,000 refugees returned to East Timor. But since April the militia have been escalating their campaign of terror and intimidation against both the refugees and the United Nations."

This reached a new peak on Tuesday when, during a visit to what was considered to be one of the safest camps in West Timor,representatives of the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) were deliberately attacked for the first time. All three were beaten so badly that they needed hospital treatment and one, a local man called Gotlief, was lucky to escape with his life.

"At one point a group of about a dozen were hitting me with sticks and throwing stones at me as I was lying on the ground," he said.

"Then I heard one of them speaking my own local language so I shouted back that I am from the same small island as him and he ordered them to stop attacking me. If he had not done so, I would have been killed."

As a result of the attack, the UNHCR has decided to suspend its operations in West Timor. "We've been pushing for improved security since October but none of our demands have been met," said Jake Morland, the UNHCR spokesman in West Timor.

"The actions of the army and police amount to peanuts. They allow the militia to act with impunity and have not bothered to disarm the militias or arrest those responsible for the terror, intimidation and beatings."

Two recent incidents exemplify the Indonesian army's attitude to the militia and the UNHCR. A day after seizing about a dozen semi-automatic rifles in a sweep of refugee camps around Atambua earlier this month, the army returned the weapons. The commander said he was afraid there would be a riot if he did not give them back.

His counterpart in Kefamenanu, a town 55 miles west of Atambua, said this week that the UNHCR would only be allowed to keep vehicles on his base, as a security precaution, if they paid him rent for the parking spaces.

The armed forces have made no concerted effort to stop the militiamen blocking the main road from Atambua to the East Timorese border.

These barricades have been erected not only to stop the refugees sneaking back home, but also to starve the East Timorese into yielding to the militia's demands, according to a militiaman armed with a machete on one roadblock.

"[East Timorese leader] Xanana [Gusmao] said he would be happy to be independent even if he has to eat stones," he said. "Well, let's see how they feel when we force them to really eat stones and drink their own piss."

The militia's guerrilla war in East Timor began in April with short, sharp hit-and-run raids on communities just across the border. Now their its involve sending squads of well-armed and well-trained fighters deeper into the territory. At least eight are known to be operating at the moment, some as far as 60 miles into East Timor.

Bitter fruit of darkness

"The ones in our area are like Japanese ninjas," UN soldier in East Timor said. "They are dressed all in black with white neckscarves. They carry modern weapons and lots of ammunition."

So far the militia squads have not singled out civilians, except for food, and have killed only two international peacekeepers. But they have caused fear in many communities.

It is unclear who is leading the militia. Diplomatic sources in Jakarta say they have accumulated conclusive evidence that several elements of the Indonesian army,particularly the special forces, are the driving force behind the campaign.

The UN administrator in East Timor, Sergio Vieria de Mello, says he is confident that the threat will not last long. "They are and will be made ever more irrelevant here and in Indonesia," he told local politicians this week. "They belong to the past when irrational violence and force of weapons, not arguments, prevailed. They were the bitter fruit of darkness, and they shall return to it."

But feelings in West Timor are more sombre. "Unless the Indonesian government shows serious political will, the refugees could be stuck here for at least another year," Mr Morland said.

The Indonesian deputy foreign minister, Hassan Wirajuda, admits there is a crisis but says it is very difficult to solve. "This is not just a simple case of dealing with a few thugs," he said during a tour of East and West Timor this week. "It is a complex problem involving many social issues, so what we need is a comprehensive solution."

He proposes to greatly increase the number of Indonesian security troops in the border region to deal with the militia threat,close the camps, and put the refugees into transit centres for eventual return to East Timor or settlement in in Indonesia, according to their wishes.

"Our problem is that we do not have enough resources and so we are appealing to the international community for help," he said.

But the international community is not backing the plan as it stands. "If they close the camps forcibly, against the wishes of the refugees, it could be catastrophic," Mr Morland said.

Meanwhile' tens of thousands of innocent victims like Marietta Soares continue to suffer.

"We aren't politicians," she said. "We are just simple people who want to go home."

If he had not done so, I would have been killed." As a result of the attack, the UNHCR has decided to suspend its operations in West Timor. "We've been pushing for improved security since October but none of our demands have been met," said Jake Morland, the UNHCR spokesman in West Timor. "The actions of the army and police amount to peanuts. They allow the militia to act with impunity and have not bothered to disarm the militias or arrest those responsible for the terror, intimidation and beatings." Two recent incidents exemplify the Indonesian army's attitude to the militia and the UNHCR. A day after seizing about a dozen semi-automatic rifles in a sweep of refugee camps around Atambua earlier this month, the army returned the weapons. The commander said he was afraid there would be a riot if he did not give them back. His counterpart in Kefamenanu, a town 55 miles west of Atambua, said this week that the UNHCR would only be allowed to keep vehicles on his base, as a security precaution, if they paid him rent for the parking spaces. The armed forces have made no concerted effort to stop the militiamen blocking the main road from Atambua to the East Timorese border. These barricades have been erected not only to stop the refugees sneaking back home, but also to starve the East Timorese into yielding to the militia's demands, according to a militiaman armed with a machete on one roadblock. "[East Timorese leader] Xanana [Gusmao] said he would be happy to be independent even if he has to eat stones," he said. "Well, let's see how they feel when we force them to really eat stones and drink their own piss." The militia's guerrilla war in East Timor began in April with short, sharp hit-and-run raids on communities just across the border. Now their its involve sending squads of well-armed and well-trained fighters deeper into the territory. At least eight are known to be operating at the moment, some as far as 60 miles into East Timor. Bitter fruit of darkness "The ones in our area are like Japanese ninjas," UN soldier in East Timor said. "They are dressed all in black with white neckscarves. They carry modern weapons and lots of ammunition." So far the militia squads have not singled out civilians, except for food, and have killed only two international peacekeepers. But they have caused fear in many communities. It is unclear who is leading the militia. Diplomatic sources in Jakarta say they have accumulated conclusive evidence that several elements of the Indonesian army,particularly the special forces, are the driving force behind the campaign. The UN administrator in East Timor, Sergio Vieria de Mello, says he is confident that the threat will not last long. "They are and will be made ever more irrelevant here and in Indonesia," he told local politicians this week. "They belong to the past when irrational violence and force of weapons, not arguments, prevailed. They were the bitter fruit of darkness, and they shall return to it." But feelings in West Timor are more sombre. "Unless the Indonesian government shows serious political will, the refugees could be stuck here for at least another year," Mr Morland said. The Indonesian deputy foreign minister, Hassan Wirajuda, admits there is a crisis but says it is very difficult to solve. "This is not just a simple case of dealing with a few thugs," he said during a tour of East and West Timor this week. "It is a complex problem involving many social issues, so what we need is a comprehensive solution." He proposes to greatly increase the number of Indonesian security troops in the border region to deal with the militia threat,close the camps, and put the refugees into transit centres for eventual return to East Timor or settlement in in Indonesia, according to their wishes. "Our problem is that we do not have enough resources and so we are appealing to the international community for help," he said. But the international community is not backing the plan as it stands. "If they close the camps forcibly, against the wishes of the refugees, it could be catastrophic," Mr Morland said. Meanwhile' tens of thousands of innocent victims like Marietta Soares continue to suffer. "We aren't politicians," she said. "We are just simple people who want to go home."

fields.headline: Rabbi Henoch Padwa
fields.standfirst: Talmudic scholar whose spiritual leadership guided Britain's Orthodox Jews
fields.trailText: For nearly 50 years, Rabbi Henoch Dov Padwa, who has died aged 91, led the Union of Orthodox Hebrew Congregations in London with firmness and a keen sense of humour.
fields.body:
For nearly 50 years, Rabbi Henoch Dov Padwa, who has died aged 91, led the Union of Orthodox Hebrew Congregations in London with firmness and a keen sense of humour.

At a time when ultra-orthodoxy in Judaism was under scrutiny and attack both in Israel and Britain, he saw the union grow in strength, and become a formidable force with numerous institutions. His spiritual leadership was effective because he was among the world's outstanding Talmudic scholars, and a man to whom even well-known rabbis deferred.

While secular and less observant Jews might see the way of life of the ultra- orthodoxy as narrow and closed, Padwa saw it as rich and ennobling. Intense study of the Torah, the sacred law, the Talmud and the commentaries were seen by him, his followers and congregations as the foremost aim of life.

Union congregations in north London venerated this gentle, white-haired rabbi, and readily accepted his decisions. He was dismissive of some modern inventions, worried that they might prove a source of corruption. Thus, while radio was tolerated, he banned the use of videos. In a letter to the community, he wrote: "There is no estimating the danger caused to godliness, and the education of boys and girls, by having a video recorder in the home. This is an opening for sinning and the destruction of humanity and modesty." In an age when celebrations tended to be exorbitant, he exhorted his community to "act modestly", and always to emphasise the spiritual side of any gathering.

Padwa was born in Busk, Galicia, which is now in Ukraine. As a boy, he was taken by his parents to Vienna, and later studied at talmudical seminaries in Hungary and Poland. He returned to Vienna to head a congregation but, when the Germans annexed Austria in 1938, he was arrested as an alien and imprisoned. On being released, he just managed to board the very last ship bound for Palestine - it was literally leaving the harbour as he arrived, and he had to be rushed to the ship by a small boat.

In Jerusalem, Padwa's stature as a scholar and leader was quickly recognised by the Charedi ultra-orthodox community. He was made a dayan (or judge) of the Broder synagogue and given jurisdiction over a number of institutions. When the Arab-Israel war broke out in 1948, he remained in Jerusalem during the Jordanian siege of the Old City.

Padwa was to have an influential voice in the affairs of the ultra-orthodox communi ties of the new state of Israel. Large number of rabbis had died in the Holocaust, and men of his standing were eagerly sought. Great ultra-orthodox congregations had been destroyed in Europe, and Padwa was among those who were determined to ensure that new, dedicated communities would arise, and that there would be young people to carry on the traditions of learning and piety.

In 1955, Padwa was invited to become principal rabbinical authority of the Union of Orthodox Hebrew Congregations in London, at a time when the union needed a man who was both an outstanding scholar and a leader. Significantly, it was to Padwa that Chief Rabbi Dr Jonathan Sacks addressed, in January 1997, his controversial letter sharply criticising the religious beliefs of the leading reform rabbi, Hugo Gryn, who had just died. The letter led to a major dispute among the Jewish communities in Britain.

Padwa, who was buried in Jerusalem, is survived by his third wife, Reisel, three sons and two daughters. His successor as the head of the union is his son, Rabbi Elrayim Padwa.

 Henoch Dov Padwa, rabbi, born August 17 1908; died August 16 2000
