fields.headline: Leaves on the line
fields.standfirst: For the people of Bolivia, coca is a sacred plant, a traditional medicine and a source of income. For the US government, it is evil, to be eradicated at any cost. And as American-funded troops burn their way through tonnes of this year's crop, the farmers are complaining of 'cultural genocide'.
fields.trailText: For the people of Bolivia, coca is a sacred plant, a traditional medicine and a source of income. For the US government, it is evil, to be eradicated at any cost. And as American-funded troops burn their way through tonnes of this year's crop, the farmers are complaining of 'cultural genocide'.
fields.body:
Zenon Cruz bites another coca leaf from its stem, tongues it into the wad already bulging in his cheek and scowls up at the army helicopter hovering above the jungle canopy. "My father sowed coca and his father sowed it before him," mutters the peasant farmer, his teeth stained green. "What the Americans do not understand is that this leaf is a gift from mother earth to our people, an ancient tradition. They do not understand its sacredness. They think it is all about drugs."

Like the majority of campesinos gathered at this roadside protest in the tropical Chapare region of Bolivia, 29-year-old Cruz has watched a US-backed eradication squad hack away his entire crop and his main source of income.

Last year alone, the soldiers destroyed a record 17,000 hectares in the region and by the end of this year aim to finish off the remaining 3,000, in a drive to strangle the US drugs problem at source.

The Bolivian government, under huge funding incentives from the US (it must be seen to be meeting drug eradication targets to qualify for development aid), calls the strategy Operation Dignity. Cruz and his struggling fellow farmers call it cultural genocide.

Andean peoples were using this hardy plant for a variety of ritual and health purposes for thousands of years before white men first learned to extract cocaine from it. Rich in vitamins and minerals, the leaves have traditionally been used to treat ailments ranging from dysentery to altitude sickness. The vast majority of Bolivians still chew them daily, mixing them with ash to create an anaesthetic effect on the stomach to ward off hunger. Death, marriage, and almost any other social or religious ritual here will include an offering of coca.

"Guard its leaves with love," warns Legend of Coca, the 800-year-old oral poem. "And when you feel pain in your heart, hunger in your flesh and darkness in your mind, lift it to your mouth. You will find love for your pain, nourishment for your body and light for your mind."

But the seers also foretold that white man would find a way to subvert their "small but strong" plant: "If your oppressor arrives from the north, the white conqueror, the gold seeker, when he touches it he will find only poison for his body and madness for the mind."

What the seers did not predict was the scale of the backlash. White man duly succeeded in extracting the 0.5% alkaloid cocaine from the coca leaf at the end of the 19th century - Dr Sigmund Freud become the first to contract nasal cancer from snorting it - and all hell broke loose.

Eradication attempts first began in 1949 after a study by a North American banker, Howard Fonda, claimed that the chewing of the plant was "responsible for mental deficiency and poverty in Andean countries". Soon afterwards, in 1961, the United Nations placed coca on schedule one, branding it one of the most dangerous and restricted drugs. Of course, this had no effect on US cocaine use, as executives snorted lines while the ghettos opted for its cheaper and more dangerous relative, crack. By the 80s, more than half the world's cocaine was being consumed by the superpower, which has just 5% of the global population. Bolivia, one of the world's poorest nations, saw an opening in the market and filled it. It was to become the world's second largest producer of coca and cocaine paste.

Now, under the concerted eradication first initiated by Ronald Reagan in his war on drugs, it is payback time. Bolivia is being punished for its recent complicity with the destruction of its ancient culture.

Not without a fight, however. "Go home Yankees!" shouts a furious Quechua woman in a bright shawl and bowler hat, marching with hundreds of others under banners calling for farmers' human rights to be respected. The helicopter keeps its distance, and the DEA officials rarely show their faces outside the confines of the nearby army base.

Zenon Cruz denies supplying the drug barons with his coca, but admits there were plenty who did. At the height of the trade, light aircraft landed regularly on these roads to pick up consignments. "But they are punishing us all - legal and illegal together - and everyone is struggling," he says.

Coca, a hardy plant ideally suited to tired or eroded soil, could produce three or four harvests a year. Now forced to grow beans and oranges instead, as part of a US-funded "alternative development" plan, Zenon must feed his family on a fraction of his former income. "You can fill a lorry with oranges and not sell any of them at market, but coca always sells like hot bread," he says. "I was making 150 bolivianos [about £20] a week before they cut down the coca. Now we sometimes struggle to make 20 [£3]. How can you feed a family on that?"

Other families still risk everything for a higher income. A few miles down the road, at the military base in Chimore, a 16-year-old local girl is being paraded before the press. Alcira Marin has just cracked after three days of interrogation and admitted to smuggling coca paste inside her body. The evidence lies in 40 pellets wrapped in yellowed clingfilm, on a table beside her. "I was paid 300 bolivianos [£40] to do it," she mumbles. "I didn't know I would die if one broke inside me." Under the country's harsh and US-influenced Law 1008, she faces between five and eight years in prison.

Later, in thick jungle barely 10 minutes walk from the main trunk road, Captain Luis Castro, of Bolivia's elite US-funded counter-narcotics police force, Umopar, shows me a cocaine pit his patrol have discovered this morning. In a six-metre polythene trough, heaps of fresh coca leaves lie half-trodden into greenish pulp, while older, browner leaves are piled a metre high at the edge of the jungle clearing. The workers, whoever they were, have disappeared, probably warned by two-way radio. "Burn it!" says Castro to his khaki-clad men, who begin scooping gasoline from a plastic separation tank hung between stakes.

"Judging by the amount of used coca here, I'd say they were working constantly for about three months," he tells me. Typically, eight men would stomp around this trough for 12 hours to turn more than 350kg of leaves, mixed with kerosene, into 1kg of pastabase, the crude paste from which cocaine must in turn be refined. Most would expect to earn up to £3 an hour, which is certainly tempting when you compare it with £3 a week for growing oranges.

At an order from Castro, a man pulls the pin on an incendiary bomb and tosses it into the centre of the pit, sending flames and smoke billowing upwards towards the jungle canopy. "We use their own gasoline to put them out of business," says Castro, whose cohorts have destroyed 275 similar pits in the first six months of this year alone. "We're not going to lose to the drugs people."

There is no doubt that the net is tightening, but the effect may simply be to drive up prices and encourage new markets elsewhere. Anti-drugs police estimate that the little more than three tons of pastabase will leave the Chapare this year, but this alone will generate some $4m, thanks to a 300% price increase over the last three years. Critics of the eradication policy argue that it will simply drive producers further into the Bolivian Amazon region, or elsewhere in South America where an estimated 2.5m square miles lie ripe for production.

"It's simply the law of supply and demand," says Kathryn Ledebur, co-ordinator of the Andean Information Network, a human rights watchdog publicising problems with the eradication effort. "It's pointless trying to stop production in the producer countries - the place to fight it is where the market is." The bigger picture is indeed discouraging. While Bolivia has fallen from second to third largest cocaine exporter behind Colombia and Peru, there has been almost no reduction in the amount of cocaine exported to the US and Europe, according to the annual report of the International Narcotics Control Board. The explanation is that production has increased in Brazil and Colombia, where the governments have little control over their tropical territories.

"It's an obvious case of the balloon theory in operation," says Ledebur, who is an American. "You squeeze it in one place and it'll just expand in another unless you tackle root demand. Instead we've got a war focused on the poor people, and it is not working."

On a terraced hillside in the fertile Yungas valleys on the other side of the country, a small boy dressed in traditional poncho and woollen cap kneels to make his offering to Pachamama, or mother nature. As he unwraps a cloth full of coca leaves, lights an incense burner and sprinkles alcohol on the ground, other children come forward to sing in Quechua:

Green coca, you are born of our land/Your fragrance makes us sing happily/In the fields among the mountains/My little coca leaf is sweet medicine/Not a drug that does damage/We suck your juices for help in our work.

It is part celebration, part pre-emptive protest. The families of this region, the last remaining place of legal coca cultivation in Bolivia, know things could easily go the way of the Chapare for them. While Law 1008 currently provides for 12,000 hectares for traditional coca-growing and distribution in the Yungas, US officials have been arguing that less than half that is needed for chewing or ritual uses. "There is evidence that Yungas coca is being diverted to the illicit market for conversion to cocaine products," says the latest US embassy report on counter-narcotics. Local people believe that if they give in now, the North Americans will simply carry on demanding more until nothing is left.

Eradication was supposed to begin here later this year, until the country exploded in violent protests over the issue in April. Coca growers dynamited the only road into the region, and the eradicators backed off - until next year. A tense impasse continues, but nobody has any illusions that they will be back.

"The child in the US learns that he must buy things in order to be happy, whether it's Nike trainers or a gramme of cocaine," says Javier Castro, curator of the coca museum in La Paz. "That's the root of the problem, and everyone knows if they can't get their drugs here, they will just go somewhere else. In the meantime, they want to wipe out coca completely - it's a kind of cultural genocide. It's going to be as if we have no soul, no spirit."

Castro is one of many who have fought to have the coca leaf recognised as a potential health product rather than a schedule one drug. Western backpackers here drink coca tea constantly to ward off altitude sickness, and a Harvard University study found that 100g of Bolivian coca more than satisfied the recommended daily allowances of calcium, iron, phosphorus, vitamin A and riboflavin.

Contrary to popular belief, the burst of energy it gives comes not from the 0.5 cocaine content - this is in fact destroyed by saliva in the digestive tract, which is why cocaine users must snort or inject - but from its conversion of carbohydrates into glucose, and its stimulation of the respiratory system.

With at least 30 coca products already available in Bolivia, ranging from toothpaste to pick-me-up pastilles, campaigners argue that there is considerable potential for salvaging the livelihoods of many thousands of poor farmers by marketing the plant in the west.

But the only company which has managed to get round the ban is the Stepan company of the US. In one of the howling ironies of the coca war, it legally imports 175,000 kilos of Chapare coca each year to manufacture, among other things, a de-cocainised flavouring for Coca-Cola.

Castro is one of many who have fought to have the coca leaf recognised as a potential health product rather than a schedule one drug. Western backpackers here drink coca tea constantly to ward off altitude sickness, and a Harvard University study found that 100g of Bolivian coca more than satisfied the recommended daily allowances of calcium, iron, phosphorus, vitamin A and riboflavin. Contrary to popular belief, the burst of energy it gives comes not from the 0.5 cocaine content - this is in fact destroyed by saliva in the digestive tract, which is why cocaine users must snort or inject - but from its conversion of carbohydrates into glucose, and its stimulation of the respiratory system. With at least 30 coca products already available in Bolivia, ranging from toothpaste to pick-me-up pastilles, campaigners argue that there is considerable potential for salvaging the livelihoods of many thousands of poor farmers by marketing the plant in the west. But the only company which has managed to get round the ban is the Stepan company of the US. In one of the howling ironies of the coca war, it legally imports 175,000 kilos of Chapare coca each year to manufacture, among other things, a de-cocainised flavouring for Coca-Cola.

fields.headline: Usha Mehta
fields.trailText: Usha Mehta, who has died aged 80, was a veteran Gandhian and one of the key players in the Quit India movement. On August 9 1942, in a daring act, she unfurled the Indian national movement's tricolour in Bombay (now Mumbai) following the arrest by the British of the entire Congress leadership, including the Mahatma himself.
fields.body:
Usha Mehta, who has died aged 80, was a veteran Gandhian and one of the key players in the Quit India movement. On August 9 1942, in a daring act, she unfurled the Indian national movement's tricolour in Bombay (now Mumbai) following the arrest by the British of the entire Congress leadership, including the Mahatma himself.

She also launched an underground radio to spread Gandhi's call to the British to "Quit India", and his exhortation to his own people to "do or die" to achieve the goal of "complete independence from the foreign yoke". She was arrested for broadcasting on Congress radio, which she described as her "finest moment". It was also, she said, her saddest moment because it was an Indian technician who betrayed the broadcasters to the police. Mehta refused to answer the judge's questions, and was jailed for four years.

Born in Gujarat state, Mehta moved to Bombay in 1933 with her father, a judge, and went to Chandaramji high school. As a child, she met Gandhi, and became his ardent follower for the rest of her life, often in the vanguard of demonstrations. She remembered picketing liquor shops at a time when "slogans were our only weapons". She felt the struggle was not just to win political freedom, but was also a moral campaign.

Mehta became so singleminded in her dedication to the Gandhian philosophy that she vowed never to marry - a big decision in an era when Indian women were forced to marry at a young age. Even after inde- pendence, an event she felt was blighted by partition, Mehta continued to serve India and follow Gandhian principles.

More recently, she was disturbed by what she saw as the dirty politics and corrup tion of modern India. "Did our great leaders sacrifice their lives for this kind of India?" she would lament. "It is a pity the new generation of political activists and leaders are paying scant respect to the Gandhian ideas, the chief among which was non-violence. If we don't mend our ways, we may find ourselves back at square one."

Her closest surviving relative is a nephew, Ketan Mehta, the noted Hindi film-maker.

 Usha Mehta, independence campaigner, born March 25 1920; died August 12 2000

fields.headline: Girls are best
fields.trailText: For the past 50 years or so, there has been a slow shift towards equality (The mark for the male, August 24). And now - to the shock of us all! - girls are steaming ahead at school.
fields.body:
For the past 50 years or so, there has been a slow shift towards equality (The mark for the male, August 24). And now - to the shock of us all! - girls are steaming ahead at school. Why isn't anyone brave enough to say the obvious? With an equal start, girls are brighter, sassier, cleverer, and more mature. And the best lesson this year's successes can learn? To hang on to their lead, because by the time they enter the world of work, they're going to need it.

Kelly Webb-Lamb, London

fields.headline: The lottery of life
fields.trailText: Why have grades in academic exams at all (GCSE grades by subject, August 24)? Everything else in life is yes or no.
fields.body:
Why have grades in academic exams at all (GCSE grades by subject, August 24)? Everything else in life is yes or no. Driving tests are pass or fail; cancer is there or not; Britpop is in or out; you either win the lottery, or you don't.

Dave Lucas, Aldeburgh, Suffolk

Would it be fair to say (Planes, trains, phones, August 24) that the postponement of the decision on the National Lottery is bound to favour Richard Branson? After all, delays are part of his expertise, judging by the performance of Virgin trains.

Ray Sirotkin, London

As neither party managed to win the lottery contract, does this mean that we have a rollover on our hands ?

Matt Owen, Bexhill on Sea, E Sussex

It may be true that there are "not many votes to be won" by licensing the arms trade (Labour ditches ethical arms trade bill, August 23), but there are huge numbers to be lost from not doing so, as Blair's government will soon discover.

Lee Chadwick, Harrogate, N Yorks

John Nash, Wivenhoe, Essex

Les Brook, Shipley, W Yorks

Chris Langan, London

Then, presumably, I shall be able to continue to use my analogue set for watching videos without having to pay a licence fee for the dubious privilege of being able to receive television channels upon which I can almost never find anything worth watching.

Andrew Connell, London

webTitle: Leader: Dame Cartwright appointed governer-general of New Zealand

fields.headline: Where women rule
fields.standfirst: A near clean sweep in New Zealand
fields.trailText: Where New Zealand goes, could Britain follow? The country which gave women the vote as far back as 1893 and invented the welfare state is a pioneer once again as a new woman governor-general, Dame Silvia Cartwright, joins an impressive array of women at the top of its political system.
fields.body:
Where New Zealand goes, could Britain follow? The country which gave women the vote as far back as 1893 and invented the welfare state is a pioneer once again as a new woman governor-general, Dame Silvia Cartwright, joins an impressive array of women at the top of its political system. There has been a woman governor-general before, but not in this kind of full house. Dame Silvia takes over a nation where the prime minister is a woman, Helen Clark, as is the leader of the opposition (and Clark's predecessor as PM) Jenny Shipley - "bossy" versus "chilly" as the battle is known to less reconstructed voters. The highest figure in the judiciary is a woman, and so is the attorney-general; as, for good measure, is the head of Telecom New Zealand, its largest company. And, at least until the republicans get their way, the head of state is a woman, too.

All this progress might be thought a bit of a shock for a country famous for beefy rugby players, not for caring, sharing equality, but New Zealanders seem to have taken it (and even the election last year of the world's first transsexual MP and a pot-promoting Rastafarian colleague) with equanimity. But has it brought about a satisfied new age New Zealand, as one might hope?

Sadly, the answer seems to be no. True, Helen Clark's Labour government has built a runaway poll lead on the back of a compassionate left-wing agenda - but the country still lags behind all but two members of the OECD on the provision of maternity leave. Meanwhile New Zealanders are emigrating in record numbers (including, last year, one lone Kiwi who escaped to Andorra). Jenny Shipley, who leads the National party, made her name by ousting her predecessor in a bloody party coup and at one point called for celibacy for the single girl. A revolution more in personnel than policy, then; but a useful example nonetheless for Britain's still woman-starved politics.

webTitle: Leader: Euroland's interest rates must stay down

fields.headline: No need to be defensive
fields.standfirst: Euroland's interest rates must stay down
fields.trailText: If Europe's Central Bank had been in charge of American interest rates, then the US economy might never have enjoyed the unprecedented growth of these past nine years. The ECB seems bent on increasing interest rates in the euro area, even though Euroland's economy has barely emerged from the period of constraint when it had to sweat off excessive debt to bring fiscal policy into line with the Maastricht criteria.
fields.body:
If Europe's Central Bank had been in charge of American interest rates, then the US economy might never have enjoyed the unprecedented growth of these past nine years. The ECB seems bent on increasing interest rates in the euro area, even though Euroland's economy has barely emerged from the period of constraint when it had to sweat off excessive debt to bring fiscal policy into line with the Maastricht criteria. Now, at the first whiff of stronger growth, the bank wants to slam the brakes on again. It is worried about the weakness of the euro and the fact that inflation has breached the 2% ceiling it is supposed to defend. Yet if higher interest rates smother the recovery, the euro could end up falling not rising. In the long run, strong currencies are associated with strong economies.

Technically, the bank is right to worry about inflation since it is required to keep it below 2% (it is now 2.4%). But the overrun is largely due to the rise in oil prices which has affected the whole world. The ECB is worried that a weak euro will push inflation even higher - but higher interest rates are unlikely to boost the euro because its weakness is mainly a consequence of the strength of the US economy. If the ECB raises interest rates next week it will not be able to test whether Europe's economy might itself be on the verge of US-style growth. If it were, then the euro would recover without higher interest rates.

Europe should have more confidence in itself. Where are the risks in going for growth? Euroland will a have whacking trade surplus of $132bn this year, according to the OECD, and with pay rising at only 2.3% a year and with unemployment at 9.1% it could grow for some time without encountering labour shortages. Euroland is also over 90% self-sufficient, so most of the benefits of imports and exports will be self-reinforcing. The euro could also benefit from the recent moves to unlock the complex cross holdings in German industry - which should open up the economy to more takeover bids, particularly from American capital, thereby boosting the euro. No one wants to go back to the hyperinflation of the 70s, but circumstances are very different now because of the deflationary forces unleashed by globalisation and the internet. There is no reason why Euroland cannot have the sort of sustained growth than both the US and the UK have enjoyed. But first, the central bankers have to believe it is possible.

fields.headline: Subs' toll
fields.trailText: The Murmansk tragedy is a grim reminder of the hazards faced by submariners.Thousands of bodies lie entombed in the hundreds of submarines lying on the sea bed.
fields.body:
The Murmansk tragedy is a grim reminder of the hazards faced by submariners.Thousands of bodies lie entombed in the hundreds of submarines lying on the sea bed. German records list 751 U-boats lost between 1939 and 1945. The number of casualties suffered by our merchant seamen as a percentage was greater than that of any of the other services, but May 1943 was the turning point of the battle of the Atlantic. In that month, 41 U-boats were sunk, 321 of them with all hands.

RS Challender, Warrington

webTitle: Letters: How to keep dad home

fields.headline: How to keep dad home
fields.trailText: You argue (Leader, August 24) that the Industrial Society's idea of equalising parental rights rather than extending maternity rights is "close to utopian" and "a waste of legislative effort",
fields.body:
You argue (Leader, August 24) that the Industrial Society's idea of equalising parental rights rather than extending maternity rights is "close to utopian" and "a waste of legislative effort", because male identity is too closely tied up with career success for them to use such leave - implying the state would have to wait for a cultural shift before it introduced such policies.

Evidence from other countries suggests, however, that the state can lead cultural change. In Norway, where a portion of parental leave is allocated to the father and lost by the couple if it is not used, paternal take up rates increased from 45% in 1994 to 80% in 1996, when 68% of leave-takers took the full month allowed to them. Sixty-one per cent of Norwegian fathers now think that the paternity quota should be extended to eight weeks.

Dr Sarah Ashwin, London

The Industrial Society's attack on a better deal for working mothers (Family plan 'will make parents worse off', August 23) is disappointing from an organisation with a proud record of supporting better conditions for people at work. Some bad employers continue to discriminate against mothers and will continue to do so whether or not there are marginal improvements in maternity provision. But people already prepared to break the law should not be allowed to dictate the terms of future social advance

In fact, many more women with small children are working today than 10 years ago. The best employers make an investment in all their employees and go to great lengths to attract women back after maternity leave. Of course working parents need a better deal. Indeed everyone at work - with or without caring responsibilities - needs a better balance between work and the rest of their life, and protection against the long-hours culture. Sweeping generalisations do little to help working mothers or fathers.

John Monks, General secretary, TUC

webTitle: Letters: Why we should stick with America

fields.headline: Why we should stick with America
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee's enthusiasm for "my Europe right or wrong" is usually just amusing but when it's coupled with the anti-Americanism of her claim that "the more we look at alien America, the more European we feel" it moves to a higher level of Euro-rubbish (Comment, August 23).
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee's enthusiasm for "my Europe right or wrong" is usually just amusing but when it's coupled with the anti-Americanism of her claim that "the more we look at alien America, the more European we feel" it moves to a higher level of Euro-rubbish (Comment, August 23).

She shouldn't assume that her dismissal of American culture, politicians and values just because they're different to hers, is a majority view. Britain draws its popular and much of its elite culture from the US. Socialists and Thatcherites both look to US egalitarianism dynamics and freedoms. Investors are pouring money into its growing economy, perhaps because it has created 20m new jobs compared to almost none in Europe.

In consumption, social change, economics, IT and education where America goes we follow, always provided Europe's elitist, bureaucratic regulatory obsessions allow us. Moreover, US problems of budget, surplus, prolonging growth, dealing with poverty and globalisation are also ours, though they're more energetic, inventive and dynamic in seeking solutions. We should learn from the US not dismiss it.

No use criticising the Americans because they don't follow Polly Toynbee's prescriptions. Europe isn't either. Indeed they're of little interest to the real people who will be deciding the fate of Gore and Bush, though they at least are free to determine the way America goes, which is more than we are in the European Union.

Austin Mitchell MP

Polly Toynbee's worries about American dominance can only get worse. UN forecasts are that the population of the US will increase from 267m in 1995 to 349m in 2050 including immigration while the EU population (exclusive of the UK) drops from 314m in 1995 to 235m in 2050.

Future labour force comparisons are even more lopsided in favour of the Anglo-Saxons because of the huge rise in EU pensioners.

A Scholefield, UK Independence party

It has been people "looking to Jesus as their guiding influence" that has played a large part in challenging successive British governments on global warming, defence, third world debt and poverty.

Rev Kenneth G Walton, Clayton le Moors, Lancs

webTitle: Letters: What my Nova cover said

fields.headline: What my Nova cover said
fields.trailText: In her article on Nova, old and new, Caroline Roux found that "looking back over those old issues... not many measure up to its shining reputation" (Right idea, wrong decade, Media, August 7).
fields.body:
In her article on Nova, old and new, Caroline Roux found that "looking back over those old issues... not many measure up to its shining reputation" (Right idea, wrong decade, Media, August 7). One, however, which "still sends shiver down the spine," she says, showed "a cover image of a black man with a single cover line asking if you would really want him to be your neighbour".

There was no such cover. The cover alluded to showed not a man but a small, coloured girl in much white space. My cover-line read: "You may think I look cute but would you live next door to my mummy and daddy?" The South Africans withheld the issue.

The cover was reproduced with my article in the Evening Standard in December and has been widely reprinted, including,I think, in the Guardian magazine. Ms Roux's browsing either didn't happen or was through someone else's defective memory. Readers should therefore take her judgments on what is or is not "shining" with a large pinch of salt.

Dennis W Hackett, Morton-in-Marsh, Glos

fields.body:
The protest planned for next month in Prague is not about looking for a fight with the police or trashing McDonald's, contrary to the impression given in your report (Riots threaten Prague autumn, August 24). Nor have previous similar demonstrations been "riots". I was in Seattle for the protest which shut down the World Trade Organisation meeting last November. It was an inspiring show of unity by trade unionists, students, peace activists, environmentalists, women's groups and pensioners against the WTO and its priorities.

Thousands are going to Prague because they believe people should come before profit. The IMF-World Bank policies of enforcing debt repayments cause the deaths of 19,000 children in the third world every day. The protests in Seattle, Washington, Millau, Los Angeles and the one to come in Prague are a sign of a rising mood against the cruelty, injustice and violence of the world system.

Charlie Kimber, London

Why are there "fears" of a huge protest at the IMF summit in Prague, rather than hopes? Why might it be the "worst so far", rather than the best? Does the Guardian's world view completely exclude the possibility of massive demonstrations against global capitalism being a good thing?

Paul Deacon, Worthing, W Sussex

We take strong issue with Oxfam's allegation that the debt relief package for Zambia under the HIPC initiative is a "fraud" (Debt relief leaving the poor worse off, says Oxfam, August 21). On the contrary, the initiative will reduce Zambia's external debt by 60-65%, and debt service payments in 2001 will be cut as a result of the initiative from nearly $600m to $225m. After 2001, Zambia's debt service payments are projected to drop sharply further, to reach single digits as a percentage of exports from 2005 on.

It is true that, despite these efforts, debt service payments next year will be higher than this year, because of repayments to the IMF, which have been zero for a number of years. But this, of course, is not a proper basis for an assessment of the impact of HIPC.

I would note, however, that the IMF is front-loading its HIPC assistance to Zambia, providing close to 60% of all HIPC initiative assistance in 2001-02. It is also looking for additional ways to reduce the burden. And in any event, Zambia will be receiving more money from the IMF than it will be repaying.

Moreover, Oxfam is taking an unduly narrow view by ignoring the fact that grants and new concessional lending - on top of the HIPC initiative - are expected to provide an amount more than double Zambia's debt service in 2001.

If they are used appropriately, these funds can start to reverse some of the deterioration in human development indicators cited by Oxfam, ensuring that the poor are better off.

Ernesto Hernandez-Cata, International Monetary Fund

webTitle: Soccer star in bid to free TV crew

fields.headline: Soccer star in bid to free TV crew
fields.standfirst: Footbal Unlimited
fields.trailText: The Manchester City and Liberian striker George Weah plans to meet his country's president and hopes to persuade him to free the Channel 4 television crew held in the west African state on charges of espionage.
fields.body:
The Manchester City and Liberian striker George Weah plans to meet his country's president and hopes to persuade him to free the Channel 4 television crew held in the west African state on charges of espionage.

The former world footballer of the year is due to play an international at home against Mauritius on Sunday.

"The meeting has not been confirmed yet, but he knows President Charles Taylor and is a well known character in Liberia," Manchester City's chief executive, Chris Bird, said. "He wants to try his best to do what he can."

Weah has donated large sums of money to rebuild Liberia after its devastating seven-year civil war and is said to be on good terms with President Taylor.

Rev Jesse Jackson, the US special envoy to Africa, and former South African leader Nelson Mandela have appealed to the president on behalf of the men.

Two Britons, David Barrie and Zimbabwean-born Timothy Lambon, a South African, Gugulakhe Radebe, and a Sierra Leonean, Sorious Samura, have been under arrest for a week. The men, who work for the London-based Insight News production company, have been denied bail. The hearing is expected to resume tomorrow.

webTitle: Chinese police hold three US evangelists

fields.headline: Chinese police hold three US evangelists
fields.trailText: The Chinese police have cracked down on a rural Christian sect, detaining three foreign missionaries for allegedly breaking the law in Henan province, a northern region noted for its religious fervour and diversity.
fields.body:
The Chinese police have cracked down on a rural Christian sect, detaining three foreign missionaries for allegedly breaking the law in Henan province, a northern region noted for its religious fervour and diversity.

Up to 130 members of the protestant Fangcheng church, which believes in the literal truth of the Bible, were arrested, according to reports reaching Hong Kong.

The police in Xihua county confirmed that about 100 people were interrogated on Wednesday.

The Information Centre for Human Rights and Democracy, in Hong Kong, said three Chinese-American missionaries from California were among those arrested.

The Fangcheng church was founded in the town of that name and has spread throughout Henan.

Its spiritual leader, Zhang Rongliang, was sentenced to two years in a labour camp last December for "leading a cult", but was released on medical parole.

Fangcheng was the target of a campaign in the early 1990s by a US missionary movement, which advertised for Asian volunteers who could pass as Chinese and were willing to smuggle Bibles and tracts in their luggage.

The movement called them "donkeys for Jesus".

All forms of religion are popular in the Henan countryside, and peasants in the province have been denounced for building too many Buddhist and Taoist temples.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Troops killed in disputed region
fields.body:
Troops killed in disputed region

Indian forces claimed that they had they killed 10 Pakistani soldiers and wounded several others yesterday repulsing an attack on a post in Jammu and Kashmir state. One Indian soldier died in the exchange of fire and another was wounded.

Meanwhile Pakistan said its troops had repulsed an "unprovoked" Indian attack across the ceasefire line in the disputed region.

A military statement said two Pakistani soldiers had been killed, two were missing and Indian troops had suffered "heavy casualties".
Reuters Srinagar

£220m award in paedophile case

The family of a 10-year-old boy who was raped and killed by two men in the US has been awarded $328m (£221m) damages for his wrongful killing.

Neither Salvatore Sicari nor Charles Jaynes, the men convicted of the murder of Jeffrey Curley, has any assets to cover the award, but the lawyer for the boy's family said it was "grateful" to the jury in Middlesex county, Massachusetts, for the symbolic gesture.
Boston Globe

Monsoon rains claim more lives

Sixty-five people are dead and five missing after two days of heavy rain caused serious flooding in the southern Indian state of Andhra Pradesh.

About 300 people are feared dead in flooding in north and north-east India, Bhutan, Nepal and Bangladesh this monsoon season. Millions are homeless, hungry and prey to disease.
Reuters Hyderabad

Huge drug bust in Colombia

Police seized 1,400kg of pure cocaine, with a US street value of $238m (£160m), in a region of central Colombia controlled by outlaw paramilitary gangs.

It was the third big drug seizure in the past week, just days before President Bill Clinton visits Colombia on August 30.

Earlier this week Mr Clinton approved the handover of a record $1.3bn (£875m) package of mostly military aid to help Colombia fight the booming drug trade and powerful Marxist rebels.
Reuters Bogota

Paraguay vote breaks mould

The Liberal opposition candidate, Julio Cesar Franco, won Paraguay's vice-presidential election yesterday, breaking the ruling party's 53-year grip on high elective office.

His victory created the unusual situation of an opposition vice-president sharing office with a ruling party president.

The post had been vacant since the last vice-president was shot in March last year. Mr Franco won 47.8% of the vote and the Colorado party candidate Felix Argana, the son of the former vice-president, 47%.
Reuters Asuncion

Mosquitoes face swat squad

A village in northern Italy is holding the country's first mosquito-killing contest.

Twenty-five male contestants, armed only with their bare hands, will try to present judges with the most corpses after five minutes' swatting.

The winner will receive a gold mosquito and a gold medal.
AP Valle Lomellina

Making tracks to North Korea

South Korea will mobilise thousands of soldiers to clear mines on the 38th parallel to help reopen the railway to North Korea, Seoul announced yesterday.

Work on the railway will begin next month and is expected to take a year. There are also plans to build an inter-Korean road to Pyongyang. The railway will join the existing network, which leads across the Yalu river to China.
John Gittings Hong Kong

fields.headline: Families flee 'anarchy' of Kabila's Congo
fields.standfirst: Rebel leader urges civilians to help withstand the advance of government forces
fields.trailText: The witch doctor says the women's prayers will keep the bombs away. The female soldiers flicking rifle catches with varnished fingernails say rebel forces will protect the town.
fields.body:
The witch doctor says the women's prayers will keep the bombs away. The female soldiers flicking rifle catches with varnished fingernails say rebel forces will protect the town.

Zongo, in the guerrilla-held Equateur province in the north-west of the Democratic Republic of Congo, is preparing for President Laurent Ka bila's government troops to advance up the eastern frontier into rebel territory.

This week Mr Kabila suspended the peace accords and ceasefire agreed 12 months ago, "pending the amendment of some points".

Jean-Pierre Bemba, a 36-year-old rebel leader, was airlifted into town to boost morale.

"He told us the population and our army had to work together to defeat Kabila," said Jean Mogle, who was trying to sell flip-flops in the empty market place.

For the past fortnight government fighters have been bombing Libenge, south of Zongo. Already Zongo's hospital is filling up with casualties. Balimon Bilinga had his elbow blown away while farming. More than 60 men and women have arrived with bullet wounds.

But many of Libenge's 15,000 residents have fled in dugout canoes across the Ubangi river to the Central African Republic.

"They bombed the church, the school and the hospital. We had no choice but to leave," said Gerro Damango, who left with his family and pigs.

While the refugee women from Libenge sat round fires complaining of rocketing food prices and lack of medicine, some of the men said they would return to Congo to fight President Kabila's soldiers.

"Under Kabila there were public burnings of rebel supporters. Women were raped by Kabila's soldiers. There was anarchy," said Jean Menda, a literature teacher from Libenge.

Mr Bemba has the support of some business circles in Belgium and France, and is being courted by German com panies eager to exploit the area's timber resources.

The Central Africans are nervously expecting a flood of refugees should Mr Kabila's forces reach Zongo.

Their interior minister, Maurice Regonessa, said: "The influx of such a huge number of people will have to be the responsibility of the international community, not only the Central Africans. We have very little resources to deal with such a problem."

There are already more than 6,000 Congolese refugees in the Central African Republic. Makeshift houses are springing up daily along the banks of the Ubangi river.

Mathieu Garba, head of the police station of Mongoumba, across the river from Libenge, said: "We're getting around 300 refugees a day. We're concerned Kabila may try and bomb Mongoumba if they stay. We want to move them further inland."

But the refugees do not want to move any further from their villages.

Thousands have also fled into neighbouring Congo-Brazzaville. Fighting has stopped trade along the Ubangi river, which forms the border between the two countries, reducing food imports into the adjacent capitals of Brazzaville and Kinshasa by a third.

But according to UNHCR representatives in the Central African Republic capital, Bangui, the situation is likely to get worse before it gets better.

"While external forces are involved in the Democratic Republic of Congo there is unlikely to be peace.

"We're expecting things to move in Kabila's favour and there to be more refugees," the head of mission in Bangui, Eusebe Hounsokou, said.

As Makambaka Cieren prepared soup for her children from scraps she had gathered that day, she said: "This is the third time we've had to leave Libenge.

"I fled leaving my door open. I had nothing left for anyone to take. This time I may stay."

webTitle: Posh trolley wheeled out by store

fields.headline: Posh trolley wheeled out by store
fields.trailText: A posh person's supermarket trolley, with mobile phone holder, canape tray, champagne cooler and wine rack, gets its test run today at a Sainsbury's in a well-heeled district of west London.
fields.body:
A posh person's supermarket trolley, with mobile phone holder, canape tray, champagne cooler and wine rack, gets its test run today at a Sainsbury's in a well-heeled district of west London.

It also has chrome bumpers, ergonomic steering and shock absorbers, and comes in this season's fashionable colour - mauve. And there is a padded baby seat in co-ordinating colours.

The prototype trolley accompanies a refurbishment of the Sainsbury's in Cromwell Road, Kensington, to be opened today by television chef Jamie Oliver. A Sainsbury's spokeswoman said: "It's the store which sells the most champagne and organic food - which shows the kind clientele we have. They are known for wanting the finer things in life, and we're giving them a trolley that matches their aspirations."

Staff and agencies

webTitle: Millions go to waste in MoD budget

fields.headline: Millions go to waste in MoD budget
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence wasted nearly £30m on defective computer systems, failed to detect a near £500,000 fraud for more than 12 months and overspent its budget for the fourth consecutive year, MPs said in a report published today.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence wasted nearly £30m on defective computer systems, failed to detect a near £500,000 fraud for more than 12 months and overspent its budget for the fourth consecutive year, MPs said in a report published today.

Confirming Whitehall's record of wasting millions of pounds of taxpayers' money on new technology, the Commons public accounts committee chided the MoD for spending £29.7m on two computer systems it had to abandon because they did not work properly.

One was to replace teleprinters for signals to and from RAF units. Initiated in 1989, it was abandoned in 1997 and replaced by a much cheaper, off-the-shelf system. The other was to replace the navy's pay system.

The committee said Marvin Hamill, 45, an executive officer in the pensions division at the army personnel centre in Glasgow, embezzled over £470,000 before he was detected and jailed for four years for fraud. The fraud could have been prevented if there had been "robust" segregation of duties and proper protection of passwords.

The MPs said the MoD exceeded its budget on two accounts by £37.1m in the year ending April 1999, mainly as a result of failures in financial forecasting and management.

The MoD said last night the overspend was caused by a small number of receipts coming in a few weeks late and some unforeseen expenditure on Kosovo. It had actually underspent its overall cash limit that year by £73.9m.

fields.headline: Dolphins on way to language
fields.trailText: Dolphins have been found to have not only their own signature tune, but also to make long distance calls to each other at sea. They could, scientists believe, have taken a first step towards language.
fields.body:
Dolphins have been found to have not only their own signature tune, but also to make long distance calls to each other at sea. They could, scientists believe, have taken a first step towards language.

Vincent Janik used hi-tech devices to listen to dolphins in the Moray Firth in 1994-95, while he was at St Andrews and Aberdeen universities.

Each had a signature whistle, not just one note but a short pattern of notes, but each could also mimic the signatures of other dolphins.

He came across evidence of one dolphin calling another - and getting an answer. On 39 occasions, two dolphins would emit whistles of the same type within three seconds of each other. The average distance between these "Are you there?" calls was 179 metres: at even a seventh of that, individuals could not possibly see each other.

Dr Janik concluded that the calls were a way of keeping in touch that could be thought of as an important step in the evolution of human language.

fields.headline: Six months for riotous ex-Etonian
fields.trailText: A former Eton schoolboy who threw a chair at a McDonald's restaurant during the May Day riots was yesterday ordered to serve six months in a detention centre.
fields.body:
A former Eton schoolboy who threw a chair at a McDonald's restaurant during the May Day riots was yesterday ordered to serve six months in a detention centre.

The self-styled anarchist, who cannot be named for legal reasons, was sentenced at west London youth court. The 17-year-old had earlier admitted charges of violent disorder and criminal damage following the demonstrations in central London.

The court heard how police video evidence captured the teenager damaging a metal barrier near Downing Street, kicking a window outside McDonald's where he is also said to have thrown a chair and later hurled bottles at police.

The youth was easily picked out on film as he was wearing a wizard-style hat and carrying a bright yellow bag.

Stipendiary magistrate David Simpson said: "It is not normal May Day headgear. It looks like he was dressed for the part."

Mark Ashford, defending, said the boy did not visit London intending to cause trouble. "It was only when he got there that he was caught up in the hysteria.

"He accepts he threw bottles but they were empty drink cartons made of aluminium and plastic."

He also spoke of the boy's previous good character and many talents.

But Mr Simpson told the youth: "By your consistent violent behaviour you have caused police and public to fear for their safety and in fact their lives. Nothing short of a custodial sentence could be justified."

He ordered that the youth should pay £26.43 in compensation and added that he could be allowed out of the detention centre after three months, for good behaviour.

The youth was easily picked out on film as he was wearing a wizard-style hat and carrying a bright yellow bag. Stipendiary magistrate David Simpson said: "It is not normal May Day headgear. It looks like he was dressed for the part." Mark Ashford, defending, said the boy did not visit London intending to cause trouble. "It was only when he got there that he was caught up in the hysteria. "He accepts he threw bottles but they were empty drink cartons made of aluminium and plastic." He also spoke of the boy's previous good character and many talents. But Mr Simpson told the youth: "By your consistent violent behaviour you have caused police and public to fear for their safety and in fact their lives. Nothing short of a custodial sentence could be justified." He ordered that the youth should pay £26.43 in compensation and added that he could be allowed out of the detention centre after three months, for good behaviour. Staff and agencies

webTitle: British drug mule jailed, and married

fields.headline: British drug mule jailed, and married
fields.trailText: A British woman caught trying to smuggle heroin with a street value of £300,000 out of Turkey was jailed for five years in Istanbul yesterday. After she was sentenced, Alison McKinnon married Max Allen, another Briton, in a prison ceremony witnessed by a British consulate official.
fields.body:
A British woman caught trying to smuggle heroin with a street value of £300,000 out of Turkey was jailed for five years in Istanbul yesterday. After she was sentenced, Alison McKinnon married Max Allen, another Briton, in a prison ceremony witnessed by a British consulate official.

With good behaviour in jail she will serve two years, as she has been in custody for five months.

McKinnon, from Devon, was detained at Istanbul airport in March before she was to board a flight to Britain. A body search revealed 3kg of heroin strapped to her chest.

Her case was given prominence in the Turkish media because police said her body piercing had set off a metal detector and given her away.

She told the judge: "I am very sorry. This was the first time, and it won't happen again."

She was initially sent to a prison in Istanbul, but officials said she would probably serve most of her sentence in Bilecik in the north-west, where most foreign inmates are sent.

Prosecutors had asked for a longer sentence, but the panel of judges at the Istanbul state security court were more lenient because McKinnon cooperated with police, giving them information about Turkish accomplices.

A Turkish citizen living in Britain, Selahattin Menguc, also received a five year jail sentence, for supplying the heroin McKinnon was carrying. A street value of £300,000 is a tiny amount compared with the billions made by drugs gangs in Turkey.

webTitle: Plenty more chips to cash in

fields.headline: Plenty more chips to cash in
fields.standfirst: ARM Holdings has been the stock market sensation of the last three years. Lindsay Vincent asks the man at the helm if its amazing success can continue.
fields.trailText: Few men in their early 20s can afford fearsome, ferocious, and far from frugal motor cars. But the chap in the staff car park of ARM Holdings, a company that did not exist just 10 years ago yet is now a constituent of the FTSE-100 index, had every reason to be sanguine about the probable pattern of his life. 'One hopes to become a millionaire,' he says. 'I am a design engineer.'
fields.body:
Few men in their early 20s can afford fearsome, ferocious, and far from frugal motor cars. But the chap in the staff car park of ARM Holdings, a company that did not exist just 10 years ago yet is now a constituent of the FTSE-100 index, had every reason to be sanguine about the probable pattern of his life. 'One hopes to become a millionaire,' he says. 'I am a design engineer.'

Corporate car parks can occasionally reveal much about the character of the bus and train dodgers who use them. The vehicles in the staff car park at ARM Holdings, on the outskirts of Cambridge, now a boom town, resemble those to be found at the nearby university, where there is a distaste for demonstrative wealth. At ARM, the resident millionaires seem to prefer scruff and dust, rather than the gleam machine of the design engineer.

ARM, then, makes millionaires, but it makes nothing that most of us could regard as a product. ARM is an 'intellectual property' enterprise, and its business is the design of silicon chips. The company's assets are its people, patent portfolio, design methods and experience rather than physical assets. The last annual report says on the cover: 'Chances are that you have just used an ARM Powered product within the last hour, minute or second'.

It is not an idle boast. The microchips that the company designs are found in a variety of consumer products, ranging from cars to mobile telephones and from fax machines to refrigerators. ARM is the world leader in its field and its recent elevation into the FTSE 100 index reflects the breathtaking rating that the investment community affords the company, now thought to have made millionaires of 40 per cent of its 500-strong staff.

The company is capitalised at some £7,494 million, yet pre-tax profits in 1999 were just £18.8 million. But 1999 profits rose by 85 per cent on the previous year and the only unknown about this year's outcome is the extent to which profits will leave last year's total in the shade. Results for the June quarter showed a 117 per cent increase in pre-tax profits - a gain achieved on a 60 per cent rise in sales to £23.1 million during the period. Both figures exceeded analysts' forecasts, but this is something the company achieves regularly.

With its shares trading at more than 400 times last year's earnings, ARM is outrageously expensive. Yet on release of the latest profit figures last month, the company's fan club in the City gained plenty more recruits as the price moved upwards in appreciation of the outcome. Indeed, one organ, the Times, commented remarkably that the shares were worth holding 'at any price'.

By the beginning of the August holidays, however, these new club members surely rued the taking out of their chequebooks, for the price took a sudden pounding - at one stage down 14 per cent in just two weeks. The shares are currently at 662p, having traded at between 173p and 1005p over the last 12 months. The killjoy was largely Nokia, the Finnish mobile telephone manufacturer, which not only dominates the Helsinki stock exchange but has grown to a size where it now ranks as the most valued quoted enterprise in Europe.

Nokia wrong-footed the markets with an unexpected profits warning, and analysts scurried to retrieve their reputations by downgrading profit predictions for all manner of communications groups. The malaise was then compounded by Motorola - after Nokia, the world's second-largest mobile telephone manufacturer - which said it would slash this year's production by a prodigious 15 million units and, as a result, profit figures would be lower than the investment community had hitherto anticipated.

One broker, Nomura Securities, says ARM earnings will have to rise by some 40 per cent a year if the current rating is to be justified. Nomura's Keith Woolcock, who has long argued that the rating is excessive, took comfort from the Nokia and Motorola figures and explains: 'ARM has one of the strongest business models out there but it is overvalued. It is a classic separation between the share price and a great company.'

But markets are a two-way bet and, right now, Woolcock's view is far from universal, since some believe that ARM will indeed achieve annual growth of two-score or more. The company has made a habit of beating the market's expectations, and the outcome of the latest quarterly results is no exception.

'We can't sit here and say we have made it,' says James Urquhart, ARM's chief operating officer, an Americanism that translates as managing director. 'The biggest competition we face is ourselves. We have got to keep evolving the technology: we want to be the architects for the digital world and we have a big vision, but as Mike Dell [chairman and CEO of Dell Computer] said: "Don't breathe your own exhaust".' As for his view on the share price, Urquhart does not have one he will share with the rest of us.

ARM licenses its products to some 44 manufacturers and, in addition, it receives royalties from on-going sales. The list of customers reads like a Who's Who of the wired world: Epson, IBM, Panasonic, Microsoft, Toshiba, Yamaha, Sony, Samsung and so on.

However, only 21 of the 44 customers are now shipping products that incorporate ARM's technology. In part, this is explained by the rapid pace of technological development. Hitherto, chips for consumer appliances tended to be very simple and often made by the same firm that made the appliance. But the new generation requires much more processing power, and ARM's strengths - protected by copyright patents - are the performance of its designs plus affordability. Some 15 per cent of sales are now for so-called 'development systems'. These are software packages used by engineers who are employed by ARM's customers. They help them create integrated chip systems for products based around ARM technology. The high level of development systems sales indicates that manufacturers are preparing to ship increasing volumes of goods that will incorporate ARM products.

Urquhart, 43, has been with ARM since the company was founded. 'There is no one hero here,' he says. 'It is teams of people that make things happen.' Originally called Advanced Risc Machines, ARM was a joint venture between Acorn, one of Britain's personal computer companies, and US companies Apple and VSLI. The idea, inspired by Hermann Hausser, a founder of Acorn and one of Britain's foremost venture capitalists, was to design Risc chips (Risc stands for reduced instruction set computing). Essentially, they are faster, cheaper and more efficient than conventional chips.

'Cambridge was inward-looking in those days. It has since become a magnet for venture capitalists and is no longer insular,' says Urquhart, a graduate of Bath University who originally intended a career as a nuclear physicist. He was sponsored at university by Plessey and went on to work for the company. 'At Plessey, the path from research to product was not easy. I left in 1983 to join Acorn, which was pretty advanced in its use of chip technology. The hardware was ambitious and that is what attracted me to the company. I still have an early Acorn computer in my study. Even my 11 year-old son plays with it.'

ARM made an early decision not to make the chips it designed. 'Complex chips have a lot of different building blocks in them,' he says. 'It's like houses. We are producing a standard building block and it is for others to focus on adding value. It looked an odd business model at the beginning, but it made much more sense to license than to manufacture ourselves.' There are some 150 semiconductor manufacturers around the world and 44 of them are licensed to use ARM technology. Eight of the top 10 are customers, the exceptions being Intel and Motorola. 'We all have a fixed interest in making things happen,' says Urquhart. 'Our strength is our focus.'

Two areas of particular interest to ARM are its emerging digital technology and the development of Bluetooth technology. Both are crucial to the company's medium-term prospects. Bluetooth is named after the 10th century Danish king, Harald Blatand (Bluetooth), whose famed communications skills united Norway and Denmark. Bluetooth is now the name of a piece of silicon that will allow billions of electronic devices to talk to each other via internet and intranets without unsightly cables.

Relaxed about the competition

Urquhart does not expect any one company to emerge with a grip on Bluetooth technology and is seemingly relaxed about the progress achieved so far by a rival company, ARC. 'We see different companies in different market segments. Therefore none can be ignored. We are not competing against any one architecture, but there is overlap - our job is not to screw up.'

Uppermost in the company's thinking is staff. Alongside ARM chief executive Robin Saxby, Urquhart believes in the stakeholder ideal. 'Getting good people is very important, which may sound trite. We have a philosophy that we will not restrict ourselves to the Cambridge area. We have the nucleus of a new design centre in Sheffield and have just bought a company in Nice. We will go wherever the engineers are. All staff have share options. We regard this as terribly important, not just because it brings a sense of shared responsibility. It brings people together. People here can work late into the evening, not because they want the money but because they own a piece of the company,' he says.

Urquhart is not impressed by the government's decision to make more money available for university research, a move to stem the alleged 'brain drain'. He says: 'This is not a concept we use. If there is a brain drain, it is because people want to work on interesting things. Our people get a great kick out of seeing their research translated into products.'

fields.headline: Late entrant
fields.standfirst:
Nintendo's Gamecube trails next generation console rivals
Special report: e-finance
fields.trailText: Nintendo yesterday became the last of Japan's big game machine makers to enter the competitive market for next-generation consoles by revealing it would start selling Gamecube in Japan next July.
fields.body:
Nintendo yesterday became the last of Japan's big game machine makers to enter the competitive market for next-generation consoles by revealing it would start selling Gamecube in Japan next July.

The company also announced its new 32-bit hand-held Gameboy Advance, which analysts said would maintain Nintendo's dominance in that market but which will hit the shops later than they and software makers had expected.

Both machines will be internet capable and Nintendo said it would sell an adapter to link the original Gameboy and Gameboy Advance with mobile phones, enabling users to exchange email and play games online.

In the first month, Nintendo aims to ship 1m units of Gameboy Advance, which is a similar size to the original eight-bit version but with a 50% bigger screen, and will release 10 games when it launches.
